The Black Years are a period in the rule of the High King, Artur Hawkwing, spanning the latter part of the Consolidation and the early part of the organization of his Empire. They are generally held to have begun in FY 961 and ended in FY 965. They are also called the "Years of Silent Rage."

In FY 959, Hawkwing's son, Modair, was killed in battle. Although Hawkwing grieved, such things are to be expected in war. However, two years later Hawkwing's queen, Amaline Paendrag Tagora was poisoned, along with Modair's twin sister Amira and Hawkwing's younger two children.

Hawkwing flew in a rage and prosecuted his war against the last surviving free kingdom, Aldeshar, with unusual and cruel savagery. He held King Joal Ramedar as being responsible for the deaths of his family, despite Ramedar's protestations to the contrary. Hawkwing refused to accept the surrender of several Aldeshari generals after defeating them, instead massacring them and their entire armies. Hawkwing's Aes Sedai adviser, Chowin Tsao, left his service in protest over this butchery. When the kingdom finally surrendered in FY 963, Hawkwing treated the kingdom harshly. Ramedar was executed, instead of being made an Imperial Governor as other former rulers had. The nobility was disenfranchised, its lands seized, and the nobles exiled and scattered to the far corners of the Empire.

The following year Hawkwing launched an ill-considered and poorly-planned invasion of the Aiel Waste. The Aiel proved unwilling to meet Hawkwing in open battle, instead harrying his flanks and supply lines. Hawkwing was forced to retreat after several months, the first and greatest defeat of his military career.

Hawkwing emerged from the Black Years when he met and fell in love with the lady Tamika. A woman thirty years his junior, Tamika brought him out of his depression and made him laugh once more. They married in FY 965 within a year of meeting one another, and in FY 967 she gave birth to their first son, Luthair Paendrag Mondwin. Several more children followed. At Tamika's urging, Hawkwing accepted a new Aes Sedai adviser in FY 967, repairing (temporarily) the rift with Tar Valon the Black Years had opened. Hawkwing also restored the nobility and merchant classes of Aldeshar to their homeland, which was now the Imperial Province of Andor, and even appointed King Ramedar's daughter Endara Casalain as Imperial Governor of the province.

Whilst Hawkwing did not fully fall into the Black Years once more, a similar rage, but this time highly directed and applied only to the Aes Sedai, appeared in FY 974, when he dismissed all Aes Sedai from all posts throughout the Empire and the following year he laid siege to Tar Valon. The cause of this rage is unknown, but it has been suggested that Hawkwing's new counselor, Jalwin Moerad, had brought evidence that it was in fact the Aes Sedai who had poisoned Amaline and their children. However, this remains speculation at best.

Blacklance.name: Blacklance
Blacklance.overview: A blacklance is a black-scaled snake approximately seven feet long. Blacklances are as quick as lightning and very poisonous. This breed of snake is solitary and won't attack unless it means to feed... or is provoked.

Blacksmith (Constellation).name: Blacksmith (Constellation)
Blacksmith (Constellation).overview: One of the constellations seen over the night skies of the Westlands.

Blacksmith Strikes the Blade.name: Blacksmith Strikes the Blade
Blacksmith Strikes the Blade.overview: Blacksmith Strikes the Blade is a sword form. Other than the name, nothing is known about it.

Blademaster.name: Blademaster
Blademaster.overview: Blademasters are acknowledged masters of sword -based combat. Although a title of sorts, it is not a proper noun and written all in lower case.

Blasted Lands.name: Blasted Lands
Blasted Lands.overview:
The lands surrounding Shayol Ghul are said to have borne the brunt of the War of Power, and are thus known as the Blasted Lands. Dead and lifeless, they are kept that way by the increasing influence of the Dark One, as they are the location of the mountain of Shayol Ghul, and thus more susceptible to it than even the Great Blight. The valley of Thakan'dar is part of the Blasted Lands, and in Thakan'dar lies Shayol Ghul.

To the south lies the Great Blight, and to the north, an icy wasteland which none have explored. Few have even reached the Blasted Lands. Jain Farstrider is the last known to have tried—without intention of suicide, at least—and in his attempt he was captured by the Shadow. The army of Lain Mandragoran, uncle of al'Lan Mandragoran, was said to have been destroyed in the Blasted Lands, though it is more likely that they fell in the Great Blight. However, the fact that the Blasted Lands even have a name indicates that people have seen it in the past.

Blightborder.name: Blightborder
Blightborder.overview: The Blightborder is the northern border of the Westlands, running along the southern edge of the Blight.

Blinder's Peak.name: Blinder's Peak
Blinder's Peak.overview: Blinder's Peak is part of the foothills northeast of the Damona Mountains in Murandy. It can be mistaken for nearby Mount Sardlen or Favlend Mountain.

Blood Feud.name: Blood Feud
Blood Feud.overview: The Aiel term for being in a state of war with another Aiel clan or sept. They arise from matters of ji'e'toh, as opposed to the more typical conflict over water and other resources. All blood feuds between the Aiel that chose to accept Rand as the Car'a'carn were ended, as they unified behind him.

Bloodknife.name: Bloodknife
Bloodknife.overview: Bloodknives are the most elite members of the Fists of Heaven, itself an exclusive group.

Bloodlance.name: Bloodlance
Bloodlance.overview: Bloodlance is a tall bay horse that belongs to Harril.

Bloodsnake.name: Bloodsnake
Bloodsnake.overview: A bloodsnake is a large brown snake of the Aiel Waste.

Bloodwash Falls.name: Bloodwash Falls
Bloodwash Falls.overview: A place where someone in Mat ’s memories fought Nashif.

Bloody Water.name: Bloody Water
Bloody Water.overview: The Bloody Water is a sept of the Taardad Aiel. The sept hold is unknown. On their way to Alcair Dal, Rand al'Thor and the Jindo are joined by other Taardad septs including the Nine Valleys, Chumai, Four Stones, Bloody Water and Miadi septs.

Blue Ajah.name: Blue Ajah
Blue Ajah.overview:
The Blue Ajah of the Aes Sedai normally involve themselves with righteous causes and justice. They have the most extensive eyes-and-ears network, and enjoy the prestige of having the highest number of Amyrlin Seats raised from their Ajah in the last millennium.

The Blue has been at odds with the Red Ajah for a millennium and for a time were separate from the White Tower altogether. The head of the Blue Ajah is called the First Selector.

See also List of Blue Ajah sisters.

Blue Crane.name: Blue Crane
Blue Crane.overview: The Blue Crane is a ship that travels on the River Erinin.

Blue goatflower.name: Blue goatflower
Blue goatflower.overview:
Not much is known of blue goatflowers. It was mentioned in a conversation, which was really more of an interrogation, between Nynaeve al'Meara and Mother Ailhuin Guenna, where they compared remedies.

In short, made in a hot poultice and water, boiled blue goatflowers improves the healing of broken bones.

Blue Gull.name: Blue Gull
Blue Gull.overview: Blue Gull is the ship of Zaida din Parede Blackwing.

Blue Reception Room.name: Blue Reception Room
Blue Reception Room.overview: The Blue Reception Room is so named for its arched ceiling which is "painted to display the sky and white clouds, and its blue floor tiles." It is the smallest of the reception rooms in the Royal Palace of Andor, measuring less than ten paces square. It contains two large fireplaces with carved marble mantels. A cornice of plaster lions and a pair of tapestries bearing the White Lion of Andor flank the doors. Its arched windows stand opposite the doors and overlook a courtyard, it front of which sit the simply carved reception chairs. This puts the light behind whoever sits in them, granting them an advantage as a delegation must usually squint into the glare.

Bluespine tea.name: Bluespine tea
Bluespine tea.overview: Bluespine is an herb found in the Aiel Waste. A Wise One will brew a tea of bluespine, which has an exceptionally bitter taste, and administer a dosage to someone she feels is being disagreeable. Bluespine tea "cures" sullenness, sulkiness, or foul-mouthed language.

Bluewing.name: Bluewing
Bluewing.overview: The Bluewing is a river boat that operates on the River Erinin. She is a two-masted vessel.

Bluewort.name: Bluewort
Bluewort.overview: Bluewort is an herb that can be found in the Two Rivers region and in Tear. It can be brewed as a tea and administered to ease a queasy stomach. Bluewort also can be used as a dye, producing a purple-blue color.

Boannda.name: Boannda
Boannda.overview:
For the chapter in The Fires of Heaven called "To Boannda", see The Fires of Heaven/Chapter 49 .

Boannda is a town in Ghealdan. It lies at the point where the River Boern joins the River Eldar and is considered to be a large town, with three towers and a small palace.

The village's name has an eerie resemblance to Semirhage 's original name, Nemene Damendar Boann.

Boern.name: Boern
Boern.overview: The River Boern is a river that flows through Ghealdan. It flows out of the Mountains of Mist and flows past Jehannah on its way to Boannda, where it joins the River Eldar at the border of Amadicia.

Boneknit.name: Boneknit
Boneknit.overview: Boneknit is an herb known for its healing properties, specifically when used to heal broken bones. Nynaeve al'Meara references the herb in a discussion with Ailhuin Guenna in Tear, though they each know it by a different name. This suggests that the plant is one that grows over a large portion of the continent.

Book of Translation.name: Book of Translation
Book of Translation.overview:
The Book of Translation is an artifact in the possession of the Ogier. Its full capabilities and origin are unknown at this time. However, it is known that the Book possesses the power to move or transport the Ogier race between worlds. Whether this is between different planets or different reflections of this world (such as the portal stone dimensions) is unclear.

The Ogier used the Book of Translation to come to this world some immeasurable time before the War of the Shadow, during or before the Age of Legends, and according to prophecy or history they believe they will one day use the Book to depart this world. According to the Ogier, there are some Ages of the Wheel of Time in which they are not present in the world, and during these times they exist somewhere else. When the appropriate Age comes again, they will return via the Book of Translation.

The Ogier have always had the option of using the Book of Translation to flee should they ever be imperiled as a species, yet chose not to exercise this option during the War of the Shadow, nor even during the Breaking of the World that followed it. They also chose not to flee during the Trolloc Wars. In each case they stood and fought the Shadow alongside their human allies. However, in 999 and 1000 NE the Ogier Great Stump began meeting to discuss opening the Book of Translation and fleeing ahead of the Last Battle, which, it was becoming increasingly clear, was imminent. The Ogier fell into two camps during the argument, one favoring this move and the other opposing it, on the grounds that should the Dark One win the Last Battle, then any other world they fled to may be in danger as well. There was also the matter of Longing, which may result in the Ogier dying if they are moved from the proximity of the stedding for more than a few years. Covril of Stedding Shangtai was not in favor of opening the book, but spoke for doing so anyway in order to give a strong argument for both sides. Elder Haman and Covril's son Loial take the opposing view, and Loial's speech eventually convinces the stump that the Ogier should remain and take part in the Last Battle.

Borderlands.name: Borderlands
Borderlands.overview:
The Borderlands are the Westland nations which lie furthest to the north and directly border the Great Blight. In modern times the term refers to the four countries of Shienar, Arafel, Kandor and Saldaea. Ten nations have been part of the Borderlands since the Breaking of the World, although the term did not come into use until at least the time of Artur Hawkwing, if not much later.

Jaramide and Aramaelle were the two original Borderland nations, until Aramaelle was destroyed in the Trolloc Wars and Jaramide collapsed shortly thereafter. Out of their ruins arose Basharande, Elsalam and Rhamdashar, which guarded the Blight during the Free Years. These kingdoms were conquered by Artur Hawkwing, who split them into five provinces of his Empire: Saldaea, Kandor, Arafel, Shienar and Malkier, though Shienar did not become a Borderland nation until the destruction of Malkier many years later.

During the War of the Hundred Years the five Borderland provinces broke away and declared both independence and also an alliance with one another, agreeing to aid one another against both the Shadow in the north and any attempts by the southern nations to attack them.

Malkier was destroyed by internal betrayal and external attack in 955 NE. Its territories were consumed by the Blight and Shienar took its place as the easternmost Borderland country. The four remaining nations share a military lifestyle of constant vigilance against the Blight to the north.

For 3,000 years the nations of the Borderlands have guarded the Westlands against Shadowspawn from the Blight. The culture of the Borderlands is the most martial of all Westlands and many of the best soldiers hail from the Borderlands. Due to the Borderlanders' view that all humankind must stand together if the shadow is to be held back, as well as their widespread respect for combat prowess, Aes Sedai will find more appreciation in these lands than elsewhere.

In the Borderlands, all men carry swords at all times in case of attack. Due to the constant threat, no country in the Borderlands has a distinct elite military formation.

Although their primary war is with the Blight, the Borderlanders also respect but have enmity with the Aiel, mainly due to the Aiel raids on Shienar through the Niamh Passes which distract Shienar from the threat of the Shadow. All four Borderlands sent substantial armies to the Grand Alliance against the Aiel during the Aiel War, but those from Saldaea and Kandor had to turn back due to increased Shadowspawn raids. 29,000 men from Shienar and 21,000 men from Arafel fought at the Battle of the Shining Walls, however, along with a small force of Malkieri veterans under al'Lan Mandragoran.

The Borderlands do not generally concern themselves with the affairs of southlanders. However, in 998 NE Moiraine Damodred and al'Lan Mandragoran, the heir to Malkier's throne, came to Fal Dara in Shienar with a party of Andorans and an Ogier. In a quest that rapidly became a legend in the Borderlands, they found the legendary Eye of the World and the Green Man, and are credited with somehow turning the tide of battle at Tarwin's Gap, where the army of Shienar was about to be overrun by a Trolloc horde ten times larger. After this, a party of Shienarans, including a sniffer named Hurin, accompanied these travelers on a series of adventures culminating in an epic battle at Falme where Rand al'Thor was proclaimed the Dragon Reborn. Hurin returned to Shienar and reported these events to Lord Agelmar Jagad, who in turn alerted the other Borderland rulers. As a result, an army of 200,000 men from the Borderlands marched south under the direct command of the four Borderland rulers with a mission to seek out al'Thor and see if he is the true Dragon Reborn. After leaving Andor the Armies of the Borderlands met Rand al'Thor at Far Madding, and after questioning him, they joined his forces and went with him to the Field of Merrilor.

Bore.name: Bore
Bore.overview:
In the Age of Legends, Aes Sedai researchers led by the esteemed scholar Beidomon at the Collam Daan discovered a region of the Pattern with what appeared to be an undivided source of the One Power separate from the True Source. Initial research suggested that this energy could be used by either gender without many of the known limitations of the One Power.

An attempt was made to access this new energy source by boring a hole in the Pattern. The resulting explosion destroyed the Sharom of Collam Daan. What the researchers had found was actually the prison of the Dark One. The resulting hole is known as the Bore, and although it has not allowed the Dark One to escape, it does allow him to influence the world.

Over the next hundred years the Dark One's influence in the world grew and his touch caused a degeneration in what had previously been a peaceful utopian society. With time people turned to the Shadow, openly declaring their loyal allegiance to the Dark One, and rose up against the existing order which eventually culminated in The War of Power.

The Bore was later sealed by Lews Therin Telamon in an attempt to imprison the Dark One. The backlash from the Dark One against this act tainted saidin. The Bore itself is described as a metaphysical point in space where the Pattern is its thinnest. It is due to this thinness that the Dark One is able to exert such control over the reality of the Bore's immediate surroundings.

During Tarmon Gai'don, the Bore was opened completely when Logain broke the remaining seals. Rand al'Thor, linked through Callandor with Nynaeve al'Meara, Moiraine Damodred, and Moridin, sealed the Bore permanently by using a pure form of the One Power to recreate the Dark One's prison anew. A shield made of the True Power protected the One Power from the Dark One's backlash. After this event, the Dark One can no longer touch the world directly.

Braem.name: Braem
Braem.overview: Braem was a city of Coremanda, one of the Ten Nations. It was built by Ogier, but was not the capital. It was destroyed by Shadowspawn during the Trolloc Wars. The modern town of New Braem in Andor is located near its ruins. Braem gave its name to the surrounding extensive forests, which are now known collectively as Braem Wood.

Braem Wood.name: Braem Wood
Braem Wood.overview:
Braem Wood is an extensive area of woodland on the northeastern borders of Andor, east and southeast of Caralain Grass and along the western banks of the River Erinin, south of Tar Valon.

Braem Wood is quite large and consists of numerous lesser forests with many towns and villages located within its boughs. The largest town of the region is New Braem, located near the site of Braem, an Ogier -built city of Coremanda that was destroyed in the Trolloc Wars. The main highway linking Caemlyn to Tar Valon runs through Braem Wood.

Other Andoran towns and villages located within Braem Wood include Kore Springs and Jornhill.

Braid.name: Braid
Braid.overview: Braided hair is a common occurrence in the Westlands, though in some cultures it holds a special social significance.

Breaking of the World.name: Breaking of the World
Breaking of the World.overview: The Breaking of the World, also known as the Time of Madness, was a period when male Aes Sedai destroyed much of the world, ending the Age of Legends, and heralding the beginning of the Third Age.

Breen's Spring.name: Breen's Spring
Breen's Spring.overview:
Breen's Spring is a village on the Caemlyn Road in Andor. It is located between Four Kings and Carysford

According to Hyam Kinch, Breen's Spring marks the westernmost point from Caemlyn where the Queen's Guards regularly patrol, although they will go further if needed.

Bridal wreath.name: Bridal wreath
Bridal wreath.overview:
A bridal wreath is used among the Aiel by a woman to indicate that she wishes to marry a man. If he refuses, it can cause violence or even a blood feud. If he is already married, she usually approaches the first-wife first to avoid any unpleasantness.

A bridal wreath is a wreath of flowers, chosen by Aiel women and given to a man they wish to marry as a proposal. The flowers used signify her personality and how she intends to approach the marriage. Segade blossoms signify a woman with a prickly nature who does not intend to change, sweetroot a sweet nature and morning drop that she would be submissive (TFoH, Ch. 21). The custom is ancient, dating back to at least the treaty of Rhuidean (TSR, Ch. 25). If the man accepts, he picks it up, if not, he may step on it (TFoH, Ch. 5). There are also circumstances when the woman does not have to make one (LoC, Ch. 19).

Broken Champion.name: Broken Champion
Broken Champion.overview:
The Broken Champion is one of the several names used in the Prophecies of the Shadow that may refer to Rand al'Thor, the Dragon Reborn. Why the prophet may have chosen that particular metaphor to characterize the Dragon can only be guessed at, but here are a few possibilities:

- The numerous wounds that Rand has incurred yet have not properly healed.
- The loss of his (left) hand.
- His mental state prior to his epiphany on Dragonmount .
- The presence of Lews Therin Telamon in his mind, usually a sign of great madness according to Semirhage .
- Some misfortune may yet happen that will send him into deep mourning; a kind of brokenness that only time can heal.
- Any combination of the above possibilities.

Broken Cliff.name: Broken Cliff
Broken Cliff.overview: The Broken Cliff sept is a sept of the Daryne Aiel and the sept of it's Clan chief, Mandelain. It is only mention in The Wheel of Time Companion. We know neither its location not the location of the lands of the Daryne Aiel generally.

Broken Crown.name: Broken Crown
Broken Crown.overview: The Broken Crown is the symbol of the Saldaean sovereign. It belongs to the House Kazadi, Bashere family branch.

Brown Ajah.name: Brown Ajah
Brown Ajah.overview:
The Brown Ajah of the Aes Sedai is devoted to knowledge and the collection of ancient wisdom. They generally forsake the mundane world, instead dedicating themselves to history and study, and are responsible for the administration of the White Tower Library. The Brown Ajah is run by a ruling council, the head of which is called First Chair.

Also see List of Brown Ajah sisters.

Brown Ajah Council.name: Brown Ajah Council
Brown Ajah Council.overview:
The Brown Ajah Council is the council which runs the Brown Ajah within the White Tower. The council does have a leader, like the other Ajahs, known as the First Chair. The First Chair however, is considered merely the first among equals.

The number of council members ranges betwen five to thirteen, but it is always an odd number. Among the council, the First Chair is merely called "the head of the council," but does have a lot more authority, especially when she has to meet with the other Ajah Heads.

Brytan.name: Brytan
Brytan.overview:
Brytan is a small village in the northwest of Altara.

Brytan was a small village that only contained a dozen families. During his travels across the nation, Perrin Aybara went through the village two days after the Shaido Aiel. Despite the cold of winter, many of his people refused to stay in the buildings due to an infestation of vermin. After his attack on Malden, Perrin camps near Brytan to let Jur Grady and Fager Neald rest.

Bubble of evil.name: Bubble of evil
Bubble of evil.overview:
Bubbles of evil were first mentioned by Moiraine Damodred, who speaks of the Dark One 's evil in the form of "bubbles rising from the things rotting on the bottom of a pond." The bubbles attach themselves to threads in the pattern and burst causing supernatural and typically deadly events to occur. Moiraine thinks perhaps ta'veren will tend to attract these bubbles more powerfully than others do.

Most bubbles of evil cause some form of bizarre, unnatural destruction that takes place in a short amount of time, a matter of minutes or perhaps hours. A strange exception to this happens in Hinderstap, where the bubble of evil acts like a lasting curse.

It is indicated in A Memory of Light that bubbles of evil are actually the effects, propagated backwards in time, of the Dark One's final onslaught against Rand al'Thor at the end of Tarmon Gai'don.

Bundling Straw.name: Bundling Straw
Bundling Straw.overview: Bundling Straw is a sword form. It was used by Rand al'Thor during his fight with Ba'alzamon in the skies over Falme. Other than the fact that it was used, nothing is known about it.

Burn.name: Burn
Burn.overview: Burn is a wolf that is a part of Dapple 's pack.

Buryhill.name: Buryhill
Buryhill.overview:
Buryhill is a village in Andor.

As Elayne Trakand and her group made their way to Caemlyn after Traveling from Altara, they passed through Buryhill. A woman there told Elyane that she supported Dyelin Taravin for the Lion Throne, believing that Morgase and Elayne were dead.

Cadin'sor.name: Cadin'sor
Cadin'sor.overview:
Cadin'sor is the "uniform" of Aiel warrior societies. The cadin'sor, worn by all Aiel men and by all Maidens of the Spear, is an adaptation of the ancient Da'shain working clothes. The word cadin'sor roughly translates to "working clothes" in the Old Tongue.

The cadin'sor includes a coat and loose breeches made in cloth of gray and brown tones to blend in with the environment of the Waste. Since the arrival of the Aiel in the wetlands, green tones have been added to fit the much greener environment. The Aiel have added soft, laced knee-high boots practical for desert wear, as well as a shoufa, a scarf-like garment that is wrapped around the head and neck, leaving only the face bare. When preparing to kill, they pull the attached black veils on the shoufa over the nose and mouth as well, veiling the face according to tradition.

The differences between the garb of a warrior and a craftsman is very subtle. Often a smaller belt knife, or even none at all, would mark a craftsman. The cut of the cadin'sor is also distinctive. Differences in the design denote clan, sept, and society. This, however, is difficult for non-Aiel to see.

Caembarin.name: Caembarin
Caembarin.overview: Caembarin was a kingdom of the Free Years. It was founded after the end of the Trolloc Wars, and was established on the former territory of Coremanda. It was later absorbed by the growing might of Artur Hawkwing's Empire. Caembarin was one of the strongest nations of its day and fielded a large army. The lands it once held are now controlled by eastern Andor and the easternmost part of Murandy.

Caemlyn Road.name: Caemlyn Road
Caemlyn Road.overview: The Caemlyn Road is one of the major highways of the Westlands. It runs for well over a thousand miles from Baerlon to Aringill, with the city of Caemlyn being the largest settlement along its route. The road crosses the River Manetherendrelle at the White Bridge, an enormous Power -wrought structure. Settlements along the road include Whitebridge, Arien, Breen's Spring, Four Kings, Market Sheran and Carysford.

Cairhien.name: Cairhien
Cairhien.overview:
For the chapter of the same name, see The Great Hunt/Chapter 25 .

Cairhien (/ˈkaɪ.ɹiˌɛn/) is a large country at the end of the Third Age in the east-central part of the Westlands. Cairhien's flag is a golden rising sun on a field of blue and the nation is renowned for exporting Daes Dae'mar, the politically intrigued Game of Houses. Cairhienin speak in a precise, clipped accent, enunciating every word.

Cairhien (city).name: Cairhien (city)
Cairhien (city).overview: Cairhien is the capital of the kingdom of the same name. A large, square-shaped city, it is located on the banks of the River Alguenya just south of its junction with the Gaelin. The city is known primarily as the seat of the king Galldrian, for the institution of the political game Daes Dae'mar, and for a hatred above all else of the Aiel since the Aiel War. It was once known as Al’cair’rahienallen and was originally built by Ogier.

Calendar.name: Calendar
Calendar.overview: This page gives details on what is known about the calendars, past and present, in the Westlands.

Camron Caan.name: Camron Caan
Camron Caan.overview:
Camron Caan is a city-fortress in Shienar.

Camron Caan sends forces with other Shienarans to fight the Trolloc army at Tarwin's Gap.

Canaire'somelle.name: Canaire'somelle
Canaire'somelle.overview: Canaire'somelle was a city in Jaramide, which was part of the Ten Nations. Other than the name, nothing is known about it.

Canluum.name: Canluum
Canluum.overview:
Canluum (pronounced: cahn-LOOM) is a small city located in the kingdom of Kandor, less than fifty miles west of the border with Arafel on the main road to Chachin, capital of Kandor. The Blight is virtually on the city's doorstep with raids by Trollocs being known to occur much deeper into Kandor than Canluum.

Sprawling across several hills, it is defended by a thick wall and a dry moat fifty paces wide and ten deep, spanned by five stone bridges. The city itself mostly consists of stone or brick buildings. The city is wealthy, both for its location on one of the main trade routes to the capital and also for the gemstones mined from the surrounding hills. The city has a less savory area along the northern wall, a warren of narrow streets, small inns and shops called the Deeps, where cutpurses work.

In 979 NE the city was administered by Lord Varan Marcasiev, whose Red Stag banner was proudly displayed on pennants fluttering from every tower. His fortress-like palace was located on top of the largest hill, Stag's Stand. While Trolloc attacks are common in the area, the city itself had never been penetrated.

Inns in the city include the Blue Rose, in the Deeps, and the Gates of Heaven, at the foot of the Stand in a more upmarket area with shops and eateries catering to the nobility and richer merchant classes.

In 979 NE Moiraine Damodred visited the city during the early part of her search for the Dragon Reborn, and had an unpleasant encounter with Cadsuane Melaidhrin there. She met al'Lan Mandragoran for the first time not far from the city on the main road to Chachin.

Cantorin.name: Cantorin
Cantorin.overview:
Cantorin is one of the Atha'an Miere islands belonging to the Aile Somera group.

The harbor on Cantorin forms a wide, lopsided bowl. During the Hailene, Suroth Sabelle Meldarath used Cantorin as a place to consolidate the Seanchan forces before continuing to the Westlands. The Sea Folk vessel of Wavedancer trades between the islands of Cantorin, Dantora and the Aile Jafar group. Egeanin Tamarath and Bayle Domon sail to Cantorin on the Spray, where they are boarded by Seanchan forces. While there, Egeanin purchases a damane named Serrisa.

Capar.name: Capar
Capar.overview:
A capar is an animal found in the Aiel Waste. It resembles a large hairy boar but its snout is pointed and its toes have claws.

Valan Luca has a capar on display as a part of the menagerie in his traveling show.

Captain-General.name: Captain-General
Captain-General.overview:
Captain-General may refer to:

- The military rank of the head of the Queen's Guard in Andor . It is unclear if the rank is exclusive, since both Gareth Bryne and Aranvor Naldwinn held the title simultaneously during the Aiel War .
- The title given to the head of the Green Ajah , though known only to members of the Green.
- A Seanchan rank , the highest in the Ever Victorious Army except for Marshal-General , which is a temporary rank sometimes given to a Captain-General put in charge of war.
- The highest rank in the Illianer Companions .

Captain-General (Andor).name: Captain-General (Andor)
Captain-General (Andor).overview: Captain-General is the military rank of the leader of the Queen's Guard in Andor.

Captain-General (Green Ajah).name: Captain-General (Green Ajah)
Captain-General (Green Ajah).overview:
Captain-General is the title given to the Head of the Green Ajah. In the Green Ajah quarters, her rooms are marked by an upward-pointed sword lacquered in red, gold and black carved into the doorway.

The Green Ajah has a somewhat military hierarchy, as the title suggests, and the Captain-General has a thorough and far-reaching authority over her subordinates. She is assisted by two women who are second in command known as the First Strategist and First Tactician. The identity of either of these roles in association with any named character is not given in the series.

Captain-General (Seanchan).name: Captain-General (Seanchan)
Captain-General (Seanchan).overview:
Captain-General is the rank given to the military commander of Seanchan forces. There are only two men who we know of having held this rank among the Seanchan.

- Kennar Miraj - He was the military commander in charge of the soldiers in the Corenne before his death on the battlefield in Illian . He was killed by Rand al'Thor 's reckless use of Callandor .
- Lunal Galgan - Is the current commander of the forces of the Seanchan , having arrived with the Hailene .

Captain of the Air.name: Captain of the Air
Captain of the Air.overview: A Captain of the Air is an officer in the Seanchan army, and is in command of those who ride raken and to'raken. The rank's sole use far indicates someone in command of all raken and to'raken in the return, it is unknown if there are any higher ranks pertaining to aerial units. Little else is known about them besides the rank except that certain rules forbid them flying very often.

Captain of the Gold.name: Captain of the Gold
Captain of the Gold.overview:
Captain of the Gold is a naval rank in the Ever Victorious Army of the Seanchan.

Egeanin Tamarath 's mother was a Captain of the Gold, and was later raised to Hand of the Empress at Sea as a so'jhin to the Empress herself.

Captain of the Green.name: Captain of the Green
Captain of the Green.overview: Captain of the Green, a naval rank in the Ever Victorious Army of the Seanchan.

Captain of the Stone.name: Captain of the Stone
Captain of the Stone.overview: The Captain of the Stone is the leader of the Defenders of the Stone. The current Captain of the Stone is Rodrivar Tihera.

Car'a'carn.name: Car'a'carn
Car'a'carn.overview:
The Car'a'carn ("Chief of chiefs" in the Old Tongue ) is the Aiel term for the one who will lead all Aiel, in accordance with the Prophecy of Rhuidean.

When a man wishes to become a chief of one of the Aiel clans, he must go to Rhuidean and walk through the glass-column ter'angreal to relive the history of the Aiel. Should he survive the experience, he is marked with a Dragon entwined about his left arm. It is this marking which designates him a chief.

The Car'a'carn is in turn marked by having a Dragon on each arm. Prior to Rand al'Thor, the Aiel have never had a Car'a'carn. It is unknown whether the Car'a'carn necessarily needs to also be He Who Comes With the Dawn.

The Car'a'carn is not the same as a king in one of the nations west of the Dragonwall. He is, at best, first among equals.
aliases: He Who Comes With the Dawn

Caralain.name: Caralain
Caralain.overview: Caralain was one of the 24 nations that came into existence after the Hundred Years War. It weakened thereafter and its last traces vanished around the year 500 NE. It was located in the Caralain Grass. The country lay to the north of Andor.

Caralain Grass.name: Caralain Grass
Caralain Grass.overview:
The Caralain Grass is an extensive area of plains lying almost in the exact center of the Westlands, roughly equidistant from the Great Blight, the Aryth Ocean, the Spine of the World and the Sea of Storms. At its widest extent, the Caralain Grass extends for almost a thousand miles.

The plain is bordered by the River Haevin to the west, the Black Hills to the north and Braem Wood, the River Erinin and the River Luan to the east, and the kingdom of Andor to the south.

The Caralain Grass was once more densely populated, with the kingdom of Coremanda (one of the Ten Nations destroyed in the Trolloc Wars ) claiming its full extent. It was later divided between the kingdoms of Dal Calain, Aldeshar and Caembarin during the Free Years.

After the War of the Hundred Years, the plains were claimed by the kingdom of Caralain, but Caralain grew desolate and depopulated, fading away after several centuries. There are some villages remaining in the area, but they owe no allegiance to anyone and are distrustful, where not openly hostile, to strangers.

Nonetheless, Caralain Grass is largely unpopulated at present, and few venture across it save occasional caravans of the Tuatha'an.

Cargomaster.name: Cargomaster
Cargomaster.overview:
The Cargomaster is a high Atha'an Miere position in the chain of command. The position is always held by a man who is often married to the Sailmistress.

The Cargomaster is in charge of the defense of the ship, as well as all trade. His word in matters of negotiations and combat are first and foremost.

While the Cargomaster technically stands below the Sailmistress, she cannot command him when it comes to these matters of his position any more than he can command her where to sail.

Carneira.name: Carneira
Carneira.overview: Carneira is the term used for the first lover of a Malkieri. In the Old Tongue it means "first".

Cary.name: Cary
Cary.overview:
The River Cary is an important waterway in eastern Andor. The river rises in Braem Wood and flows south, a short distance west of Caemlyn. After crossing out of Andor it forms the eastern border of Murandy before joining the Manetherendrelle in northern Illian.

The town of Carysford is located where the Caemlyn Road crosses the river.

Carysford.name: Carysford
Carysford.overview:
Carysford is a large village or small town located on the banks of the River Cary, a day or two's ride west of Caemlyn in Andor and not far downriver from its source. It is where the Caemlyn Road crosses the river on its way to the capital.

The village consists of neat, vine-covered brick houses and is fairly peaceful. The ford itself has long been bridged over, although the bridge is not kept in the best of conditions.

Cat's Paw dice game.name: Cat's Paw dice game
Cat's Paw dice game.overview: Cat's Paw is a dice game when a crowd of onlookers betting against a lonely dice gamer's tosses. In some lands it is called Third Gem or Feathers Aloft.

Cat Crosses the Courtyard.name: Cat Crosses the Courtyard
Cat Crosses the Courtyard.overview:
For other similarly named sword forms, see Cat Dances on the Wall and Cat on Hot Sand .

Cat Crosses the Courtyard is not so much a sword form but a method of movement.

Cat Dancer.name: Cat Dancer
Cat Dancer.overview: Cat Dancer is the war horse ridden by al'Lan Mandragoran during the Aiel War.

Cat Dances on the Wall.name: Cat Dances on the Wall
Cat Dances on the Wall.overview:
For other similarly named sword forms, see Cat Crosses the Courtyard and Cat on Hot Sand .

For other uses of the word "dance," see Dance .

Cat Dances on the Wall is a sword form used to knock aside a strike and go for the legs in one sweep. The movement of the form looks like a surprised cat scrambling up a wall.

Cat on Hot Sand.name: Cat on Hot Sand
Cat on Hot Sand.overview:
For other similarly named sword forms, see Cat Crosses the Courtyard and Cat Dances on the Wall .

Cat on Hot Sand is a sword form. Aside from the name, nothing is known about the actual movement.

Catfern.name: Catfern
Catfern.overview: Catfern is an herb that can be found in the Two Rivers region. A village Wisdom such as Nynaeve can boil the catfern and mix with powdered mavinsleaf to form a viscous sickly green liquid with an atrociously acrid tang. The concoction is harmless, but the highly unpleasant taste makes drinking it a punishment administered for someone who lies.

Cavalry.name: Cavalry
Cavalry.overview:
Cavalry is a type of military unit consisting of mounted soldiers organized for scouting, flanking and/or shock assaults.

Cavalry is most commonly equipped with horses and are organized into troops of fifty cavalrymen led by a lieutenant. Ten troops are organized as a squadron under the command of a captain. Three squadrons under the command of a Banner-General form a Banner of Horse. Generally, Legions combine cavalry (horse) and infantry (foot) Banners; "pure" cavalry legions (and higher formations) are almost unheard of.

Cavalrymen are often contemptuous of infantry or foot soldiers.

Cemaros.name: Cemaros
Cemaros.overview: The cemaros are "great winter tempests'" which "roll out of the Sea of Storms."

Cera Doinal.name: Cera Doinal
Cera Doinal.overview: Cera Doinal is a servant in the Sun Palace in Cairhien.

Cha Faile.name: Cha Faile
Cha Faile.overview:
Cha Faile is a phrase from the Old Tongue meaning "Falcon's Talon" or "Falcon's Claw."

This name has been adopted by the cadre of men and women, previously nobles, who follow Faile and function unofficially as her spies. The members of Cha Faile are fanatically loyal to her, and also seek to emulate the Aiel way of life. Many of them were used by Faile and later by Sebban Balwer as spies and agents.

Chachin.name: Chachin
Chachin.overview:
Chachin is the capital city of Kandor, in the Borderlands. It is located on the junction of several trade routes, including the cross-Borderland route running from Bandar Eban to Fal Moran and another running south to Tar Valon. It is located just south of the Blight and as a result is extremely heavily defended, although it is large enough and far enough south that vigilance is not quite as severe as in smaller settlements such as Canluum. Chachin is not usually counted as one of the great cities of the Westlands, but it rivals Tear in size. Despite being neither built by Ogier nor founded on the site of a city built by Ogier, Chachin holds its fair share of ancient relics; foremostly the documents named the Strike at Shayol Ghul were found inside the mountain city. It is unknown exactly how old the city is; it is known that it, and its neighbor capital Shol Arbela, lay within the borders of Elsalam, but it is neither said of what importance they were nor if either of them was capital.

The city is built around several hills with three tall mountains rising out of the center. The Aesdaishar Palace, the seat of the ruler of Kandor, currently Queen Ethenielle Kirukon Materasu, is located atop the highest mountain, which rises over 5,000 feet over the city below. Three tall ringwalls encircle the city with a 100-foot-wide drymoat located beyond that. Twenty-four bridges cross the moat, each overlooked by a small fortress where the bridge meets the city. The Bridge of Sunrise is located on the eastern side of the city, where the road from Canluum enters the city.

Its location is at a high enough altitude to cause some difficulty in breathing and dizziness. This is a sign of altitude sickness which generally occurs only at altitudes above 2500 m or 8000 ft. Examples of capital cities in the real world at this kind of altitude are Bogotá (2,640 m or 8,660 ft), Quito (2,850 m or 9,350 ft)) and La Paz (3,640 m or 11,942 ft).

As with many Borderland cities, Chachin is mostly made of stone buildings with glazed tile roofs that are more difficult to burn in a sneak attack. The poorest districts are nearest the edge of the city, within the first ringwall, with the districts becoming richer and more prosperous the closer a traveler comes to the central mountains.

The city is also the home of the Merchants' Guild of Kandor. These merchants can easily be recognized by the chains going across the front of their coats.

Inns within Chachin include the Silver Penny, Ruffled Goose, Evening Star and Blind Pig.

Chaendaer.name: Chaendaer
Chaendaer.overview: Chaendaer is a large mountain in the Aiel Waste, which sits above the valley of Rhuidean. There is a portal stone near Chaendaer.

Chain Ridge Stand.name: Chain Ridge Stand
Chain Ridge Stand.overview: Chain Ridge Stand is a watering hole in the Aiel Waste. The Shaarad and the Goshien clans both dispute the ownership of the stand.

Chainleaf.name: Chainleaf
Chainleaf.overview: Chainleaf is an herb that can be found in the Two Rivers region and in Tear. It can be brewed as a tea and administered to ease a queasy stomach.

Challenge.name: Challenge
Challenge.overview: Challenge is the name of Gawyn Trakand 's horse.

Chalm.name: Chalm
Chalm.overview:
The Chalm is the port district of Tear.

The area contains many warehouses for goods shipped to Tear. There are also many inns and taverns catering to the sailors and workmen that frequent the area. The taverns are noted for cheap wine, bad ale, occasional fights and unending dice games.

Mat visits the area to get away from the Stone and Moiraine as well as to gamble a bit after the Lordlings stop playing cards with him.

Chamber of Bonds.name: Chamber of Bonds
Chamber of Bonds.overview: The Chamber of Bonds is the main central chamber of the fortress of the Eelfinn.

Chane Rocks.name: Chane Rocks
Chane Rocks.overview: The Chane Rocks is a sept of the Codarra Aiel. Indirian, the clan chief of the Codarra, was born in the Chane Rocks sept.

Chansein.name: Chansein
Chansein.overview:
Chansein occurs on the third day of Jumara. It is a day of gluttony and wild indulgence in food. The celebration centers around stuffing people full of food and then some. Not just stuffing bellies, people are sometimes seen stuffing their pockets, or carrying bagfuls of food, and handing them out to everyone they see. The recipient would be ill-mannered to leave even a crumb uneaten. Hot pastries stuffed with meat or dried fruit are a traditional food for this holiday.

Chansein is celebrated throughout the Borderlands and in Arad Doman.

Chareen.name: Chareen
Chareen.overview: The Chareen are one of the twelve Aiel clans. Their clan hold is unknown.

Chelsaine Palace.name: Chelsaine Palace
Chelsaine Palace.overview:
The Chelsaine Palace is located in Ebou Dar.

Matrim Cauthon once followed Lady Shiaine to the palace. Mat later learns from Noal Charin that the palace is being rented by Jaichim Carridin, the Whitecloak Ambassador.

Sammael visits the palace and Carridin to discover that Mat is in Ebou Dar. Sammael then leaves Carridin instructions regarding Mat.

The palace is staked out by various members of Mat's party during their stay in Ebou Dar, including Mat himself, Vanin, and Birgitte.

Cherry Petal Kisses the Pond.name: Cherry Petal Kisses the Pond
Cherry Petal Kisses the Pond.overview: Cherry Petal Kisses the Pond is a sword form. Other than the name, nothing is known about it.

Chiendelna.name: Chiendelna
Chiendelna.overview: House Chiendelna was a minor Murandian noble house. "Lord Luc" claimed membership in this relatively old but minor house during his time in the Two Rivers. Verin Sedai thought the word had a Borderlander sound, so it is unclear if the house even really still exists at all.

Child of the Dragon.name: Child of the Dragon
Child of the Dragon.overview: Child of the Dragon is a name given to Da'shain Aiel by the people of the time of the War of the Shadow.

Children of the Light.name: Children of the Light
Children of the Light.overview:
The Children of the Light are an independent military organization dedicated to finding Darkfriends and rooting out evil and corruption wherever it may be found. Their zeal in this endeavor often borders on the insane and makes them dangerous opponents. Their headquarters is the Fortress of the Light in the city of Amador in Amadicia. Although Amadicia has a king, the Children hold so much political and military power there that they are undoubtedly its true rulers.

They typically refer to themselves as 'the Children'. They are commonly referred to by others as ' Whitecloaks' due to their snowy white cloaks worn over their armor which is the most distinguishable feature of their uniform and the aspect that makes them easy to identify and instantly recognizable. This is not a name favored by the Children themselves and is likely to offend them if used in their presence.

The current Lord Captain Commander of the Children of the Light is Galadedrid Damodred.

The Children's banner consists of a golden sunburst on a white field edged with gold.

Chinje wheel.name: Chinje wheel
Chinje wheel.overview: A chinje wheel is a gambling device from the Age of Legends.

Chishen Mountains.name: Chishen Mountains
Chishen Mountains.overview:
The Chishen Mountains are a range of mountains in southeastern Andor, located close to the River Erinin, approximately 300 miles from Caemlyn. They may be linked to the Hills of Kintara to the southwest. The Chishen Mountains are home to several estates, most notably that of House Matherin, who are loyal supporters of House Trakand.

Curiously, despite their distance from the border with Murandy, border raids are apparently not uncommon in this region.

Choren.name: Choren
Choren.overview: Choren is the tenth month in the Farede calendar. In most years, it is equivalent to the real world period from September 1 to September 28. Festival of Lanterns occurs on the 1st.

Chumai.name: Chumai
Chumai.overview: The Chumai is a sept of the Taardad Aiel. The sept hold is unknown. When Shaiel was accepted as Far Dareis Mai, she joined the Chumai sept. On their way to Alcair Dal, Rand al'Thor and the Jindo are joined by other Taardad septs including the Nine Valleys, Chumai, Four Stones, Bloody Water and Miadi septs.

Cindaking.name: Cindaking
Cindaking.overview: Cindaking is a Sea Folk island in the Sea of Storms south of Godan and southwest of Mayene, near the mouth of the Bay of Remara.

Circuit of Heaven.name: Circuit of Heaven
Circuit of Heaven.overview:
The Circuit of Heaven is a horse racetrack just north of Ebou Dar, past the Dal Eira Gate.

During his time in Ebou Dar, Matrim Cauthon, Olver and several of his party frequent the Circuit.

Cirri.name: Cirri
Cirri.overview:
Cirri is a cat owned by Sara, who cooks at the Stag and Lion Inn in Baerlon.

The night Moiraine 's party stayed at this inn, guests complained that several dead rats, apparently killed by Cirri, were found in the inn, all with their backs broken.

From Sara 's comments about the unusual behavior, it seems likely that they were not killed by him as was assumed, but were instead killed by Ba'alzamon as a warning to Rand Al'thor.

Clan.name: Clan
Clan.overview: Clans are groupings of people used by the Aiel and the Atha'an Miere, much like the noble houses of the Westlands.

Clan chief.name: Clan chief
Clan chief.overview:
Aiel clan chief s have authority over the several septs of their clan. Unlike nobles of the Westlands, any Aiel may speak with the clan chief and while there are some formalities, they are not afforded the same sort of servile adulation as "wetlander kings."

They are chosen from among the clan's male members by the Wise Ones, who must agree to allow the candidate to travel to Rhuidean. There he learns the true history of the Aiel through the memories of his ancestors. If he returns, he is marked by a single dragon tattoo on his forearm and becomes the new clan chief. Only one in three men survive this trip to Rhuidean.

Cleansing of saidin.name: Cleansing of saidin
Cleansing of saidin.overview:
The cleansing of saidin was a world-altering event that occurred at the climax of Winter's Heart and was felt throughout the entire world by channelers.

In 1000 NE, Rand al'Thor made an extraordinary claim: he believed he had discovered how to cleanse the Dark One 's 3,000-year-old taint on saidin. While Rand was inside the redstone doorway ter'angreal, one of the questions he asked the Aelfinn was how to cleanse saidin. The answer to the question is never revealed to the reader, but it is known to be a riddle that Herid Fel said stated "sound principles, in both high philosophy and natural philosophy."

On Saban 22, Rand al'Thor and Nynaeve al'Meara used the two most powerful sa'angreal ever made, the Choedan Kal, one buried in Cairhien and the other on Tremalking, to funnel the taint into Shadar Logoth.

Nynaeve and Rand were linked together for the cleansing. When Nynaeve touched saidin, because she held control of the circle, she openly expressed her shock and fear of the "chaos and rage" of saidin and wondered how Rand was ever able to control it. When Rand "ripped" control of the circle away from her, he was able to touch saidar and, unbelieving of Nynaeve's warning that saidar could not be controlled, only guided, he immediately tried to control saidar like he did saidin, and felt like he was being pulled into a thick, slow-moving stream with eddies and cross-currents pulling every which way. It was not until he could both surrender to saidar and dominate saidin that he was able to weave either half of the Source at all.

Rand's strategy was to create a funnel of saidar from the Source of saidin to Shadar Logoth, and when he guided saidar to that goal, it created something he had not directly intended. Rather than a tunnel as he thought would appear, saidar was actually an intricate, flowery-looking shape which was a tunnel of infinite and zero distance only relative to the Source and Shadar Logoth; from any other vantage point, it looked nothing like a conduit. Saidin flowed very easily into the conduit, and the taint began to slide off of saidin into Shadar Logoth. Rand's theory was, that after channeling enough of saidin into the conduit, the taint would be drawn in its entirety towards a similar, yet polar opposite sort of taint; the evil residue of Shadar Logoth. After that, he would merely need to keep a steady flow of saidin going through the conduit, and the taint would automatically be pulled into Shadar Logoth so long as he kept saidin touched directly to the evil of the city. Fortunately, the plan worked exactly as predicted.

In Shadar Logoth, a dome-like structure of black darker than black appeared, slowly rising out of the ground as if thick, viscous mud were being piled on the city. Towards the end of the battle, flames even darker than the mass of taint flashed throughout the bubble—Mashadar and the taint destroying each other. This created an immensely powerful whirlwind, sucking Moghedien towards the ruins, and left a gigantic crater sweeping the city.

Six Rebel Aes Sedai who went to investigate the area afterward report that the crater left was "roughly circular hole in the ground... three and a half miles across and one and a half miles deep." The strength of the residues discovered are the impetus for their alliance with the Black Tower.

Near the end of 1000 NE, it is believed that this process was entirely successful, although what it means for the Asha'man and other male channelers, not to mention the Red Ajah, remains to be seen. By the end of the Last Battle, it seems as though the source being cleansed has been accepted by most, and the fear of male channelers by the general populace is beginning to fade.

However, the cleansing of saidin was not without consequences. The female Choedan Kal access key was destroyed along with the statue on Tremalking, home of the peacful Amayar who worshipped the statue. After the sa'angreal's destruction, all of the Amayar people on the island collectively committed mass suicide by poison. Since there was not enough poison, many had to take weaker poisons, resulting in many still being alive and able to tell to the Sea Folk traders who arrived, though none of them would accept healing, saying that "the ending of all days" was upon them.

See also the Battle near Shadar Logoth

Cliffs of Dawn.name: Cliffs of Dawn
Cliffs of Dawn.overview:
The Cliffs of Dawn are an extensive range of cliffs marking the northeastern edge of the Aiel Waste. They extend for 250 leagues (1,000 miles) southwest from the Mountains of Dhoom into the Aiel Waste and range in height from 100 to 500 feet. Large mountains are located beyond the cliffs.

There are only six spots along the cliff where it is possible to scale the heights. At each one of these spots is a trade town built by the secretive nation of Shara that lies to the east. At their southern end, the Cliffs suddenly drop into the massive canyon known as the Great Rift.

Cloud.name: Cloud
Cloud.overview:
Cloud is a tall and gray horse, with black mane and tail. Rand al'Thor rode him when he fled the Two Rivers.

Cloud is very spirited as well as very fast. He was purchased from Jon Thane, the miller, who would often race the horse against those belonging to merchants' guards. Rand had never known the horse to lose.

Cloud was ridden out of Two Rivers, into Baerlon, out of Baerlon, into Shadar Logoth, and out of Shadar Logoth by Rand. After Rand rode Cloud out of Shadar Logoth, he, Thomdril Merrilin, and Matrim Cauthon escaped incoming Trollocs by boat, abandoning their horses, including Cloud.

Codarra.name: Codarra
Codarra.overview: The Codarra are one of the twelve Aiel clans. Their clan hold is Red Springs Hold.

Coin peppers.name: Coin peppers
Coin peppers.overview:
An edible pepper found in the borderlands.

One of Siuan ‘s little sayings is, “if you want to keep something hidden...don’t try to buy coin peppers this far south.” Alluding to the fact that since they are popular (and likely produced) in the Shienar and Malkier, then finding some in Ebou Dar may point towards a less than reputable merchant.

Cold Peak.name: Cold Peak
Cold Peak.overview: The Cold Peak is a sept of the Miagoma Aiel. The location of the sept hold is unknown.

Cold Rocks Hold.name: Cold Rocks Hold
Cold Rocks Hold.overview:
For the chapter in The Shadow Rising called "Cold Rocks Hold", see The Shadow Rising/Chapter 49 .

Cold Rocks Hold is a settlement belonging to the Taardad Aiel of the Nine Valleys sept. The Taardad Aiel continued to protect the Jenn Aiel until they founded Rhuidean. They are descended from Lewin who was the first of the Jenn Aiel to be cast out for killing. Lian is its Roofmistress.

Cold Water.name: Cold Water
Cold Water.overview: Cold Water is a leader of a pack of wolves.

Collam Daan.name: Collam Daan
Collam Daan.overview:
The Collam Daan was a university located in the city of V'saine, in the Age of Legends.

The university was constructed of silver and blue domes. Along with the Sharom, a massive white sphere that floated above it, it was the leading institution for development and research in the Age of Legends.

Several characters of importance were involved with Collam Daan. Lanfear, then known as Mierin Eronaile, was a researcher at the university. Mesaana, then known as Saine Tarasind, instructed students at the university after being deemed "unsuited for research" by the board of Collam Daan.

When the Bore was created, the resulting backlash was so strong that it shattered the Sharom. This leveled the university to the ground.

Collapse.name: Collapse
Collapse.overview:
The Collapse is the name given to a span of time in the Age of Legends between the creation of the Bore and the War of Power. The drilling of the Bore was a scientific experiment headed by Mierin and Beidomon in an attempt to access a power that both men and women could use. The power turned out to be the True Power, the essence of the Dark One seeping through a thinness in the Pattern.

During this period there was a slow degeneration of society, attributed to the Dark One 's ability to influence hearts and emotions. Brutal sports and treacherous politics became more and more common as the Collapse wore on, and the art of war was rediscovered through these often fatal confrontations. This slow corrupting influence lasted a little more than a hundred years; slowly persons of power and prestige converted to the Shadow, either publicly or in secret.

Once a sufficient segment of society had fallen under the Dark One's sway, the War of Power began in earnest with a concerted attempt to unleash him fully upon the world.

However, Lews Therin Telamon / Rand al'Thor speculates that all these problems were simmering under the surface of society, which the government refused to acknowledge. He therefore speculates that even if the Dark One had not been released, the Collapse still would have occurred. Considering powerful channelers like Aginor and Semirhage desired to push the limits of morality in their fields before the Bore was opened and turned to the Shadow partly to be free of moral constraints proves that while the Dark One may have hastened and precipitated the Collapse, he did not create all of the necessary preconditions.

Color-shifting cloak.name: Color-shifting cloak
Color-shifting cloak.overview:
Color-shifting cloaks are special garments that are unique to Warders. Made out of a special material called fancloth, they seem to mimic the surrounding landscape and serve as camouflage.

Warder's cloaks tend to invoke a disturbing feeling on people who see them while they are moving, and while stationary the wearer blends in nearly perfectly with the background. The cloaks are somewhat of a trademark for Warders, and as such, can be used to recognize a Warder and his Aes Sedai on sight.

The fabric for the color shifting cloaks is made by a certain ter'angreal in the White Tower which has no other known use.

Colrada Hold.name: Colrada Hold
Colrada Hold.overview: Colrada Hold is a settlement in the Aiel Waste. Mora of the Shaarad was the Wise One of the hold. It is unknown what sept or clan owns this hold.

Comaidin Riots.name: Comaidin Riots
Comaidin Riots.overview: Comaidin was a place during the time of the Compact of the Ten Nations, where Caraighan Maconar is credited with putting down riots at a time when she had no Warders.

Comarda Hold.name: Comarda Hold
Comarda Hold.overview: Comarda Hold is an Aiel settlement in the Three-fold Land. It is held by the Shaido. Couladin, Muradin, Suladric, and Sevanna are from this hold.

Comelle.name: Comelle
Comelle.overview: Comelle was a great city during the Age of Legends, the third largest in the world at the time. Comelle was a coastal city built along the mountains. The city's buildings, made of beautiful crystal, glass, and metal clung to the mountainside.

Comfrey.name: Comfrey
Comfrey.overview:
Comfrey is a small village north of Baerlon, in Andor.

When Matrim Cauthon delivers Elayne Trakand 's letter to Morgase Trakand, he does so under the alias of "Thom Grinwell," claiming to be from Comfrey.

Commander.name: Commander
Commander.overview: Commander is a military rank title in Kandor and Arad Doman. In both countries it means the military control over a fortress or a city.

Commentary on the Dragon.name: Commentary on the Dragon
Commentary on the Dragon.overview:
Commentary on the Dragon, by Sajius, is a commentary on The Karaethon Cycle. Sajius claimed that the phrase " He shall hold a blade of light in his hands, and the three shall be one." referred to the unification of three nations. Min believed that interpretation is incorrect, and that the passage has something to do with the use of Callandor.

During the Last Battle, Rand, Moiraine, and Nynaeve use Callandor to pull Moridin into their circle. Using saidin, saidar, and the True Power, Rand creates a new seal on the Dark One 's Prison, thus achieving victory at Tarmon Gai'don.

Common.name: Common
Common.overview: Common is a way of telling stories. It differs greatly from the High Chant and Plain Chant. It is described as the way you might tell your neighbour about your crop.

Common Chant.name: Common Chant
Common Chant.overview:
Common Chant is undoubtedly the least used form among professional entertainers such as gleemen and bards. Most often, stories in Common Chant are fictional accounts of a supposed character in history told from one commoner to another. Some of these stories are roughly based on true events, but, having been passed down from generation to generation and spread prominently through word of mouth, have changed significantly over time (written Common Chant is very rare).

Common Chant is the lowest tier of speech, under Plain and High Chant, and can be thought of as a day to day type of speaking akin to slang. In Common, stories are told like you would speak to a friend or neighbor, or like modern English. It is an unstylized form of language, and the stories of the land are most often only told this way in small towns or the roughest taverns or inns. Most bards and gleemen show open disgust at being asked to perform with such an unartistic medium.

Due to the prime audience exposed to Common being farmers, commoners and other lower class citizens the topics of such stories infrequently deal with epic legends. They most often focus on topics the listeners are familiar with, such as farming, short distance traveling, simple trading and local festivals, with the epic tales such as the Hunt for the Horn being told in High Chant or at the very least Plain. They are often comical in nature, and almost never mention politics, drama and other serious topics. Some areas and cities are more apt to spread vulgar stories and jokes while others avoid them, telling stories of a more anecdotal and clever nature. Having originated in one form, spread by traders and travelers and further developed to reflect the morals and personalities found in each given location, these differences are often found as variations of the same story.

Comolad.name: Comolad
Comolad.overview: Comolad is an "exquisite" wine from the Age of Legends.

Company.name: Company
Company.overview: A company is a military unit led by a captain consisting of 250 infantry divided into five squads.

Condaris.name: Condaris
Condaris.overview:
Condaris was a city in Aelgar, part of the Ten Nations. It was Ogier-built. It's current loction is unknown.

During the rebuilding after the Breaking of the World, the Ogier built a waygate to Condaris.

In the Old Tongue, it may be an amalgamation of conde (walk) and aris (harmony) to mean something like "the way of harmony". Conden is the verb "to walk" and conde are "walkers", so it may not be a stretch to translate the first half as the noun "walk", "path" or "way".

Consolidation.name: Consolidation
Consolidation.overview: The Consolidation is a name given to two separate, although related events in the history of the Westlands and Seanchan, namely the conquest of the former by the High King, Artur Paendrag Tanreall in FY 943 - 963 and the latter by his son Luthair Paendrag Mondwin starting in FY 992. For the sake of clarity this article will refer to the former, while the latter can be found under the Conquest, the name by which it is known in Seanchan.
aliases: Wars of Consolidation, or the Consolidation

Contagious dreams.name: Contagious dreams
Contagious dreams.overview:
For other pages related to dreams, see Dream .

Contagious dreams are dreams by powerful channelers that incidentally affect the dreams of other people within the same area.

Cor Darei.name: Cor Darei
Cor Darei.overview: The Cor Darei is an Aiel warrior society. The name means "Night Spears" in the Old Tongue.

Coramen.name: Coramen
Coramen.overview:
Coramen is a town in Altara, located on the east bank of the River Eldar on the Great North Road, between Ebou Dar and Lugard.

Coramen has a companion town called Alkindar, which is on the west bank of the Eldar. There is a ferry that connects the two towns. When Valan Luca 's Traveling Show is traveling through Altara, they cross the ferry from Alkindar into Coramen. Despite the heavy presence of Seanchan troops, Tuon Athaem Kore Paendrag keeps her word to Matrim Cauthon not to betray them. While camped near Coramen, Renna Emain stabs Egeanin Tamarath and then steals a horse. She almost makes it back to Coramen when Harnan kills her with a crossbow bolt.

Coramoor.name: Coramoor
Coramoor.overview:
The Coramoor is the Sea Folk 's version of the Dragon Reborn. He is mentioned in The Jendai Prophecies which are the Sea Folk's version of the Prophecies of the Dragon.

The Sea Folk believe that the Coramoor is predicted by the Jendai Prophecy to lead them to greater glory, including domination of all the seas of the land. Rand al'Thor, who is also the Dragon Reborn and the Car'a'carn of the Aiel, is believed to be the fulfillment of that prophecy. The Sea Folk will serve the Coramoor in any way they can, but no-one agrees on exactly how the Bargain should pan out.

As of yet, Rand al'Thor has neglected much attention to either the Sea Folk or the prophecies in which they hold him, mostly due to their lack of mention in the Karaethon Cycle. However, an agreement between the Sea Folk and Rand's allied countries is eventually reached, with particularly onerous terms both ways, something which the new Mistress of Ships is extremely displeased about.

Corartheren.name: Corartheren
Corartheren.overview: Coratheren was a city in Manetheren, which was part of the Ten Nations. Other than the name, nothing is known about it.

Cordamora Palace.name: Cordamora Palace
Cordamora Palace.overview:
The Cordamora Palace is the home of the ruler of Saldaea, located in the northern part of Maradon.

Its name translated into the Common Tongue is possibly "Heart of the People" - from the Old Tongue corda (meaning "the heart") and mora (meaning "the people or a population").

Cordese Hills.name: Cordese Hills
Cordese Hills.overview: The Cordese Hills lie to the north and west of the city of Ebou Dar in Altara. Their extent is uncertain, but is apparently enough to ensure that no major ports can be built on the Sea of Storms west of Ebou Dar.

Coremanda.name: Coremanda
Coremanda.overview: Coremanda was one of the Ten Nations forged after the Breaking of the World. It flourished for over a thousand years before it was destroyed in the Trolloc Wars.

Corenne.name: Corenne
Corenne.overview:
The Corenne (meaning " the Return " in the Old Tongue ) is the name given by the Seanchan both to the fleet of thousands of ships and to hundreds of thousands of soldiers, craftsmen and others carried by those ships, who came behind the Forerunners to reclaim the lands stolen from Artur Hawkwing 's descendants. The Corenne is led by Captain-General Lunal Galgan.

Soon after the Hailene came to the Westlands, the nation of Tarabon was occupied. A new king swore loyalty to the Seanchan Empress in Seandar. After the conquest of Tarabon, Amador and the whole of Amadicia was occupied by the Seanchan invaders. King Ailron was killed in the Battle of Jeramel.

At the same time a Seanchan invasion force landed in Ebou Dar, the capital of Altara. Their march to the north was stopped by the Dragon Reborn and his Asha'man forces.

Corenroot.name: Corenroot
Corenroot.overview: Corenroot is an herb that can be found in the Two Rivers region. It is administered to someone with serious injuries to help the person manufacture blood.

Corlm.name: Corlm
Corlm.overview:
Corlm are animals from the Seanchan continent. They appear as hairy, flightless birds, their fur usually gray, black, or brown in color. Corlm can grow up to eight feet tall, with long necks and a double crest on their heads which function as their ears. At maturity they can weigh as much as three hundred pounds. Their fur comes striped or mottled, resembling the pelts of some house cats. Their beak is long, hooked like a bird of prey, and seems oversized for the oblong head. Unlike the torm, their eyes sit on the side of the head, and there are only two of them. They have powerful, four-toed short-clawed hind feet and short forearms they hold close to the body. The forearms generally are not used for anything other than nest building and feeding.

Corlm are carnivores and make extremely efficient predators, able to track down prey using both smell and hearing. To attack, a corlm will use its long beak, which is similar to that of a bird of prey, and is used for killing. They are fast sprinters, able to outrun a man in a short sprint, and can match a man over long distances.

The birds respond to both words and whistles from their handlers, called morat'corlm and der'morat'corlm, the " der " meaning "master." When in their own environment, the corlm do not tolerate each other very well, and prefer solitude except during mating season. The creatures will lay only one egg at a time, and not all hatch, so breeding them takes time.

Corlm are used by the Seanchan as trackers because of their keen ability to hunt and their speed.

Cormaed.name: Cormaed
Cormaed.overview:
Cormaed is a village in Altara, located on the River Eldar.

When searching for Gareth Bryne, Morgase Trakand, Lini Eltring, Martyn Tallanvor, Basel Gill, Breane Taborwin and Lamgwin Dorn travel from Sehar to Cormaed to find a ferry that will take them across the Eldar into Amadicia.

Cormalinde Masoon.name: Cormalinde Masoon
Cormalinde Masoon.overview:
Cormalinde Masoon was a sculptor during the Age of Legends.

Cormalinde's sculptures were immense and done out of spinglass, shaped like stylized humans and animals. Their work was showcased at the Ansaline Gardens.

Coron Ford.name: Coron Ford
Coron Ford.overview:
Coron Ford is a town in Arad Doman.

Coron Ford is a rendezvous point for Rodel Ituralde and his men.

Cosa.name: Cosa
Cosa.overview: An animal that scampered up trees, referred to by Graendal in describing how Sammael would react if Rand chased him out of Illian.

Cosaida.name: Cosaida
Cosaida.overview: The Cosaida is a sept of the Chareen Aiel. The location of the hold of this sept is unknown.

Cosamelle.name: Cosamelle
Cosamelle.overview: Cosamelle is a town in Ghealdan.

Council of Merchants.name: Council of Merchants
Council of Merchants.overview:
The Council of Merchants is a powerful and influential political body in Arad Doman, formed by the heads of the great Merchant Houses from the Merchants' Guild, almost always women. The focus of the Council is to secure wealth for Arad Doman through trade.

Among the Council's roles is to elect the Domani King from the noble class. There must be at least eight members assembled to order a new vote for king. The Council also has the power to depose the King by a three-quarters majority.

Council of Nine.name: Council of Nine
Council of Nine.overview:
The Council of Nine is one of the governing bodies of Illian. It shares governing power with the King and the Assemblage.

The Council of Nine meets in the Great Hall of the Council. It is situated across from the King's Palace in the Square of Tammaz. The palace is identical to the King's Palace, even down to the lamps, but slightly smaller in every dimension. Each member of the council wears a green sash, even over armor.

Council of the Anointed.name: Council of the Anointed
Council of the Anointed.overview: The Council of the Anointed is the name for the ruling council of the Children of the Light and is presided over by the Lord Captain Commander.

Council of Twenty Two.name: Council of Twenty Two
Council of Twenty Two.overview:
The Council of Twenty Two is the future council of the Aiel in one of Aviendha 's visions through the Glass columns.

Speculatively, the number twenty-two would match a Wise One and Clan chief for eleven out of the twelve traditional clans. It's likely that the Shaido no longer existed as a clan after their defeat in Malden and Padra 's later point of view recalls "all eleven Clan Chiefs" in attendance decades earlier. The Companion notes that the Shaido "dispersed in many directions", giving some credit to this theory. From Ladalin's point of view, we know that both Wise Ones and Clan Chiefs attended. The Council is not mentioned in The Wheel of Time Companion.

Its time-frame is likewise unknown. Ladalin notes, however, that Takai was in attendance at the Council and that he was "the third chief of the Miagoma in as many years". If he attended in the capacity of a Clan Chief, this would place it as occurring less than a year before the fall of the White Tower and around twenty years after the Seanchan capture of the Andoran war machines. This would also imply that the fall of the Aiel was extremely swift as, by the time of Ladalin's vision, only five Aiel Clans remained and only "three clan chiefs and two Wise Ones... remained of the Council of Twenty-Two." Again, this would have been within a year of the Council.

On the other hand, if Takai attended in another capacity, it may have been much longer before the later meeting of survivors.

Counsel.name: Counsel
Counsel.overview: Counsel is the rank that the members of the ruling body of Far Madding hold, highest among them being the First Counsel.

Court of the Nine Moons.name: Court of the Nine Moons
Court of the Nine Moons.overview: The Court of the Nine Moons is the throne room of the Seanchan rulers.

Crescent Palace.name: Crescent Palace
Crescent Palace.overview:
The Crescent Palace is the large, ornate residence of Lord Balthaz of Tarabon. It is located in Tanchico on the Maetsa peninsula, not far from the king's palace.

It bears the "palace" moniker only because a former Panarch was heard to exclaim that it was "amazing, almost like a palace in miniature" upon entering the building; the other part of the name comes from its cresent-moon motif.

Although it is not actually a royal residence, the Crescent Palace is as impressive as a private home can be imagined. It stands two stories high, amid a formal garden surrounded by a 15-foot white stone wall. Crescent moons decorate the wrought-iron bars of the gate, top the corners of the walls, and proliferate along the scrollwork detailing of the building's fancy corneries.

In the absence of Lord Balthaz, the palace is let out to Belyne Sedai during her stay in Tanchico.

Crimsonthorn root.name: Crimsonthorn root
Crimsonthorn root.overview: Crimsonthorn root is an herb described as being white and having a rather sweet taste to it. It is a good painkiller in small doses. In large quantities it kills more than just pain by slowly paralyzing muscles and causing asphyxia. Adeleas Namelle and Ispan Shefar found this out first-hand the paralyzing nature of crimsonthorn root. No antidote is known for a strong dose.

Crossbow.name: Crossbow
Crossbow.overview:
The crossbow is a weapon consisting of a bow that is mounted on a stock and shoots bolts instead of arrows. Unlike a regular bow, which relies on the muscle power of the archer, a crossbow uses mechanical principles to launch its arrow.

The crossbow is consistently described as being significantly inferior to weapons such as the Two Rivers-style longbow in power, accuracy, range, and refire rate (due to long reload times). However, it is far simpler to use, and men can be trained and drilled in crossbow use far faster than they can be trained in the use of the longbow.

The Band of the Red Hand have incorporated the crossbow as a standard weapon among their troops and have proved efficient when using it. They have also incorporated a number of mechanical improvements, including a crank design which significantly decreases the reload time of the crossbows and allows Band crossbowmen to unleash volleys of crossbow fire at an unprecedented rate.

Crossroads of Twilight.name: Crossroads of Twilight
Crossroads of Twilight.overview: Crossroads of Twilight (abbreviated CoT ) is the tenth book in The Wheel of Time series. It was published by Tor Books and released on January 7, 2003. Upon its release, it immediately rose to the #1 position on the New York Times hardcover fiction bestseller list, making it the third Wheel of Time book to reach the #1 position on that list. It remained on the list for the next three months. It is 846 pages long.

Crown High Council.name: Crown High Council
Crown High Council.overview:
