The Crown High Council is the governmental body which rules the kingdom of Ghealdan in the name of the King or Queen. The Council sees to the day-to-day running of the kingdom and consists of a council of nobles and merchants.

The Council was founded by Lady Valera Prosnarin, Lord Cynric Talvaen and Lady Iona Ashmar, who along with Lord Kirin Almeyda had established Ghealdan during the latter part of the War of the Hundred Years. Almeyda became King and his companions became his closest advisors. As the centuries passed, additional houses gained seats on the Council.

If the King or Queen dies without issue, the new ruler is elected from within the ranks of the Council. Traditionally, the Council's power has been secondary to that of the ruler and the elite military forces, the Legion of the Wall. However, the chaos brought about by the arrival of the Prophet of the Dragon in the kingdom saw several rulers topple in rapid succession and the Legion disband at Masema's order. Queen Alliandre Maritha Kigarin was not permitted to reconstitute the Legion. After Alliandre departed Ghealdan with Lord Perrin Aybara on a mission to bring the Prophet to heel, the Crown High Council assumed full control of the country until her return.

The Crown High Council is unaware that Alliandre has both reconstituted the Legion of the Wall under First Captain Gerard Arganda and sworn fealty to the Dragon Reborn, Rand al'Thor, through his representative, Perrin.

Crown of Swords.name: Crown of Swords
Crown of Swords.overview:
The Crown of Swords is the crown worn by the king of Illian. It was formerly known as the Laurel Crown but was renamed by the current king Rand al'Thor. It was renamed because it contains small swords hidden amongst the laurel leaves that prick his skull. The crown was first seen in one of the first of Min's viewings:

"A sword that isn't a sword, a golden crown of laurel leaves..."

The crown is noted to be very heavy due to the amount of gold put into making it, and the swords provide much discomfort. Recently, during Rand's battle with the Seanchan, one of the swords acquired a chip in it.

Crown of the Tree.name: Crown of the Tree
Crown of the Tree.overview:
The Crown of the Tree is the crown worn by the Panarch of Tarabon. It is a wreath of golden trefoil leaves supporting a large moonstone, the trefoil leaves symbolizing Tarabon's cultural association with Avendesora.

The Crown of the Tree is worn along with the Panarch's Stole.

Cuebiyarsande.name: Cuebiyarsande
Cuebiyarsande.overview:
Cuebiyarsande was a city in the nation of Aramaelle, which was part of the Ten Nations. Aside from the name, nothing else is know about it.

Its name translated into the Common Tongue is possibly "Rose of our Heart" - from the Old Tongue words cuebiyar (meaning "(my) heart; capitalized, it refers to the heart of the nation or people, or the heart of a ruler") and ande (meaning "rose").

Cuendillar.name: Cuendillar
Cuendillar.overview: Cuendillar (pronounced K WAIN-de-yar ), also known as heartstone, is an almost indestructible substance created during the Age of Legends. It absorbs any force attempting to break it, including the One Power, and is believed to become stronger as a result. Cuendillar objects have been shown to be unharmed even by balefire. We see this when Jeaine Caide unleashes balefire using the stolen black rod ter'angreal in Tanchico where "the cuendillar figures were all that dropped out of that molten white shaft".

Culain's Hound.name: Culain's Hound
Culain's Hound.overview: Culain's Hound is an inn in the New City district of Caemlyn.

Cullen's Crossing.name: Cullen's Crossing
Cullen's Crossing.overview: Cullen's Crossing is small village in Andor ten miles from Caemlyn.

Cumbar Hills.name: Cumbar Hills
Cumbar Hills.overview: The Cumbar Hills are located in southern Murandy, south of Lugard. The rebel Aes Sedai under Egwene al'Vere passed through this region during their march to the Andoran border. The River Reisendrelle passes through this region.

Cup (Constellation).name: Cup (Constellation)
Cup (Constellation).overview: One of the constellations seen over the night skies of the Westlands.

Customs and Ceremonies of the Tairen Cou.name: Customs and Ceremonies of the Tairen Court
Customs and Ceremonies of the Tairen Cou.overview: Customs and Ceremonies of the Tairen Court is a book left behind when a group of Black Ajah fled the White Tower. It was used as a taunt and bait so that Nynaeve al'Meara, Elayne Trakand, and Egwene al'Vere would chase the Black sisters to Tear.

Cutting the Clouds.name: Cutting the Clouds
Cutting the Clouds.overview: Cutting the Clouds is a sword form. The movements associated with this form are unknown. Lan Mandragoran once used this form to cut off an assassin's hand in Canluum. There may be a very tenuous allusion to "Wave Hands Like Clouds" from Tai Chi.

Cutting the Reeds.name: Cutting the Reeds
Cutting the Reeds.overview: Cutting the Reeds is a sword form. Other than the name, nothing is known about it.

Cutting the Wind.name: Cutting the Wind
Cutting the Wind.overview: Cutting the Wind is a sword form. Other than the name, nothing is known about it.

Cutworm.name: Cutworm
Cutworm.overview: A cutworm is an agricultural pest found in the Two Rivers. After Bili Congar named the Dark One, cutworm got into his field and only his field.

Cyrendemar'naille.name: Cyrendemar'naille
Cyrendemar'naille.overview: Cyrendemar'naille was an Ogier-built city in Aridhol, one of the Ten Nations after the Breaking.

Da'covale.name: Da'covale
Da'covale.overview:
Da'covale is a term used among the Seanchan for slaves. The term "property" is often used too, as the word means "one who is owned," or "person who is property" in the Old Tongue.

Those born to covale parents are also considered da'covale, including those who are born to a da'covale mother and a father who is not da'covale. Thus, most men do not lie with da'covale, or use birth control if they do. In the very unusual circumstance that a child is born to a free mother and a da'covale father, the child is free, since condition always follows that of the mother in Seanchan society.

Any free person can own a da'covale, and not just the Blood. They may be bought and sold like horses.

Slavery has a long and unusual history among the Seanchan, with slaves having the ability to rise to positions of great power and open authority, including authority over those who are free. An example of such a position is so'jhin. To a large degree, da'covale share somewhat in the standing of their master or mistress, modified by the position in the household. A lesser lord or lady may have to defer to a high-ranking da'covale in the household of a High Lord or High Lady, at least to a so'jhin, and a High Lord or High Lady would show respect to a da'covale of the Imperial household.

Da'covale traditionally wear nearly transparent white robes. When outdoors, these are usually covered by outer robes of thick white wool. Higher ranking da'covale, such as so'jhin, do not wear these robes, and shave half of their heads.

It is also possible for those in positions of great power to be reduced to da'covale. Examples of such da'covale are the former Panarch of Tarabon Amathera and the High Lady Suroth, as well as most nobles and Guardians of the Gate in Amadicia who were not killed by the Seanchan. In Seanchan, many preferred execution to the possible punishment of being reduced to da'covale in light of a crime.

However, it is possible to be freed as a da'covale, and it is customary in some circumstances to free da'covale in one's will if they have served long or in a close capacity, much in the manner that someone may leave money or trinkets to a close servant. This is not always done, or even desired by the da'covale, because the complexities of Seanchan society meant that being freed sometimes brought a reduction in social standing. By law, one is required to make provision for the future of any da'covale freed, either by establishing a trust or seeing that the da'covale had a way to earn a living and support any family.

Da'shain Aiel.name: Da'shain Aiel
Da'shain Aiel.overview: The Da'shain Aiel are the ancestors of the Jenn Aiel, the modern Aiel, and the Tuatha'an. During the Age of Legends, they were servants of the Aes Sedai and followers of the Way of the Leaf.

Da'tsang.name: Da'tsang
Da'tsang.overview: Da'tsang, meaning "despised one" in the Old Tongue, is a term among the Aiel.

Daes Dae'mar.name: Daes Dae'mar
Daes Dae'mar.overview:
Daes Dae'mar is a phrase in the Old Tongue which translates to The Great Game, but is more commonly known as The Game Of Houses.

It refers to the political and social maneuvering employed by the nobility of various nations to gain status or wealth, or to cause the downfall of others they dislike.

The Great Game is played the most heavily in Cairhien, where the most seemingly irrelevant act can cause lords and ladies to speculate endlessly about one's motives; even servants of the Cairhienin nobility play their own version of Daes Dae'mar. Conversely, it is rarely seen in the Borderlands, as Borderlanders are more concerned with Shadowspawn and the Blight than individual power, status or wealth.

It has been stated that the best way to put players of the Great Game off balance, is to be honest, since no-one expects you to be. This has been the case with both Rand and Perrin.

Perhaps one of the most accomplished players of the Great Game in current times is Thom Merrilin, who developed his skill at court in Caemlyn. He has used his skill more than once to come to the aid of Rand al'Thor; first in Cairhien while Rand was hunting the Horn of Valere, and later in Tear after Rand proclaimed himself the Dragon Reborn to keep the Tairen High Lords off-balance enough to leave him alone. Another accomplished player of the Game is Moiraine Damodred, whose skillful mind for the Game more than once was annoyed with Siuan Sanche 's lack of understanding for it.

Rand and Perrin have often expressed their dislike of Daes Dae'mar, though Rand has become skilled in it recently.

Berelain supposedly has used the Game of Houses heavily to protect her small country of Mayene from being absorbed by Tear.

Daghain.name: Daghain
Daghain.overview:
Daghain is a satellite village of Tar Valon, on the eastern bank of the river Erinin, were one of the six bridges of the city connects the island to the continent.

Because Tar Valon is often the target of attacks and sieges, the village has been a victim of many burnings over the years.

Dahan.name: Dahan
Dahan.overview:
Dahan occurs on the ninth day of Saven.

It is supposedly the anniversary of final victory in the Trolloc Wars and freedom from the Shadow. It is believed that the date was arbitrarily chosen.

Dai Shan.name: Dai Shan
Dai Shan.overview:
Dai Shan is a title from lost Malkier and known throughout the Borderlands.

In the Old Tongue, "dai shan" means "battle lord." In the Borderlands, Lan Mandragoran is often called Dai Shan. Lord Agelmar Jagad explains that when Lan was a baby, his parents anointed his head with oil and named him Dai Shan, a Diademed Battle Lord. It is not known if all kings of Malkier are titled Dai Shan.

Dailin.name: Dailin
Dailin.overview:
For the Maiden of the Spear, see Dailin (maiden) .

Dailin is a Shaido Wise One.

Daishar.name: Daishar
Daishar.overview:
Battle blood (n.) – daishar (meaning, glory)

Daishar is a horse owned by Egwene al'Vere. His name means "glory" in the Old Tongue.

Dal Calain.name: Dal Calain
Dal Calain.overview: Dal Calain was a kingdom of the Free Years. It arose from the ruins of Coremanda after the Trolloc Wars. Its territory is currently unclaimed by any modern nation.

Dalenshar.name: Dalenshar
Dalenshar.overview:
Dalenshar is an area on the Seanchan continent.

Kennar Miraj has troops that come from Dalenshar. People from Dalenshar, including Gamel Loune have black skin and a distinctive accent.

Dalsande.name: Dalsande
Dalsande.overview:
Dalsande was a city in Essenia, which was part of the Ten Nations. Other than the name, nothing else is known about it.

Its name translated into the Common Tongue is possibly "Rose Bowl" - from the Old Tongue words dal (meaning "bowl") and ande (meaning "rose").

Damane.name: Damane
Damane.overview:
For the chapter in The Great Hunt called "Damane", see The Great Hunt/Chapter 40 . Damane with her Sul'dam by Ariel Burgess, Official Wheel of Time Artist

A damane ( Old Tongue: Leashed One ) is a woman who can channel who has been leashed by the Seanchan, using a type of ter'angreal called an a'dam.

Damane are Seanchan women (for only women can be collared, although a male collar was later described in the series) born with the spark or ability to channel. As the Seanchan believe that these women can cause great damage with the One Power, they are leashed by a controller, known as a sul'dam, or "Leash Holder", who utilize a collar-like tool known as the a'dam. A woman who can channel and who has not been collared is known as marath'damane ( Old Tongue: those who must be leashed ), and is seen as an abomination. Seanchan consider any Aes Sedai not collared to be marath'damane.

When Hawkwing 's son, Luthair first came to Seanchan, he found a vast land that was a seething cauldron of alliances and betrayals and power grabs. Among them were those who called themselves Aes Sedai, though they bore little resemblance to the Aes Sedai of the White Tower. They used the Power in battle, and turned on each other as readily as they did anyone else. It is not known how women were trained in such chaos, possibly by individual apprenticeship.

In the course of conquering this new land Luthair was handed his greatest weapon, the a'dam, made for him by an Aes Sedai who sought to ingratiate herself. It is made of silvery metal, has a collar part (worn by the damane ) and a bracelet part (worn by her controller, the sul'dam ). They are linked by a leash a few feet in length, though it is later found out that the leash part isn't strictly necessary, and the collar and bracelet will work without it. Either the Seanchan have never realized this (unlikely, in all the centuries of making a'dam ) or they prefer not to permit their damane too much freedom.

The a'dam has different effects depending on which part is worn, and who wears it. When collared, a woman who is capable of touching saidar cannot channel more than a thread without becoming violently sick; she cannot move the bracelet more than a foot; she cannot touch anything she considers to be a weapon, and she cannot open her own - or another - collar. Likewise, when worn by a woman who can channel, the bracelet permits the wearer to feel the emotional state of the woman in the collar, to cause her pain or pleasure just by willing it, and to control completely her access to the Source. If she wishes, she can channel, with the damane being nothing more than a conduit. A person who cannot channel will be unaffected by either part. If a man who can channel, or has the potential to learn, puts on the bracelet, both he and the damane suffer pain. If contact is maintained, both die in horrible agony. This is speculated to be because when men and women link unaided, the woman must initiate, while the a'dam forces control of the link to the wearer of the bracelet.

Luthair's dislike for channelers translated itself to the culture he built; damane have the lowest status of any channeler in the Wheel of Time universe. All damane become property, slaves, as soon as they are found to be able to channel. Even those who work closely with damane consider them to be little more than useful and intelligent animals. It would be expected that such a life would make damane incredibly frustrated and rebellious, eager to be free, but in fact the opposite is true. Raised in the Seanchan culture, they honestly believe they need to be collared for the safety of everyone else, and behavior training makes them childlike, obedient, and eager to please. Even when damane are "freed", the conditioning is almost impossible to break, and many freed damane have great difficulty adjusting to autonomy.

Since the start of The Return, several channelers from the Westlands (including several Aes Sedai ) have been collared. Although some have successfully escaped from this captivity, most collared Aes Sedai have been effectively broken to the a'dam. It is unclear how collaring Aes Sedai affects their Warders.

Damane are kept and treated as sentient pets, but their main use is in battle, as fearsome weapons. They are trained in the art of using the One Power as a weapon, preferring fireballs and lightning to more indirect methods. Collared Aes Sedai are largely useless as weapons in battle since the Three Oaths forbid them from attacking those who aren't darkfriends or shadowspawn (unless directly threatened). Specially trained damane are able to put on an impressive pyrotechnics show known as the Sky Lights, and they are the only culture known where the Talent for copying ter'angreal is still found (it is not clear if they can also experiment in creating completely new items of the Power). The full range of Talents found in these particular channelers is not known, but there are damane who have learned to Heal - although few Seanchan would welcome the help - and some of them have a version of the Foretelling, allowing them to tell 'fortunes'. In many cases this could be pure charlatanry, tying in with a very superstitious culture, but we have seen at least one fortune, detailed and specific, come true. As Sea Folk Windfinders have almost certainly been collared over the years, it makes sense that damane are skilled in weather control as well. The Seanchan damane also have the talent for Delving, or finding and extracting ores from the earth. This talent is mentioned for the first time when Egwene is captured and is shown to have a strong affinity for this Talent. The range and usefulness of these abilities to the Empire have made the Seanchan Empire apparently invincible.

Damelien.name: Damelien
Damelien.overview:
Damelien is a village in Andor.

When Elayne Trakand and her group make their way to Caemlyn after Traveling from Altara, they stay at an inn called The Golden Sheaves. While there, Elayne hears rumors that the Dragon Reborn had killed both her and her mother.

Damona Mountains.name: Damona Mountains
Damona Mountains.overview:
The Damona Mountains are a mountain range in eastern Altara. They stretch from close to Garen's Wall to the River Manetherendrelle, forming a barrier between the north and south of the country and an obstacle to travel between Altara and Murandy. The Damonas are "new" mountains, that is a range formed in the Breaking of the World and noted for being extremely craggy. What appear to be passes through the mountains frequently turn out to be dead ends, making traversing them difficult.

The Damonas are traversible by one well-known pass, the five-mile-wide Molvaine Gap, which carries the Great North Road on its way from Ebou Dar to Lugard. The Great North Road is also known in this region as the Lugard Road. Just short of the Gap are the Malvide Narrows, where the road winds through the foothills towards the gap, a perfect place for ambushes and battles.

Danabar.name: Danabar
Danabar.overview: Danabar is a location in Andor where Elayne Trakand possesses some estates. It is located in mountainous countryside in the vicinity of the Lugard Road, although not within easy reach of it. In early 1000 NE, significant deposits of alum were found at Danabar, and Elayne used these to fund her claim to the Lion Throne.

Dance with Jak o' the Shadows.name: Dance with Jak o' the Shadows
Dance with Jak o' the Shadows.overview: Dance with Jak o' the Shadows is song usually sung by Matrim Cauthon and the Band of the Red Hand. According to Mat, it had not been heard since Aldeshar fell to Artur Hawkwing 1,000 years before he taught it to the Band.

Dandelion in the Wind.name: Dandelion in the Wind
Dandelion in the Wind.overview: Dandelion in the Wind is a sword form. The movements for this form are unknown. Lan Mandragoran once used this form to slice open an assassin's throat after using The Rose Unfolds. The form's name may allude to the spray of blood from a throat wound looking similarly to a dandelion spraying in the wind.

Danshu.name: Danshu
Danshu.overview: Danshu occurs on the twenty-eighth day of Nesan.

Dantora.name: Dantora
Dantora.overview: Dantora is an island belonging to the Atha'an Miere and is part of the Aile Jafar group.

Danu.name: Danu
Danu.overview: Danu is the thirteenth month in the Farede calendar. In most years, it is equivalent to the real world period from November 24 to December 21. The Feast of Lights occurs on the 28th.

Daori.name: Daori
Daori.overview:
A daori refers to the customary braid of hair cut from a Malkieri man.

A Malkieri boy's hair was allowed to grow to the waist. At a certain age they were given the right to tie it back with the hadori. When the boy is taken as a lover, his first lover has his hair cut back to shoulder length. He would weave a piece of that cut-off hair-part into a cord and present that to his lover as a token of his obligations and ties to her. After that time Malkieri man wore their hair shoulder length. Never shorter, never longer.

The first lover is called carneira. She has his hair being cut off right after their first night together and the braid is kept by the carneira. She will present the daori to the man's bride on his wedding day. Custom dictates that while a man holds his daori, his will is at the whim of his carneira. Men have several obligations towards their carneira, although he has no right to demand any from her.

Dapple.name: Dapple
Dapple.overview: Dapple is the leader of the pack of wolves affiliated with Elyas Machera.

Darath.name: Darath
Darath.overview: An animal from the Age of Legends. The darath was a dangerous creature in molt.

Darein.name: Darein
Darein.overview: Darein is a village at the base of the middle Tar Valon bridge on the west shore (The Alindrelle Erinin ). Darein was burned during the Trolloc Wars, destroyed by Artur Hawkwing, looted during the Hundred Years War and burned again during the Aiel War. Every time it was rebuilt. During the White Tower Schism negotiations were held between the two factions in Darein.

Dark One's eyes (carrion).name: Dark One's eyes (carrion)
Dark One's eyes (carrion).overview:
For the dice roll, see The Dark One's Eyes (dice) .

Dark One's Eyes are crows, ravens,, rats and other carrion eaters that serve as spies for the Shadow.

Dark One.name: Dark One
Dark One.overview: The Dark One is the primordial, sapient, cosmic force of evil in the universe. The Dark One's goal is to break the spirits and hearts of whatever sapient beings he can influence, and, if freed from his prison, eventually to remake Creation in his own image. His actions appear to indicate that he is also a force of chaos, destruction, and discord, as many of his underlings, as well as Shaidar Haran, seemed to place a great deal of emphasis on increasing the amount of chaos in the world at any opportunity. His existence is revealed to be an integral part of human free will, as his malign influence encourages humanity to make selfish choices. If destroyed, humans (and likely other sapient beings) would seemingly become completely incapable of evil, violence, or selfishness in any respect. He is said to have been imprisoned by the Creator at the beginning of time in a separate dimension outside of normal reality, and outside of the Pattern, and has sought ever since to break free of his prison and destroy the Wheel of Time and remake the world according to his image and purpose, or alternatively, to destroy creation completely. He is currently imprisoned, outside of the Pattern.

Darkfriend.name: Darkfriend
Darkfriend.overview: Darkfriends, known as Atha'an Shadar (People of the Shadow) among the Seanchan, Shadowrunners among the Aiel, and Friends of the Dark amongst themselves and by the people of the Second Age, are humans who given allegiance to the Shadow, usually due to a desire for immortality and power. Although members of the Black Ajah are Darkfriends (as are Dreadlords and even the Forsaken ), the vast majority of Darkfriends cannot channel. Shadowspawn (with the arguable exception of Gray Men ) are not considered Darkfriends. There are no known Ogier allied with the Shadow. Therefore, it is not known if such Ogier would be considered Darkfriends.

Darluna.name: Darluna
Darluna.overview: Darluna is a large town in southern Arad Doman.

Darmovan.name: Darmovan
Darmovan.overview: Darmovan was a large kingdom that existed during the Free Years. It was established after the end of the Trolloc Wars, rising out of the former territory of Safer. It later formed part of the empire of Artur Hawkwing. Darmovan is known to history as the place where the false Dragon Guaire Amalasan begin his campaign to conquer the Westlands, although it is unclear if Darmovan was his homeland. Its territory was later inherited by the kingdom of Almoth and parts of it are today held by Arad Doman and Tarabon, although the majority is wilderness.

Dart.name: Dart
Dart.overview: Dart is a horse that belongs to Rodel Ituralde.

Darter.name: Darter
Darter.overview: The Darter is a ship on the River Erinin. It has a bluff bow and is twice as wide as the Blue Crane.

Daryne.name: Daryne
Daryne.overview: The Daryne are one of the twelve Aiel clans. Their clan hold is unknown.

Daughter-Heir.name: Daughter-Heir
Daughter-Heir.overview:
The Daughter-Heir of Andor is the title given to the heiress-apparent to the Lion Throne of Andor. Although the Andoran Daughter-Heir is generally a princess, she need not be so, as discussed further.

As Andor can legally only be ruled by a woman, the rule over that nation is ideally passed from the ruling queen to her eldest daughter. If the queen has no daughters, the succession to the throne follows to the queen's nearest female blood relation. However, in practice, determining which noblewoman that might be can be very complicated, as the great houses of Andor are heavily interrelated, and many of them all claim a line of descent from Ishara, the first queen and foundress of Andor in the opening stages of the War of the Hundred Years.

In the event of the absence of a clear Daughter-Heir, internal armed struggles may erupt, known outside of Andor as Wars of Succession and internally colloquially referred to simply as the 'Succession' or as blandly as as 'disturbances."

Prior to the onset of the storyline, Andor had only just emerged from yet another Succession as Morgase Trakand was placed upon the Lion Throne by a coalition of allied houses who successfully completed the claim put forth by Morgase's late mother, Lady Maighdin. Both Maighdin and Morgase were deemed the closest female blood relations to the late queen, Mordrellen Mantear. Queen Mordrellen's own Daughter-Heir, Lady Tigraine, had gone missing and was declared dead.

It is unknown how legally unassailable the Trakands' dynastic claim was, as it did result in armed conflict requiring a military solution with numerous allied blocs of houses contesting the throne. The internal struggles were again repeated when numerous noblewomen asserted a claim as Morgase's Daughter-Heir when both Morgase and Elayne were missing and the Lion Throne was again vacant.

The claim to the Lion Throne, by which typically only a woman may ascend, actually can be passed to male members of Ishara's line, therefore revealing there really is no Sallic Bar, that is, women-only succession. As we see in the series, in Andor, numerous powerful Andoran lords are seen trying to assert claims for their daughters and granddaughters.

The Daughter-Heir of Andor is awarded a ceremonial crown, called the Diadem of the Daughter-Heir.

Daughter of the Nine Moons.name: Daughter of the Nine Moons
Daughter of the Nine Moons.overview:
Daughter of the Nine Moons is a title in the Seanchan empire. The title is held by the current heir to the Crystal Throne. The title was most held by Tuon Athaem Kore Paendrag and upon her ascension to Empress, the title became vacant. It can be assumed that if a man was heir, the title would be changed to "Son of the Nine Moons." Matrim Cauthon is supposed to marry the Daughter of the Nine Moons, he finds out, visiting in the world of Aelfinn through the twisted red doorframe under the Stone of Tear ( TSR 15 )

After the mourning period that follows the death of an Empress, the Daughter of the Nine Moons must state "I am the Empress" to be recognized as the successor to the Crystal Throne. She is then crowned in the imperial capital, and is given the opportunity to execute any who she believes has barred her ascent to the throne with her own hand.

Daughters of Silence.name: Daughters of Silence
Daughters of Silence.overview:
The Daughters of Silence was a group formed in the year 794 NE by two former Accepted who were put out of the White Tower. They gathered twenty-three wilders and organized, taught and trained them in the Power. When the Aes Sedai discovered them in the year 798 NE, they disbanded the group, enrolled the "students" in the Tower as novices and punished the two former Accepted who started the group. The punishment was severe and public to make sure that the lesson was carried to everyone who might entertain the thought of channelers outside of the Tower banding together.

Only one of the women enrolled as a novice ever became full Aes Sedai - Saerin Asnobar.

Dawn Wind.name: Dawn Wind
Dawn Wind.overview: Dawn Wind is a horse owned by Elenia Sarand.

Dawnweave.name: Dawnweave
Dawnweave.overview: Dawnweave is a horse owned by Rodel Ituralde.

Day of Repentance.name: Day of Repentance
Day of Repentance.overview:
Day of Repentance is a feast held at the first half moon after High Chasaline.

It is celebrated in Cairhien. According to Min, it includes "sedate dancing" at night, and she asks Rand to join her for it.

Daylight.name: Daylight
Daylight.overview: Daylight is a horse owned by Faile Bashere.

Dealings with the Territory of Mayene, 5.name: Dealings with the Territory of Mayene, 500 to 700 of the New Era
Dealings with the Territory of Mayene, 5.overview: Dealings with the Territory of Mayene, 500 to 700 of the New Era is a book that Rand al'Thor studied in the Stone of Tear.

Death of Ten Thousand Tears.name: Death of Ten Thousand Tears
Death of Ten Thousand Tears.overview: The Death of Ten Thousand Tears in Seanchan is a death sentence given to the members of the High Blood who displease the Empress, since their blood may not be spilled. They are put bonded inside a silk sack that is suspended from a particular tower till they die and the sack rots away.

Deathwatch Guard.name: Deathwatch Guard
Deathwatch Guard.overview:
The Deathwatch Guard are elite Seanchan personal guards to the Seanchan Empress. They are made up of both men and Ogier Gardeners. The humans are da'covale and are the private property of the Empress. If the person the Deathwatch Guard is protecting dies, the remaining human guards are executed.

Their armor is lacquered red and green, the latter so dark that it is commonly thought of as black. Ranks in the Deathwatch stand a half step above those in the Ever Victorious Army.

Members of the Deathwatch Guard often display the ravens tattooed on their shoulders, the mark of a da'covale of the Empress.

December.name: December
December.overview: December is the ninth month in the Gregorian calendar. It occurs in Wheel of Time world during Danu 8 to Taisham 10.

Deckmistress.name: Deckmistress
Deckmistress.overview: Deckmistress is the Atha'an Miere title given to a woman on a ship. She is the one who receives orders from her Sailmistress and is responsible for making sure that the entire crew carries them out.

Defender of Amadicia.name: Defender of Amadicia
Defender of Amadicia.overview:
For other Defenders, see Defender .

Defender of Amadicia is a title of the Amadician monarch. Nothing is known about the title, aside from the obvious implication. The last known holder of the title was King Ailron.

Defender of Garen's Wall.name: Defender of Garen's Wall
Defender of Garen's Wall.overview:
For other Defenders, see Defender .

Defender of Garen's Wall is a title of the monarch of Ghealdan. It is currently held by Alliandre Maritha Kigarin. The title is derived from the location in Ghealdan, Garen's Wall.

Defender of the Heartland.name: Defender of the Heartland
Defender of the Heartland.overview:
For other Defenders, see Defender .

Defender of the Heartland is a Saldaean title owned by Davram Bashere, father of Faile, father-in-law of Perrin, and Marshal-General to Tenobia, Queen of Saldaea.

Defender of the Realm.name: Defender of the Realm
Defender of the Realm.overview:
For other Defenders, see Defender .

Defender of the Realm is a title of the Queen of Andor.

Andoran history may bear some light on how the title came to be part of the royal styling. In FY 1063, Queen Maragaine personally led her army into battle against four rival kings who sought to invade Andor. This type of heroics could have been the foundation of the title.

Currently, Elayne Trakand holds the title. Her mother, Morgase Trakand, held the title when she was queen.

Defender of the Wall of First Fires.name: Defender of the Wall of First Fires
Defender of the Wall of First Fires.overview:
Defender of the Wall of First Fires is a title Lan Mandragoran claimed for himself just prior to ordering his army of twelve thousand to charge one hundred fifty thousand Shadowspawn at Tarwin's Gap.

Little remains to inform us of his meaning, but it is not hard to assume that it had something to do with a line of defense maintained by Malkier. And it probably had something to do with fires, perhaps beacons to alert the nation that an invasion from the Blight was occurring.

Defender of the Waves.name: Defender of the Waves
Defender of the Waves.overview:
For other Defenders, see Defender .

Defender of the Waves is a title of the Firsts of Mayene. The title alludes to Mayene's location in the Westlands, on a peninsula on the Sea of Storms and the easternmost city. If any naval invasion were to come from either the Aiel Waste or Shara, Mayene would be a first line of defense. The current holder of the title is First Berelain sur Paendrag Paeron.

Defenders of the Stone.name: Defenders of the Stone
Defenders of the Stone.overview: The Defenders of the Stone are an elite military group of Tear. They guard the Stone of Tear, form the core of the Tairen army and act as a police force within the city of Tear.

Degalle.name: Degalle
Degalle.overview: The Degalle is a sept of the Shiande Aiel. Janwin, the clan chief of the Shiande, was born in the Degalle sept.

Denhuir.name: Denhuir
Denhuir.overview:
Denhuir is a village located on the Maradon Road near the Black Hills.

Denhuir is the village where Mazrim Taim escapes the custody of Aes Sedai. When Siuan Sanche learns of this, she sends a dozen Aes Sedai and one thousand guards to capture and gentle him.

Deranbar.name: Deranbar
Deranbar.overview:
Deranbar was the capital city of Jaramide, which was part of the Ten Nations.

During their reconstruction after the Breaking of the World, Ogier built a waygate to Deranbar. The city later became modern-day Maradon.

Deven Ride.name: Deven Ride
Deven Ride.overview: Deven Ride is a community located near the southern boundary of the Two Rivers region.

Dhael.name: Dhael
Dhael.overview: Dhael is an Aiel Maiden of the Spear.

Dhagon.name: Dhagon
Dhagon.overview:
The River Dhagon is a river that flows out of the northernmost peaks of the Mountains of Mist. The river flows south and west through Arad Doman, where it is joined by the River Akuum before reaching the sea at Bandar Eban.

There is a large hill-chain (or small mountain range) lying north of the River Dhagon's easternmost course where two inhabited Ogier stedding are located, Stedding Mintai and Stedding Wenchen.

Dhallin Forest.name: Dhallin Forest
Dhallin Forest.overview: Dhallin Forest is a forest in Ghealdan. Several battles were fought here between the false Dragon Logain Ablar and the forces opposed to him, but Logain won these engagements. The forest's location within Ghealdan is unknown.

Dhana.name: Dhana
Dhana.overview: Dhana is a Seanchan to'raken who takes Mat and Olver to the Valley of Thakan'dar. An arrow from the battle below hits her wing, forcing Mat to perform a crash landing after her rider Sulaan is also injured.

Dhowlan.name: Dhowlan
Dhowlan.overview: Dhowlan was a kingdom of the Free Years. It was founded after the Trolloc Wars, rising out of the southernmost remnants of Manetheren, and was later conquered by the false Dragon Guaire Amalasan and then Artur Hawkwing. The modern kingdom of Ghealdan almost exactly matches the borders of Dhowlan.

Dhurran.name: Dhurran
Dhurran.overview:
Dhurrans are breed of large draft horses originally from a region or town in Ghealdan.

In Emond's Field, Bran al'Vere owns a team of six Dhurrans which he hires out to local farmers when they have tasks of hauling that are beyond the capabilities of regular horses. After the initial attack on the village, Rand sees them hauling Trolloc corpses to be burned.

Some are large enough for Ogier to ride. Loial 's horse is described in multiple places as "as big and heavy as a prime Dhurran stallion", but is not actually of this breed itself.

Dhurrans can be seen in the streets of Baerlon hauling large carts of ore to and from the ironworks.

Diadem of the Daughter-Heir.name: Diadem of the Daughter-Heir
Diadem of the Daughter-Heir.overview: The Diadem of the Daughter-Heir is the ceremonial crown awarded to the Daughter-Heir of Andor. It is a simplified version of the Rose Crown of Andor, a single highly wrought golden rose on a slim gold band. It first appeared when worn by Elayne Trakand in Winter's Heart.

Diadem of the First.name: Diadem of the First
Diadem of the First.overview:
The Diadem of the First is the ceremonial crown worn by the Firsts of Mayene, the ruler of the small nation of Mayene.

The diadem is described as a golden hawk in flight, resting amid the hair of the wearer, and affixed to a slim golden band. The golden hawk is both the symbol of Mayene itself, and the ruling family of Mayene, House Paeron, as well as being the historical sigil of Artur Hawkwing, from whom House Paeron claims descent.

Distances in the Westlands.name: Distances in the Westlands
Distances in the Westlands.overview:
The size of the Westlands can be calculated using quotes from the books. The distances quoted here are accurate to 1%.

The tables below give distances between all the capital cities and main locations of the nations of the Westlands. All are as the crow flies. Calculating the distances by road would depend on the route taken and we would assume that only the main roads are shown on the canonical maps. in addition, many times it makes sense to go off-road (as in The Dragon Reborn where Egwene travels with Verin and other across the Caralain grass to reach Tar Valon from Falme).

Dogwart.name: Dogwart
Dogwart.overview: Dogwort is an herb that can be found in the Two Rivers region and is used to aid kitting flesh from a wound.

Dogweed.name: Dogweed
Dogweed.overview: Dogweed is a tea with a taste that is considered extremely unpleasant. It is often used as a punishment to encourage the patient to end his or her moping behavoir. Rand al'Thor once reminded Egwene al'Vere that Nynaeve al'Meara dosed her with dogweed tea.

Doirlon Hills.name: Doirlon Hills
Doirlon Hills.overview:
The Doirlon Hills are an upland region located along the eastern border of Illian, at the western edge of the Plains of Maredo. The Illianers have fortified these hills with wooden border forts and stockades as part of their defensive lines against Tear.

In late 999 NE and early 1000 NE, Rand al'Thor assembled a vast army some 200 miles east of the Doirlon Hills in preparation for an invasion of Illian, then the stronghold of the Forsaken Sammael. A large-scale assault was launched on the hillforts under the command of the High Lord Weiramon Saniago. Despite some successes (mostly attributable to the Asha'man who accompanied Weiramon), the attack was checked by the personal intervention of Sammael. At this point Rand, another force of Asha'man, and the Legion of the Dragon Traveled into the city of Illian itself to liberate it. Sammael was forced to abandon the hillforts, which were subsequently overrun by Rand's forces.

Domai.name: Domai
Domai.overview: The Domai is a sept of the Shaido Aiel. The sept hold is unknown.

Dome of Truth.name: Dome of Truth
Dome of Truth.overview: The Dome of Truth is a building in Amador, capital of Amadicia.

Doomseer.name: Doomseer
Doomseer.overview:
A Doomseer is a Seanchan position for someone who is able to divine and interpret omens extremely skilfully. This position is highly respected in the Imperial Court. A true Doomseer is someone who is born with the ability to receive Viewings of future events in the Pattern, although Seanchan also knows that this ability is not tied to the One Power, as the Doomseers are very respected, unlike damane.

There have been no known individuals in Seanchan born with the ability to become a true Doomseer since c. 700 NE. When Empress Fortuona discovered that Min Farshaw was able to receive true Viewings, she immediately respected the woman and promoted her to Doomseer, despite Min's own objections to the totalitarian nature of Seanchan.

Dorelle Caromon.name: Dorelle Caromon
Dorelle Caromon.overview:
Dorelle Caromon was a city in Eharon, which was part of the Ten Nations.

During their construction after the Breaking of the World, Ogier built a waygate to Dorelle Caromon. The city later became the city of Illian.

Dorlan.name: Dorlan
Dorlan.overview:
Dorlan is a small village to the East of Tar Valon. Dorlan is the traditional, exclusive source of cheese for the White Tower.

The mayor of Dorlan is Garon Burlow. The village consists of fifteen houses, a village green and a cow barn for each house.

Dragon's Dagger.name: Dragon's Dagger
Dragon's Dagger.overview:
The Dragon's Dagger is a major mining complex in Kinslayer's Dagger, run and administered by the kingdom of Cairhien.

It is unknown if the "Dragon's Dagger" is the name of just the mine or the mountain it is located under as well.

Dragon's Fang.name: Dragon's Fang
Dragon's Fang.overview:
The Dragon's Fang is an ancient symbol, though its original meaning has been forgotten by present-day people.

In the Age of Legends, the Dragon's Fang, along with the Flame of Tar Valon, was part of the ancient symbol of the Aes Sedai. Since the Breaking and the splitting of the Aes Sedai to remove the men, the Dragon's Fang has taken on an evil meaning. A common use is to be scrawled on someone's door as an accusation of evil or as a curse. It is no longer connected with male channelers by the common person, and its origins are lost to common knowledge by the passing of years, but superstition still regards the Fang as an omen of evil or ill luck.

Dragon's Peace.name: Dragon's Peace
Dragon's Peace.overview: Until recently, not much was known about the Dragon's Peace, but it was mentioned when Aviendha stepped through the glass columns at Rhuidean the second time. It is Rand al'Thor 's legacy and final gift to the world, a peace treaty forbidding any conflict in the entire known world of the time.

Dragon Banner.name: Dragon Banner
Dragon Banner.overview: The Dragon Banner also called as the banner of the Lord of the Morning, or the banner of Lews Therin Telamon. The original one was used by the Dragon when he led the forces of the light against the Shadow during the War of the Shadow.

Dragon Scepter.name: Dragon Scepter
Dragon Scepter.overview: The Dragon Scepter is a scepter that Rand al'Thor uses as a symbol of the Dragon Reborn.

Dragon Throne.name: Dragon Throne
Dragon Throne.overview: The Dragon Throne was the throne used by Rand al'Thor.

Dragonmount.name: Dragonmount
Dragonmount.overview:
Dragonmount is a volcanic mountain west of the island of Tar Valon, located between the rivers Erinin and Luan and dominating the otherwise flat plain between the two. It is said to be perhaps the tallest mountain in the world, and is known to be several miles high at least.

It was created during the Breaking of the World, when Lews Therin Telamon killed himself after Ishamael Healed him from the insanity caused by the taint on saidin. His return to sanity forced him to acknowledge what he had done to family and friends, and in utter despair, he began channeling massive amounts of the One Power. He drew upon all that he could possibly channel, and then exceeded it, causing a bar of white-hot energy to descend from the sky. This pillar struck Lews Therin and atomized him, but also struck the ground where he had been standing. The blast, so hot as to flash-vaporize stone, tunneled into the mantle of the Earth and caused a volcanic eruption of gigantic proportions, creating Dragonmount. This eruption caused a river that had been flowing through the area near the mountain to fork, creating an isle that would come to be known as Tar Valon.

No person has ever successfully climbed to the top of Dragonmount (or at least climbed to the summit and back), and the slopes are littered with the bones of those who have attempted it. Smoke is always rising from the summit, leading to the idea that it is an active volcano ↗, It is the tallest mountain in the Westlands, even taller than any individual peak of the Spine of the World. Its shadow just touches the city of Tar Valon each evening.

Janduin 's and Tigraine Mantear 's son was born on the slopes of Dragonmount, fulfilling the Foretelling of Gitara Moroso. Tam al'Thor found the baby on Dragonmount during the Battle of the Shining Walls and adopted him with the name Rand al'Thor.

Dragons.name: Dragons
Dragons.overview: Dragons are a newly developed weapon originally designed by the Illuminator Aludra. She initially creates them as a means of taking revenge on the Seanchan for destroying the Illuminator's Guild. Mat Cauthon proposes the weapon to Elayne Trakand in Caemlyn who agrees to lend every bellfounder in Andor in order to make them.

Dragonsworn.name: Dragonsworn
Dragonsworn.overview:
Dragonsworn is the name given to a group of people who have sworn to serve and fight for the Dragon Reborn. The term is applied whether the Dragon they have sworn to follow is Rand al'Thor or a False Dragon like Taim or Logain.

Often times the Dragonsworn are no more than rioting peasants. Many of these groups have never had any political contact with the Dragon and frequently cause pandemonium in the land in misguided loyalty. As a result they clash frequently with the armed forces of whatever nation they arise in.

It should be noted that while the term "Dragonsworn" is applicable to anyone sworn to the Dragon, it is generally used only towards groups by those in disapproval.

However, at the time of the Last Battle, Dragonsworn forces became organized better and include also some members of nobility, gai'shain temporarily not wearing the white, and even several Aes Sedai with their warders, and several Asha'man. This army participates in attack on Shayol Ghul as well as in the battle of the Field of Merrilor. They are under command of the Great Captains and proves themselves valuable. In Shayol Ghul they were the last defenders of the path to the Pit of the Doom.

Dragonsworn are included also in the Rodel Ituralde's forces fighting Seanchan, where they are also effective.

Dreadbane.name: Dreadbane
Dreadbane.overview:
Dreadbane is a title in the Borderlands. It is given to a person who has slain a Myrddraal. It does not matter whether the Myrddraal is slain in single combat or if it had previously been wounded.

The title refers, presumably, to those that defeat a Myrddraal without the aid of the One Power, which would not be difficult for any channeler of at least middling strength.

Drowned Lands.name: Drowned Lands
Drowned Lands.overview:
The Drowned Lands is a region extending from the end of the Spine of the World to the Bay of Remara and Mayene. It is mainly impassable swamp, with little to no open channels of water. In the Drowned Lands, any expanse of dry land more than a hundred paces wide is considered huge. Passage through the Drowned Lands to reach the Aiel Waste does exist, but is almost impossible to survive, as the waterless Termool stands between the two locations.

The Drowned Lands hold a number of fascinating and strange species of animals, such as many brightly colored birds, nedar, which is essentially a tusked water-pig, a type of giant rat called a soetam, and the swamp cat, which loves to swim unlike its land-bound cousin. It also serves as a home for the water lizard, a dangerous swimmer twenty feet long with sharp teeth and powerful jaws.

Although the creatures of the Drowned Lands can be fascinating to see, the expanse also holds a number of extremely dangerous and venomous types of animals. Several varieties of snakes can easily kill a person, and there exist water-lizards, which can grow up to twenty feet in length and hold a set of very powerful jaws.

Duadhe Mahdi'in.name: Duadhe Mahdi'in
Duadhe Mahdi'in.overview: The Duadhe Mahdi'in is an Aiel warrior society whose name means "Water Seekers" in the Old Tongue.

Dueling blades.name: Dueling blades
Dueling blades.overview: Dueling blades were used in a game called sha'je, a violent dueling contest popular during the Collapse, when the Dark One 's influence awakened the darker side of human nature and caused society to degenerate. The participants used twin blades, the right called aran'gar, the left named osan'gar. In the years immediately preceding the final collapse into war, murder, rape, and even torture became regular parts of many spectator sports. This game was particularly vicious, as both blades were coated with a slow poison, so that even the victor seldom survived. Because of this fact, the game is thought to have been started or perpetuated by Friends of the Dark.

Dumai's Wells (place).name: Dumai's Wells (place)
Dumai's Wells (place).overview: Dumai's Wells is a watering hole of little note most known for the Battle of Dumai's Wells that took place there in the last days of 999 NE.

Duster.name: Duster
Duster.overview: Duster is the name of Banner-General Tylee Khirgan 's warhorse.

Each Castle.name: Each Castle
Each Castle.overview: Each Castle is a book that Rand al'Thor remembers Min Farshaw reading as he dreams himself into a meeting with Moridin. The book is a biography.

Easing the Badger.name: Easing the Badger
Easing the Badger.overview: Easing the Badger is an inn in Illian run by Nieda Sidoro, one of the Blue Ajah 's eyes and ears. Moirane, Lan, Perrin, Loial, and Faile stop there as they are trying to catch up with Rand. A group of Gray Men try to kill Perrin in the common room, but he smells them in time to warn the others. After the attack and Moiraine's discovery that one of the Forsaken rules Illian, they leave early after only a few hours of sleep.

Easing the Badger (inn).name: Easing the Badger (inn)
Easing the Badger (inn).overview:
For the chapter in The Dragon Reborn , see Easing the Badger .

Easing the Badger is an inn in Illian. It is owned by Nieda Sidoro, with her nephew, Bili, working there as a bouncer.

Ebou Dar.name: Ebou Dar
Ebou Dar.overview: Ebou Dar is the capital city of Altara, located on the southern coast, straddling the River Eldar. The city is built around a large bay, with the river dividing it in two. One side contains the palaces, homes, and shops of the upper and middle classes, the other, known as the Rahad, is the home of the lower classes in Ebou Dari society.

Echoes of His Dynasty.name: Echoes of His Dynasty
Echoes of His Dynasty.overview: Echoes of His Dynasty is a book that Cadsuane was reading.

Eel Among the Lily Pads.name: Eel Among the Lily Pads
Eel Among the Lily Pads.overview: Eel Among the Lily Pads is a sword form. Other than the name, nothing is known about it. Either Galadedrid Damodred or Eamon Valda used this form during their fight. Leaf on the Breeze was used to counter it.

Egwene al'Vere's Council.name: Egwene al'Vere's Council
Egwene al'Vere's Council.overview:
Egwene al'Vere 's Council was set up so that she could be advised by a single sister from each of the six Ajahs among the Rebel Aes Sedai.

The bulk of it was made up of the Salidar Six, minus Sheriam Bayanar who was already Egwene's Keeper of the Chronicles. The sixth member of the council was Nisao Dachen, who had also sworn an oath of allegiance to Egwene. She used the oaths they had sworn to her to force them to get themselves chosen as the representative of their respective Ajahs. This was no easy task for some of them, but they managed to do it. This meant that she was surrounded with advisors that she felt she could trust - as much as you can trust any Aes Sedai, at least.

Curiously, the Council closely resembles the "seven women closely advising" the very first Amyrlin Seat, Elisane Tishar, the first Ajah Heads. It has been speculated that several on the Council were Ajah Heads - Anaiya of the Blue, Myrelle of the Green, Carlinya of the White and Morvrin among the Brown - and some of them truly proved to be, or showed strong evidence to be. In an eerie way, Elisane's council marked the beginning of an Age - and Egwene's council may be a signal of the coming end of an Age.

Eharon.name: Eharon
Eharon.overview: Eharon was one of the Ten Nations that arose after the Breaking of the World and collapsed after the Trolloc Wars.

Eharoni High Prince.name: Eharoni High Prince
Eharoni High Prince.overview: Eharoni High Prince is one of the title given to the rulers or high nobility in the former kingdom of Eharon.

Eianrod.name: Eianrod
Eianrod.overview: Eianrod is a town in Cairhien. The town was abandoned during a civil war caused by King Galldrian Riatin 's assassination.

Eighty and One.name: Eighty and One
Eighty and One.overview:
The Eighty and One is a group formed by Demandred during the War of Power.

Not much is known about the Eighty and One, although Rand al'Thor possibly alludes that it was a counter to Lews Therin Telamon 's Hundred Companions. Demandred formed this group right before attacking Lews Therin and killing Tellindal Tirraso.

Likely the group was the name for Demandred's personal army, as its known that the Forsaken were not solely united in anything other than the goal of freeing the Dark One and did fight amongst themselves jockeying for power.

Elaida a'Roihan's White Tower.name: Elaida a'Roihan's White Tower
Elaida a'Roihan's White Tower.overview: Elaida a'Roihan's White Tower details the state of the White Tower during Elaida do Avriny a'Roihan 's reign as Amyrlin Seat.

Elan Dapor.name: Elan Dapor
Elan Dapor.overview: Elan Dapor was a nation of the Free Years. It was founded after the end of the Trolloc Wars and rose from the ruins of Safer and parts of Aelgar. It was later conquered by the false Dragon Guaire Amalasan in FY 940 and was then annexed by the Empire of Artur Hawkwing. Its territory currently resides within the borders of the modern nation of Tarabon and part of the southernmost reaches of the Almoth Plain.

Eldar.name: Eldar
Eldar.overview: The River Eldar starts in the Mountains of Mist and flows in a southerly direction through Ghealdan and Altara. It forms the northern borders of Amadicia, Ghealdan and Altara and empties into the Sea of Storms. It is joined by the River Boern at Boannda.

Elder (Kin).name: Elder (Kin)
Elder (Kin).overview: Elders are the thirteen oldest Kinswomen in Ebou Dar and comprise their Knitting Circle. That group is led by the oldest of them, who holds the title of Eldest.

Elder (Ogier).name: Elder (Ogier)
Elder (Ogier).overview: Elders are the leaders of Ogier society. They may be male or female and are generally old by even Ogier standards. The highest and oldest of the Elders is known as the Eldest. Eldest is not a singular title, and presumably every stedding has an Eldest.

Eldone Market.name: Eldone Market
Eldone Market.overview: Eldone Market is a village near Tar Valon on the eastern side of (The Alindrelle Erinin ). Whitecloaks tried to occupy the city after Falme but the Tower Guard made them leave.

Eldrene's Veil.name: Eldrene's Veil
Eldrene's Veil.overview: Eldrene's Veil is a waterfall formed by the Tarendrelle River as it flows out of the Mountains of Mist.

Elmora.name: Elmora
Elmora.overview: Elmora is one of the major towns of Tarabon. It is halfway on the road between Tanchico and Amador and on a major trade route.

Elsalam.name: Elsalam
Elsalam.overview: Elsalam was a kingdom of the Free Years. It was founded after the end of the Trolloc Wars, and was established on the former territory of Aramaelle. It was later absorbed by the growing might of Artur Hawkwing's Empire. Elsalam was one of the Borderlands in its day and also a militarily strong nation. The lands it once held are now controlled by Kandor and the western half of Arafel, as well as lands to the south that are now wilderness.

Elwin.name: Elwin
Elwin.overview: Elwin was a Da'shain Aiel boy, one of the five children of Adan and Siedre.

Emar Dal.name: Emar Dal
Emar Dal.overview:
Emar Dal was one of the great cities during the Age of Legends, built as a metropolis of beauty of wonder.

The city was destroyed during either the War of Power or the Breaking of the World.

Emela.name: Emela
Emela.overview: Emela is the name of the doll given by a very young princess Tuon to Furyk Karede as a sign of gratitude for saving her life.

Emond's Field.name: Emond's Field
Emond's Field.overview: Emond's Field is a village of farmers and craftsmen centrally located in the Two Rivers district of western Andor.

Emptiness.name: Emptiness
Emptiness.overview: Emptiness is a sword form. Other than the name, nothing is known about it.

Erinin.name: Erinin
Erinin.overview:
The River Erinin is one of the major rivers of the Westlands. It rises in the Spine of the World and flows westwards to form the southern borders of both Shienar and Arafel. In Shienar the river is about four days ride south of Fal Dara. It is only about sixty paces wide there, with a small village built on its banks and a ferry for crossing.

It flows south from Arafel and is joined by the River Antaeo. It continues southwards until it reaches the island and city of Tar Valon, where it splits in two, with the western branch named the Alindrelle Erinin and the eastern branch named the Osendrelle Erinin. The river reforms south of the island and continues to flow south, where it forms the western border of Cairhien and the eastern border of Andor. The river flows between the Andoran port town of Aringill and the Cairhienin village of Maerone. The River Luan also flows into the Erinin shortly after it meets the Cairhienin border.

South of Cairhien, the river is joined by another major tributary, the River Iralell, before it reaches the borders of Tear. Just south of the capital, the river breaks up in a maze-like delta called the Fingers of the Dragon before finally reaching the Sea of Storms.

Esandara.name: Esandara
Esandara.overview: Esandara was a kingdom of the Free Years. It was founded after the end of the Trolloc Wars, and was established on the former territory of Essenia. It was later absorbed by the growing might of Artur Hawkwing's Empire. The lands it once held are now mostly wilderness, although parts of Illian and Andor may have been within its borders.

Essenia.name: Essenia
Essenia.overview: Essenia was one of the Ten Nations. It arose after the Breaking of the World and fell in the aftermath of the Trolloc Wars. Essenia was famous for its philosophers and seats of learning.

Ever Victorious Army.name: Ever Victorious Army
Ever Victorious Army.overview: The Ever Victorious Army is the name given to the Seanchan army because it has never been defeated. While it has lost battles, it is by description ever adapting and switches strategies and methods so that the next time it confronts the enemy, they'll be sure to win.

Eye of the World.name: Eye of the World
Eye of the World.overview: The Eye of the World is an oval-shaped artificial pool located inside a hill in the Blight. It was created by a hundred male and female Aes Sedai after the Dark One tainted saidin. They worked together using both saidin and saidar to fill it with the essence of cleansed, pure saidin, enough to mend the seal on the Dark One's prison or break it open completely. Knowing that they will die during the process, they asked Someshta, the last living Nym, to guard it. Moiraine explains that many in Tar Valon have attempted to find a way to use the Power in the Eye, but they failed as it is untouchable for any woman.

Eyes-and-ears.name: Eyes-and-ears
Eyes-and-ears.overview:
Eyes-and-ears is a term used loosely to describe a network of spies, or an individual informant loyal to a group or individual. Eyes-and-ears is a term most commonly used by the White Tower, though other organizations and rulers employ eyes-and-ears as well. Eyes-and-ears are also sometimes known in those circles simply as spy networks, though the term is interchangeable.

Each Ajah has their own eyes-and-ears, and individual Aes Sedai are also known to maintain eyes-and-ears loyal to themselves. Many believe that the White Ajah has no formal network of its own, but this was proven false by the Wheel of Time Companion - as even the Whites wanted to manipulate world events logically. In theory, all intelligence gathered by the Ajah's eyes-and-ears should be given to the Amyrlin Seat, but this is rarely the case.

When Siuan Sanche was deposed and stilled, she maintained control of the Amyrlin's eyes-and-ears, and was given a position of authority with the Rebel Aes Sedai. She had also previously been the head of the eyes-and-ears for the Blue Ajah - the largest network of any of the Ajahs. This title is now held by Aeldene Stonebridge.

Leane Sharif, as Keeper of the Chronicles, also maintained her own eyes-and-ears within Tar Valon.

Fal Dara.name: Fal Dara
Fal Dara.overview:
For the chapter in The Eye of the World by the same name, see Fal Dara .

Fal Dara is the northernmost city in Shienar, close to the Blightborder, and part of the final line of defense between it and the cities and farmsteads farther south. The city has several gates, the East Gate in the east wall, the King's Gate in the south wall and the Malkier Gate in the north wall. Its wall is studded with towers and encloses shops, inns, and homes around the central fortress with farms outside the wall. Most of the houses within and without the walls have sharp peaked wooden shingled roofs that run almost to the ground. This angled design prevents the damaging buildup of snow and ice during the long winter.

As with many cities of the Borderlands, the center of the city is dominated by a fortress or keep, and all streets and alleys are torchlit at night to prevent incursions from Fades. At the center of Fal Dara a dry moat, deep and wide with sharp spikes embedded in the bottom, and a second defensive wall studded with more towers, protect the inner keep, a massive fortress of stone built atop the highest point of the hill. The keep is the home of the Lord of Fal Dara, Agelmar Jagad, as well as his family, retainers, warriors, and servants. His fortress, as well as the walls that protect it and the town around it, are built for strength rather than beauty, yet there is a severe elegance in the stark lines of each wall and beauty in the massive stones. Its sign is the Black Hawk.

It was known as Mafal Dadaranell in the days before the Trolloc Wars, capital of Aramaelle, one of the Ten Nations. It was Ogier-built, consisting of grand towers, graceful arching buildings, and intricate palaces joined by wide avenues. Yet nothing was strong enough to hold back the waves of Shadowspawn flooding from the Blight. When the Trolloc Wars finally ended, Mafal Dadaranell was gone, razed to the bare earth. Those who survived decided to build another city on the site of the old one, but the Ogier stonemasons were gone. Rather than make a poor imitation, they replaced its elaborate design with simplicity.

In 998 NE, the then Amyrlin Seat, Siuan Sanche visited the city with an escort of no less than fourteen Aes Sedai, among them Anaiya, Maigan, Alanna Mosvani, Liandrin, Carlinya, Verin Mathwin and Serafelle.

- Though not all Shienaran towns and fortresses have such interesting histories, all are linked more strongly by their shared threat than by their allegiance to the nation. Ankor Dail holds the eastern marches and guards the Spine of the World. Other fortresses such as Mos Shirare, Fal Sion, and Camron Caan each provide an integral part of the defense of Shienar, and each has its own stories, and its own heroes.

Fal Eisen.name: Fal Eisen
Fal Eisen.overview: Fal Eisen is a city-fortress in Shienar. Kayen Yokata is the Lord of Fal Eisen.

Fal Moran.name: Fal Moran
Fal Moran.overview:
Fal Moran is the capital city of Shienar.

The Royal Palace of Shienar is in the city of Fal Moran. It is the home of Easar Togita, King of Shienar.

Prior to the Battle of Tarwin's Gap, Agelmar Jagad arranged for the people of Fal Dara to be moved to the capital in case the battle was lost.

Fal Sion.name: Fal Sion
Fal Sion.overview:
Fal Sion is a city-fortress in Shienar.

Fal Sion sends forces with other Shienarans to fight the Trolloc army at Tarwin's Gap.

Fall of Caemlyn.name: Fall of Caemlyn
Fall of Caemlyn.overview: The Fall of Caemlyn was the first in a series of battles fought as the initial conflict of the Last Battle between various groups representing the Light and the Shadow.

Fall of Malkier.name: Fall of Malkier
Fall of Malkier.overview:
The Fall of Malkier was a conflict in 955 NE in which Malkier, having endured against the Shadow for almost a thousand years, was overrun by a Shadowspawn army and subsequently absorbed by the Blight.

Malkier had been weakened after Breyan Mandragoran had plotted a coup against al'Akir Mandragoran. The coup failed, but in the process the Blightborder fortresses were almost stripped bare, enabling an army of Shadowspawn to overrun the country. A final battle was fought at Herot's Crossing, in which the king and queen of Malkier were slain.

Malkier fell before other countries had time to intervene, and while the armies of Shienar, Arafel and Kandor eventually stopped the invasion at the Stair of Jehaan, they did not push the Shadowspawn back all the way.

Falling Shale.name: Falling Shale
Falling Shale.overview: Falling Shale is one of Min 's books. It is a history.

Falme.name: Falme
Falme.overview:
For the chapter in The Great Hunt called "Falme", see The Great Hunt/Chapter 42 . A map of Falme.

Falme is the largest town on Toman Head, with a population of around twenty-five thousand citizens. Residents of Falme are called "Falmen".

Fancloth.name: Fancloth
Fancloth.overview: Fancloth is a synthetic fabric that duplicates its surroundings for a total camouflage effect. Warders ' cloaks are made of fancloth. It is manufactured with a specific ter'angreal in the White Tower. In the Age of Legends fancloth was considered stylish. During the War of Power soldiers wore it. " The Watcher " covers himself completely with fancloth so he cannot be seen.

Far Aldazar Din.name: Far Aldazar Din
Far Aldazar Din.overview: The Far Aldazar Din is an Aiel warrior society. The name means "Brothers of the Eagle" in the Old Tongue.

Far Dareis Mai.name: Far Dareis Mai
Far Dareis Mai.overview: Far Dareis Mai, the Maidens of the Spear, is an Aiel warrior society that only accepts women, as opposed to other all-male Aiel societies.

Far Madding.name: Far Madding
Far Madding.overview: Far Madding is an independent city-state in the southeastern part of the Westlands on the Plains of Maredo. It is situated on an island in the midst of a lake, and is connected to the mainland by three bridges. At a junction of major overland trade routes, Far Madding is an important commercial center. It is the only known significant human settlement where channellers are unable to access or even sense the presence of the True Source.

Far Madding Gate.name: Far Madding Gate
Far Madding Gate.overview: The Far Madding Gate is the southern gate at the city of Caemlyn. The gate leads south to the Far Madding Road. Arymilla 's main force attacks the Far Madding Gate to the New City.

Farashelle.name: Farashelle
Farashelle.overview: Farashelle was a kingdom of the Free Years. It arose from the ruins of Manetheren after the Trolloc Wars. During the War of the Hundred Years the region became independent, although contested by many nobles and factions. It was eventually conquered by Andor and became the westernmost part of that kingdom. The region known as the Two Rivers was controlled by Farashelle at this time.

Farm.name: Farm
Farm.overview:
The farm is a large piece of land owned by the Kin and used as a waypoint for traveling Kin passing through Ebou Dar. For two hundred miles around, it has a reputation for being a women's retreat, rather than what it secretly is—where the Kin will stay to ensure their numbers in nearby Ebou Dar stay unnoticeably low.

It is located several miles from the city in a broad hollow among three hills. Structures include a dozen white-plastered, flat-roofed buildings in addition to four large barns built in one of the hills. The farm also boasts olive groves to the north and east of the main establishment. It keeps a sharp watch for visitors, to ensure its privacy and secrecy.

Though it is a serene place, it still manifests a slow bustle among the over 100 residents; all women—no men or children allowed. It could be mistaken for a small village except for the missing men and children. Noblewomen and commoners mix on its grounds, but there seems to be an air of equality amongst them as all women are expected to chip in and accomplish the chores required to keep the place running.

Fateful Concord.name: Fateful Concord
Fateful Concord.overview: The Fateful Concord was an agreement between Latra Posae Decume and the female Aes Sedai with great power to stand opposed to Lews Therin Telamon 's plan to reseal the Bore, and instead support a plan to defeat the Shadow with the Choedan Kal and to erect a temporary barrier around the Bore. As a result, no female Aes Sedai joined Lews Therin and the Hundred Companions when they marched on Shayol Ghul. Rand Al'Thor speculated that if both halves of the True Source had been used to make the Seal, the taint on the male half might not have occurred.

Favlend Mountain.name: Favlend Mountain
Favlend Mountain.overview: Favlend Mountain is part of the foothills northeast of the Damona Mountains, in Murandy. It can be confused with some of the nearby hills, either Mount Sardlen or Blinder's Peak.

Fearless.name: Fearless
Fearless.overview: The Fearless is a Seanchan ship, captained by Egeanin Tamarath.

Feast of Abram.name: Feast of Abram
Feast of Abram.overview:
The Feast of Abram occurs on the ninth day of Jumara. The holiday honors travelers and visitors. Traditionally honeycake is served into which prizes have been baked.

The Feast is celebrated in Tarabon, Amadicia, Ghealdan, Andor, Altara, Murandy, Illian, Tear, and Cairhien. In Tear, Illian, and the southern half of Altara, the time between the Feast of Abram and the Feast of Fools is considered the most propitious for a wedding.

Feast of All Souls Salvation.name: Feast of All Souls Salvation
Feast of All Souls Salvation.overview: The Feast of All Souls Salvation, also called All Souls Day, is celebrated once every ten years at the autumn equinox. It is not part of any month.

Feast of Embers.name: Feast of Embers
Feast of Embers.overview:
Feast of Embers occurs on the 20th day of Taisham.

It is celebrated in Ebou Dar.

Feast of Fools.name: Feast of Fools
Feast of Fools.overview:
Feast of Fools is celebrated during the month of Tammaz (in Arad Doman and the Borderlands ) and Shaldine (everywhere else), the exact day varying according to locality. A day in which all order of rank is flip-flopped: people of high status perform lowly tasks, while the low do no work and give orders to their usual superiors. In many villages and towns the most foolish person is given a lofty but foolish title, and for that one day everyone has to obey whatever orders the chosen one gives. Celebrations for this holiday can include wearing of masks, pranks, and the exchange of sweets and small pastries.

Alternate names for this holiday include:

- Foolday - in Two Rivers and Baerlon
- Festival of Unreason - in Saldaea
- Festival of Fools - in Kandor

In Tear, Illian, and the southern half of Altara, the time between the Feast of Abram and the Feast of Fools is considered the most propitious for a wedding.

Feast of Freia.name: Feast of Freia
Feast of Freia.overview:
Feast of Freia occurs on the twenty-first day of Adar.

It is celebrated in Illian, Arad Doman, Ghealdan, Tarabon, and parts of Altara and Murandy.

Feast of Lights.name: Feast of Lights
Feast of Lights.overview: Feast of Lights is a two day holiday that occurs on the last day of the old year (the 28th of Danu ) and the first day of the new year ( the 1st of Taisham.) Danu 28th is the winter solstice, the shortest day of the year.

Feast of Maia.name: Feast of Maia
Feast of Maia.overview:
The Feast of Maia occurs on the sixth day of Amadaine. (The companion says ninth day of Amadaine, the 6th comes from the Guide)

It is celebrated in Andor, Ghealdan, Altara, Murandy, and in Illian.

Feast of Neman.name: Feast of Neman
Feast of Neman.overview:
Feast of Neman occurs on the ninth day of Adar.

It is celebrated in Andor, Cairhien, Tear, and in the Borderlands.

Feast of Thanksgiving.name: Feast of Thanksgiving
Feast of Thanksgiving.overview:
The Feast of Thanksgiving is celebrated once every four years at the spring equinox.

Unlike most holidays and feastdays, there is either little or no variation in celebrating this feastday between nations, and it is celebrated across the entire Westlands.

Feast of the Half Moon.name: Feast of the Half Moon
Feast of the Half Moon.overview:
Feast of the Half Moon occurs on the 23rd day of Taisham.

It is celebrated in Ebou Dar.

Feather (wolf).name: Feather (wolf)
Feather (wolf).overview: Feather is a young wolf who is the mate of Leafhunter and part of her pack.

Feathers in the Wind.name: Feathers in the Wind
Feathers in the Wind.overview: Feathers in the Wind is a sword form. Other than the name, nothing is known about it.

February.name: February
February.overview: February is the second month in the Gregorian calendar. It occurs in Wheel of Time world during Jumara 14 to Saban 13.

Fellowship of Alms.name: Fellowship of Alms
Fellowship of Alms.overview:
The Fellowship of Alms is one of the guilds which proliferate in Altara but particularly in the city of Ebou Dar.

All beggars in the city are required to maintain membership in the brotherhood and to wear a small brass ring signifying their continued membership and continuity of their dues. They guard thier trade most jealously, often beating or even killing off those not members of the fellowship.

Fergansea.name: Fergansea
Fergansea.overview: Fergansea was a nation of the Free Years. It was founded after the Trolloc Wars, located in the territory formerly belonging to Essenia. During the War of the Hundred Years its former territories were split between three kingdoms, Illian, Maredo, and Tear.

Festival of Birds.name: Festival of Birds
Festival of Birds.overview:
For the chapter in A Crown of Swords called "The Festival of Birds", see A Crown of Swords/Chapter 29 .

Festival of Birds is celebrated on the eighteenth day of Taisham, observed primarily in Ebou Dar.

The holiday entails men, women, and children wearing feathers. Commonly, feathered masks are worn, shaped into a bird such as an owl, eagle, hawk, wren, or a fanciful feathered creature that represents "no bird ever seen by human eyes." Men and women also wear feathered costumes or feathers sewn into their clothes or coats. Usually wealth takes a factor in how elaborate one's mask is and how revealing their costumes are. Poorer folk usually adorn their hair with a few feathers, perhaps from pigeons gathered on the pavement for the poorest, while the more wealthy wear elaborate masks and feathery - and often scandalously revealing - costumes.

Celebrations usually take place indoors for the most part, since the festival occurs while the weather is usually "cold enough to keep people from running around outdoors all but unclothed." Extravagantly costumed people pose, showing off great plumes, crests, and long colorful wings inside guild halls and private palaces and homes. However, when weather permits it, the festivities joyously pour into the streets. Parades of wagons pull platforms, called settings, upon which those most ornate, feathered costumes are displayed. Tumblers, jugglers, and musicians wearing feather sewn clothes or in their hair play at every street corner throughout the day time.

Another tradition on this day is giving money, done with jubilant tossing of coins amidst shouting and laughter or simply folding bills. The money may be directed at the appreciated costumed display or toward those in need: raggedly dressed children and beggars.

As provocative as the scarcely-covering costumes are during the day, it is said that when the sunlight fades, so do the inhibitions.

Festival of Lanterns.name: Festival of Lanterns
Festival of Lanterns.overview:
Festival of Lanterns occurs on the first day of Choren.

On this day, paper lanterns, often brightly colored and fancifully shaped, are hung everywhere in places such as windows or trees.

Celebrated in Arad Doman, Tarabon, Amadicia, Ghealdan, Altara, Murandy, and Illian.

Feverbane.name: Feverbane
Feverbane.overview: Feverbane is an herb that can be found in the Two Rivers region. It is a remedy for fever.

Field of Bekkar.name: Field of Bekkar
Field of Bekkar.overview: The Field of Bekkar - which some historical records have refered to as the Field of Blood - was the site of a battle between the army of Manetheren and forces of the Shadow during the middle years of the Trolloc Wars. It occurred circa 1200 AB and resulted in a victory for the forces of Light.

Fifth.name: Fifth
Fifth.overview:
The Fifth is a custom among the Aiel. It states that after they conquer a place, they are entitled to take a fifth of all that the conquered hold has, save food.

In Caemlyn, Tear, and various other cities, the Aiel have been refused the right of the fifth by Rand al'Thor, their prophesied Car'a'carn, for the reason that he cannot afford for the Aiel to be seen as enemies, or for the areas to be weakened in the times of approaching war.

Fifth Treaty of Falme.name: Fifth Treaty of Falme
Fifth Treaty of Falme.overview: The Fifty Treaty of Falme was a short-lived peace treaty between Arad Doman and Tarabon. It was brokered with the help of Merana Ambrey in 961 NE. The treaty concerned the land known as Almoth Plain but was broken shortly after it was signed. Merana considers it her only real failure as an Aes Sedai of the Gray Ajah.

Fingers of the Dragon.name: Fingers of the Dragon
Fingers of the Dragon.overview:
