Ogier stonework is known for its organic nature, often appearing to have been grown like plants. However, it is understood to be a skill they acquired during the Breaking, and is of lesser importance than their first love, forestry. They love the trees of their stedding, and grew groves near the cities they built to remind them of their home. Even their written language resembles growing leaves and vines.

See also the List of Ogier mentioned (or active) in the storyline.

Ogier grove.name: Ogier grove
Ogier grove.overview: Ogier groves are groups of trees that were planted after the Breaking of the World. They are located near places Ogier live or worked, particularly stedding and Ogier built cities such as Caemlyn, Tar Valon, and Manetheren. They were grown to add beauty to the world and to remind Ogier working in human cities of the stedding. Ogier sometimes use the ones in their stedding as public meeting places. Many waygates are located near places where groves once stood. The Ogier Groves are said to contain every type of tree the Ogier could coax to grow in a given area.

Oilfish.name: Oilfish
Oilfish.overview: A fish that produces valuable oil, found in shoals off Mayene. The oil from these fish was the major competor for olive oil both in cooking and in lamps. Mayeners knew the location of the oilfish shoals, which no one else did.

Old Blood.name: Old Blood
Old Blood.overview: The Old Blood is a phenomena in which traits from one's heritage manifest themselves in oneself. It is frequently used to explain certain characteristics exhibited by the people of the Two Rivers.

Old Road.name: Old Road
Old Road.overview: The Old Road is a road located in the Two Rivers that stretches between Emond's Field and Deven Ride.

Old Tongue.name: Old Tongue
Old Tongue.overview:
The Old Tongue is a now-dead language, once common parlance in the Age of Legends, but now spoken only by scholars and certain nobles, and not perfectly by either of those. Its structure and meaning are shaded so that a single phrase can have many different meanings, depending on context. Modern dialects have evolved from the Old Tongue (some might say, 'degenerated'), such that a farmer who hears a word of the Old Tongue will think that it sounds familiar, and such that any native speaker of the Old Tongue can decipher the New.

Also see List of Old Tongue words.

Old Tongue numbers.name: Old Tongue numbers
Old Tongue numbers.overview:
Also see List of Old Tongue words for all known Old Tongue words and phrases.

This page consists of a list of numbers in the Old Tongue that is expanded from and using the rules described in The Wheel of Time Companion. The key features are as follows:

- Numerical stem : Every number has a core part that reresents a value.
- Concrete vs abstract : For numbers under 20, the suffix "- yat " is appended to the numerical stem to represent objects that are concrete/material ( e.g. , apples, oranges), while the suffix "- ye " is appended to represent abstract/immaterial objects ( e.g. , ideas, arguments, propositions).
- Teen suffix : For the numbers from 11 to 19, the suffix "- pi " is appended to the stem. Note that this includes 11 and 12, which are not considered "teens" in English.
- Tens, hundreds, and thousands suffixes : Suffixes can be added to describe larger quantities. The suffixes for ten, hundreds and thousands are "- shi ," "- deshi ," and "- tuhat ," respectively. Note that the word for one hundred, " deshi ," is a compound of the stem for ten, " des ," and the suffix for tens, "- shi ".
- Ordinal numbers : Ordinal numbers ( e.g. , "first," "second," "third," etc.) are formed by appending the suffix "- yn " to the numerical stem.

The following tables give a selection of numbers. There are no canon versions of the larger numbers, as, though the above rules are enumerated in the Companion, the order in which to apply said rules is not described. The following conventions have been applied to the numbers in the tables below:

- Numbers read from left to right in descending order ( i.e ., they're written as "forty-one," not "one-and-forty"- in the Old Tongue, " min'shi'ko," not " ko'min'shi ").
- Ordinal number suffixes are added to the integer of the smallest order of magnitude ( i.e ., "forty-first," not "fortieth-one" - in the Old Tongue, " min'shi'koyn," not " min'shiyn'ko ").
- We use apostrophes to seperate the suffix(es) from the numerical stem and, if applicable, from each other ( i.e. , " min'shi'ko ," not " minshiko/min'shiko/minsh'ko "); ordinal numbers are an exception (see below).
- We also use an apostrophe with the "- pi " suffix used for the numbers from 11 to 19.
- Using the canon spelling of koyn, "first", as an exemplar, we do not use an apostrophe to seperate the "- yn " suffix for ordinal numbers, with the exception of "- shi'yn " in order to seperate the phonemes (" -shyn " might be an alternative). For the first 19 numbers, we have the two suffixes to be applied for concrete/abstract distinctions.

For higher numbers:

These rules can be combined to create any number whatsoever.

Oman Dashar.name: Oman Dashar
Oman Dashar.overview: Oman Dashar was a kingdom of the Free Years. It was founded after the end of the Trolloc Wars, and was established on parts of the former territories of Jaramide and Safer. It was later absorbed by the growing might of Artur Hawkwing's Empire. The lands it once held are now controlled by Arad Doman.

Oosquai.name: Oosquai
Oosquai.overview:
Oosquai is a particularly potent alcoholic drink made and consumed by the Aiel. Made from zemai, it looks "like faintly brown-tinged water, tasted almost like it — and was stronger than double-distilled brandy" according to Rand al'Thor.

The sharing of oosquai with another person is said to be a great act of friendship between warriors. For example, Aiel under Rand share oosquai with various westlanders in the aftermath of the Second Battle of Cairhien.

Aviendha, Min Farshaw, and Birgitte Silverbow all drink a heavy amount of oosquai while Rand and Elayne are making love for the first time in order to numb the sensations they are feeling through their bonds to either of the individuals.

Origins of the Wheel of Time.name: Origins of the Wheel of Time
Origins of the Wheel of Time.overview:
This article is about the book. For the animated shorts, see The Wheel of Time Origins ↗ .

Origins of the Wheel of Time: The Legends and Mythologies that Inspired Robert Jordan is an new non-fiction book by Michael Livingston, with a foreword from Harriet McDougal. The book was released on November 8, 2022.

The book focuses on the history of the writing process of The Wheel of Time, as well as the real-world inspirations for the series.

Osenrein.name: Osenrein
Osenrein.overview:
Osenrein is a satellite village of Tar Valon, on the eastern bank of the river Erinin, were one of the six bridges of the city connects the island to the continent.

Because Tar Valon is often the target of attacks and sieges, Osenrein has been a victim of many burnings over the years.

Ostin Falls.name: Ostin Falls
Ostin Falls.overview: Ostin Falls is a trading town on the border of Toman Head and Almoth Plain. It is a fairly large town, with a population of roughly five hundred people. Its mayor is Bretton Kilvar.

Paaran Disen.name: Paaran Disen
Paaran Disen.overview:
Paaran Disen was the greatest city in the Age of Legends, considered to be the "crown jewel" of all the cities, and the location of the Hall of Servants. It was also the capital city and seat of government. Lews Therin defeated Ishamael at the Gates of Paaran Disen. Like its slightly smaller companion city, M'Jinn, Paaran Disen was technologically advanced, with skyscrapers glittering like precious jewels in the sky. Nym and Ogier were known to have sung trees into being throughout the city. The most striking building in Paaran Disen is said to have been the Hall of Servants, the home for the governing Aes Sedai, which comprised both male and female channelers in that Age.

This beautiful city was presumably destroyed in the Breaking of the World, leaving little to nothing of its one-time grandeur.

It is explained through the Seventh vision of Rand al'Thor in the Glass ter'angreal of Rhuidean, how Jonai, a Da'shain Aiel was given orders to lead the Aiel to safety by Solinda Sedai, in the Hall of Servants. She says "I want you far from Paaren Disen by tomorrow." So Aiel start their wandering from Paaran Disen.

Pact of the Griffin.name: Pact of the Griffin
Pact of the Griffin.overview:
The Pact of the Griffin was an alliance of nations that existed in the Fourth Age as envisioned by Aviendha. It was comprised of Andor, the Two Rivers, Mayene, Ghealdan, and Saldaea.

Its symbol was a creature with the head of a lion (Andor), the body of a wolf ( Perrin Aybara and the Two Rivers), and the wings of a hawk (Mayene), with three stars above (Ghealdan) and three fish below (Saldaea).

Curiously in this symbol is not comprised the rising sun of Cairhien which is another kingdom expected to be part of this alliance. This may portend that in the fourth age Cairhien is politically merged with Andor.

Paerish Swar.name: Paerish Swar
Paerish Swar.overview: Paedish Swar or "The Darkwood" is a forbidding, large forest on the eastern edge of Almoth Plain, and marks the edge of that territory. The Darkwood blocks easy access to Lake Somal to the east. It is unknown if the Darkwood is inhabited, but forces of Dragonsworn did operate in this region during their war with both Tarabon and Arad Doman. Katar is the nearest large city to this region.

Panarch's Palace.name: Panarch's Palace
Panarch's Palace.overview:
The Panarch's Palace is the palace and home to the Panarch of Tarabon. Inside the Palace there is a Museum collecting many items from the previous Age. One of these artifacts was a Domination Band which was the target of the Forsaken in Tarabon.

The palace was partially destroyed during a skirmish between Elayne and Nynaeve and the Black Ajah with the use of balefire.

Panarch.name: Panarch
Panarch.overview:
Panarch is the title of the female ruler of Tarabon, whereas the male ruler is referred to as the King. The title is not inherited (as is the King's title), but the Panarch is elected by the Assembly of Lords. She wears the Crown of the Tree made of gold trefoil leaves and a stole embroidered with trees.

The Panarch is equal in authority to the King, and is responsible for collecting taxes, customs and duties. She has authority over the Civil Watch and the Panarch's Legion and is in charge of all courts with the exception of the High Court of the King.

Parting the Silk.name: Parting the Silk
Parting the Silk.overview: Parting the Silk is a sword form.

Peaches.name: Peaches
Peaches.overview: Peaches are the same as the fruit known today, with the important exception that they are believed to be poisonous in the Third Age.

Pearman's Lane.name: Pearman's Lane
Pearman's Lane.overview: Pearman's Lane was a road in Caemlyn, the capital city of Andor.

Pecara.name: Pecara
Pecara.overview: Pale, wrinkled nuts found in the Aiel Waste. Possibly like a walnut or pecan. Also defined as a tree having pale, wrinkled fruit.

Piesa.name: Piesa
Piesa.overview: Piesa is a horse owned by Leya.

Pillow friends.name: Pillow friends
Pillow friends.overview:
The term pillow-friends refers to a homosexual relationship between two individuals, most commonly between two women. It is most prevalent in the White Tower.

Novices and Accepted commonly enjoy these relationships as comfort during the hardships of White Tower training, but are viewed as a thing of girlhood and are almost universally abandoned upon gaining the shawl. Some attempt to continue the relationships as Aes Sedai.

This has the equivalent term of heart-friends in Seanchan slang.

Pips.name: Pips
Pips.overview:
Pips is the nondescript brown gelding owned by Matrim Cauthon. He purchased the horse in Tear before traveling with Rand al'Thor and the Aiel to Rhuidean. Mat has some of his father's ability to pick good horses, and chose this one for its deep chest and strong withers. Pips is named after the spots found on dice.

Pips has accompanied Mat throughout his travels. Pips has been to Tear, Rhuidean, the Jangai Pass, Cairhien, Maerone, Salidar, Ebou Dar, various towns and villages throughout southern Altara, Murandy, and Caemlyn.

Pit of Doom.name: Pit of Doom
Pit of Doom.overview:
The Pit of Doom, also spelled Pit of Dhoom, is the area where the Bore in the Dark One 's prison is most easy to detect, as well as being the area where he has most control. This area lies under a mountain in the heart of Shayol Ghul. It is a vast and deep lava-filled cavern with a small ledge above it that leads into the tunnels through the mountain, and the top of it is open to the sky. However, the sky above the Pit is not the same as the sky over Shayol Ghul; clouds of various colors and striations pass overhead at speeds far beyond what any terrestrial wind could produce. Despite the Pit's metaphysical proximity to the Bore, in reality the Pit is no physically closer to the Bore than anywhere else in the world. It is also apparently not the physical location of the Bore's first drilling; Shayol Ghul was a tropical tourist destination during the Age of Legends, whereas the Bore was drilled at the Sharom research station at Collam Daan university.

The Pit is the only place where most people can communicate with the Dark One. Doing so makes one feel pain and ecstasy beyond imagining; it is somewhat like the feeling of the True Power. The Dark One has no physical manifestation that he uses, he simply speaks directly inside the mind of whomever he is contacting with an overwhelmingly powerful telepathic "voice". However, it appears not to be strictly the only place where one can communicate with the Dark One, as Moridin could apparently hear direct commands from the Dark One anywhere in the world. However, he was a unique case due to his gross overuse of the True Power.

Reality is twisted and malleable within the Pit of Doom, most likely due to the Dark One's direct influence. Possibly due to this twisting of reality, a mindtrap can be established here and nowhere else in the world. It is revealed that Rand al'Thor can at least reverse the Dark One's reality tampering here, though the mechanism behind this can only be speculated to be related to his ta'veren nature, unique among even ta'veren individuals as he was also the Dragon Reborn.

Channeling in the Pit of Doom can be sensed by the Dark One. Channeling in the Pit without permission is a sure way to anger him, and death is invariably swift. Additionally, anyone except Moridin who might attempt to channel the True Power in the Pit would evidently burn themselves to a cinder due to the Dark One's metaphysical closeness to the Pit. Why Moridin seems to be able to channel the True Power there is a mystery.

During the Last Battle, the Dark One "hatched" a tiny portion of his being from Shaidar Haran in the Pit, which resulted in an absolutely empty patch of nothingness coming to exist there. This void emptied the Pit of its lava and quenched all of its fires, leaving little more than a pitch black hollow beneath Shayol Ghul.

Plain Chant.name: Plain Chant
Plain Chant.overview:
Plain Chant is often the most common form of story telling as it consists of grand, often exaggerated myths and legends. It is very specifically written to create the most exciting imagery possible and to draw the listener deep into the story. For this reason most plain chant stories are meant to be recited word for word, with little variation even down to tone of voice, speed, rhythm and possibly actions performed (though many of these specifications may vary from story teller to story teller).

Most Plain Chant can be reasonably compared to a form of free verse poetry. Stories are often shorter than High Chant, so they are usually preferred in common rooms where lower class listeners either don't have patience enough to listen to the long, artful (and usually philosophical) stories written in High Chant, or they are called by farms and other duties, causing their amount of listening time to go significantly down.

While bards residing in great halls and palaces typically are drawn to the study and memorization of High Chant, gleemen and the like (bards of the lower classes in a way) naturally focus on Plain Chant. Though gleemen will often memorize several stories in Common Chant for use in casual conversation, Plain Chant stories are memorized and recited more commonly than both High Chant and Common Chant (though it is possible that High Chant may be contained in more books and other written forms).

Plain of Lances.name: Plain of Lances
Plain of Lances.overview: The Plain of Lances is a large plain located to the south of the Blight and spans the borders of Saldaea and Kandor. The two countries use the plain for military exercises.

Plains of Maredo.name: Plains of Maredo
Plains of Maredo.overview:
The Plains of Maredo are a vast plains area between Illian, Tear and Andor. The only city in the Plains of Maredo is Far Madding.

This is where Rand built his army to invade Illian.

Plowman (Constellation).name: Plowman (Constellation)
Plowman (Constellation).overview: One of the constellations seen over the night skies of the Westlands.

Plucking the Low-Hanging Apple.name: Plucking the Low-Hanging Apple
Plucking the Low-Hanging Apple.overview: Plucking the Low-Hanging Apple is a sword form. It is used to cut at the neck, the head being the "low-hanging apple." Eamon Valda used this form at the beginning of his duel with Galadedrid Damodred. Leopard's Caress is often used as a following form to take advantage of the traditional, trained responses to Plucking the Low-Hanging Apple.

Ponderings.name: Ponderings
Ponderings.overview: Ponderings, by Pelateos, is one of Min 's books.

Portal Stone.name: Portal Stone
Portal Stone.overview:
Portal Stones are certain kinds of gateways to different locations and alternative realities within the Pattern. The One Power is needed to activate them, with the same strength level as needed for Travel. This may make them a form of Ter'angreal, although the term is never explicitly used in association with them.

Provided the user knows the meaning of its guiding symbolism, one stone can take the traveller to a stone of another location of the same world or to another stone in a different reality (e.g. to a parallel world of the universe of the Wheel of Time). When used for travelling in this world, the time dimension could be inconsistent.

Lanfear shares with Loial that "There are worlds where it is time rather than distance that changes. Spend a day in one of those, and you might come back to find a year has passed in the real world, or twenty. Or it could be the other way round. This one seems pale to us because it is a weak reflection, a world that had little chance of ever being. Others are almost as likely ours. Those are solid as our world and have people. The same people. You could go to one of them and meet yourself. The Pattern has infinite variation, she says, and every variation that can be, will be."

Poses.name: Poses
Poses.overview: Poses are a set of exercises performed by the da'covale of the Seanchan empire. They are usually performed by ten or twenty da'covale together. Sometimes they are performed by only one da'covale, however.

Power-wrought.name: Power-wrought
Power-wrought.overview: An item is said to be Power-wrought or Power-forged if the One Power was used in its construction. During construction, this is achieved by a process or Talent called Aligning the Matrix in which the One Power is used at an atomic level to strengthen steel or to seamlessly join stone using flows of Earth.

Practice sword.name: Practice sword
Practice sword.overview:
A practice sword is shaped like a true sword but is made of bundled wood lathes and is bound with cloth to reduce impact and the risk of injury.

It is used by young men wanting to learn the sword. The most notable examples are Rand al'Thor when training with Lan Mandragoran and the Warders -in-training and Younglings at the White Tower, including Gawyn Trakand and Galadedrid Damodred.

The practice sword is similar to the real life shinai: a bamboo sword used in the Japanese martial art of Kendo.

Pretty.name: Pretty
Pretty.overview:
Pretties are typically subordinate to their partners in some sense, usually social rank, wealth, or simply in terms of power wielded in the relationship.

When "pretty" is used to describe a relationship, it implies a degree of superficiality and a casual nature. Pretties are typically chosen for their attractiveness and the relationships can be somewhat transactional. Pretties who are not Compulsed are typically lavished with gifts and/or a luxurious lifestyle.

"Pretty" relationships are generally expected to be consensual. However, the narrative focus on exceptional individuals like ta'veren and Forsaken results in most known examples being non-consensual aberrations, such as the coercion used on Mat and the Compulsion used on Morgase Trakand.

The term "pet" is commonly used as a synonym to pretty, usually in reference to those who are coerced or Compelled. Note that "pet" can also refer to relationships that are not in any way physical or romantic (i.e. do not involve pretties), in reference to how dominant one person is over the other.

Prince.name: Prince
Prince.overview: Prince is a nobility title given to many high ranking people in royal families.

Protector of the Land.name: Protector of the Land
Protector of the Land.overview: Protector of the Land is a title of the Kandori monarch. Aside from the generalization of the Borderlands serving as a first line of defense against invasion from the Great Blight, nothing is known about the title. Currently, Ethenielle Kirukon Materasu holds this title.

Protector of the People.name: Protector of the People
Protector of the People.overview: Protector of the People is a title of the Queen of Andor. It is not exactly known how the title came to be part of the royal styling. It may be due to Andor's treatment of the common people being better compared to other nations. Currently, Elayne Trakand holds the title. Her mother, Morgase Trakand held the title when she was queen.

Pujili.name: Pujili
Pujili.overview: Pujili is a region in Seanchan continent. Gamel Loune 's bodyservent Mantual is from Pujili. The people there have a culture somewhat similar to those of the Kaensada Hills.

Qaim.name: Qaim
Qaim.overview: Qaim is a Sea Folk island in the Sea of Storms east of Tremalking and southwest of Ebou Dar.

Qal.name: Qal
Qal.overview: Qal was a city which during the Age of Legends fell into the Shadow. It is known that sha'je duels were popular there.

Qirat.name: Qirat
Qirat.overview:
Qirat is the fifth largest city in Seanchan.

The city is located at the tip of a large peninsula at the north of the continent.

Quarry Road.name: Quarry Road
Quarry Road.overview: The Quarry Road is a rock-strewn track that lies near Emond's Field in the Two Rivers region. It appears as a weedy stretch bare of trees with overgrown ruts from generations of wagons and carts.

Quarterstaff.name: Quarterstaff
Quarterstaff.overview: The quarterstaff is a weapon made of hardwood, usually six to nine feet long.

Queen's Guards.name: Queen's Guards
Queen's Guards.overview: The Queen's Guards are responsible for the protection of the kingdom of Andor, for the upholding of the queens' laws, and the keeping of the queens' peace.

Queen of Andor.name: Queen of Andor
Queen of Andor.overview: The Queen of Andor is the ruler of Andor, the largest nation of the Westlands and arguably the single most powerful ruler with the exception of the Amyrlin Seat. As Andor is only ever ruled by a woman, it is technically a "Queendom". The Queen of Andor sits on the Lion Throne and resides in the Royal Palace of Andor (often just referred to as "the Palace") within the Inner City of Caemlyn. The husband of the Queen gains the title Prince Consort.

Quick.name: Quick
Quick.overview: Quick is the name of Davram Bashere 's horse.

Rabbit Nose.name: Rabbit Nose
Rabbit Nose.overview: Rabbit Nose is a young, fierce wolf.

Rahad.name: Rahad
Rahad.overview:
The Rahad is the oldest district of the city of Ebou Dar, the capital of Altara. Located east of the river, the Rahad used to be the heart of Barashta, the Ogier-built capital city of Eharon before it was destroyed during the Trolloc Wars. The city was rebuilt, but the new construction was done mostly west of the river. The ruins of the Rahad were reoccupied by the poor and destitute and over time, the settlement was rebuilt as Ebou Dar's lower-class district.

The Rahad is a dangerous place where criminals and cutpurses thrive. Visiting this district is not advisable unless in numbers and well-armed.

Rahien Sorei.name: Rahien Sorei
Rahien Sorei.overview: The Rahien Sorei is an Aiel warrior society. The name means "Dawn Runners" in the Old Tongue.

Raidhen of Hol Cuchone.name: Raidhen of Hol Cuchone
Raidhen of Hol Cuchone.overview:
Raidhen of Hol Cuchone is a ruler of a country that existed four hundred years after the Breaking, around 400 AB.

N'Delia Basolaine, First Maid and Swordfast to Radhen was believed to have translated The Prophecies of the Dragon.

Rain in High Wind.name: Rain in High Wind
Rain in High Wind.overview: Rain in High Wind is a sword form. Other than the name, nothing is known about it. During the duel between Eamon Valda and Galadedrid Damodred, Galad used this form desperately quick as a response to Valda's use of the form River of Light.

Raken.name: Raken
Raken.overview: Raken are large animals from the Seanchan continent.

Raker.name: Raker
Raker.overview: A raker is a type of Sea Folk ship; they are widely reputed to be the fastest seagoing vessels in the known world.

Ram (Constellation).name: Ram (Constellation)
Ram (Constellation).overview: One of the constellations seen over the night skies of the Westlands.

Rampore.name: Rampore
Rampore.overview:
Rampore is the eleventh largest city in Seanchan.

The city is located at the mouth of a bay in the southeast of the continent.

Rand's Aes Sedai.name: Rand's Aes Sedai
Rand's Aes Sedai.overview: In recent times Aes Sedai divided themselves in many factions. Among these factions was formed a group of sisters that allied themselves directly or indirectly to the Dragon Reborn, under many different circumstances. It can be calculated that the sisters allied to the Dragon were more than eighty, but many of them were turned to the shadow before the Last Battle.

Rand al'Thor/Parallels.name: Rand al'Thor/Parallels
Rand al'Thor/Parallels.overview: Robert Jordan draws on a number of sources from myth and legend to create the Dragon archetype. Here are some observations on likely parallels with these.

Randland.name: Randland
Randland.overview:
Randland is a name adopted by fans to refer to the world where The Wheel of Time series takes place, and is derived from the name of the central character, Rand al'Thor.

More specifically, it often refers to the Westlands, the main area of Randland's main continent between the Aryth Ocean and the Spine of the World; although forgotten places are mentioned in the east. Like many other writers, Robert Jordan never officially names his world, so in lieu of another name Randland has come into accepted common usage so that fans have something to call it. It is possible that it is still called Earth as Lan Mandragoran refers to Malkier as being "wiped off the face of the earth".

Although no scale appeared on the maps in the books themselves, a scale did appear on the world map on page 146 of the guidebook accompanying the series, The World of Robert Jordan's Wheel of Time. The scale on this map suggests that the distance from the edge of the continent on the west to The Spine of the World in the east is approximately 3,000 miles. This concurs broadly with the designers who worked on The Wheel of Time Roleplaying Game, who suggested a scale of 1"=400 miles on the color endpaper maps in the hardback editions of the books. By their calculations, the Westlands therefore measures roughly 3,500 miles from the west coast to the Spine of the World, making it approximately the size of the United States of America.

A reliable way of measuring the maps was produced in the novel New Spring, which gave the straight-line distance from Tar Valon to the sea south of Tear as 400 leagues (1,600 miles). Additionally, Caemlyn is roughly 800 miles north of the plains at the border of Tear, thereby providing a scale of approximately 530 miles to 1 inch for the maps provided in the paperback editions ( Lord of Chaos ).

Rannel.name: Rannel
Rannel.overview: Rannel is an herb that can be found in the Two Rivers region. A mixture of rannel and sheepstongue root will perk a person up somewhat, but the significant property is its horrible and lasting taste. A village Wisdom such as Nynaeve may administer the concoction to someone who is claiming they are sick, moping, behaving "like a goose" and generally acting the fool.

Rat Gnawing the Grain.name: Rat Gnawing the Grain
Rat Gnawing the Grain.overview: Rat Gnawing the Grain is a sword form. Other than the name, nothing is known about it. While trapped in Hinderstap, Matrim Cauthon saw Delarn use the form while being attacked by the villagers. This allowed Mat to help save Delarn.

Ratliff.name: Ratliff
Ratliff.overview: Ratliff is a historical figure from an unknown Age.

Ravinda.name: Ravinda
Ravinda.overview:
Ravinda is a village in Kandor, located on the main road from Canluum to Chachin, west of Manala. It is two days' ride from Chachin. It is fairly small, consisting of several buildings clustered on a main street with a wide field outside used as a meeting point and bartering ground for traders from several surrounding villages. In 979 NE the village had at least one inn, The White Tower, named in honor of the Aes Sedai stronghold.

Moiraine Damodred, al'Lan Mandragoran, Ryne Venamar, and Bukama Marenellin passed through the village on their way to Chachin in 979.

Razor.name: Razor
Razor.overview: A razor is a breed of horse from Arad Doman, so called due to the pattern of coloring. In a razor's coat, "black met white in straight lines that could have been sliced by a razor." Mat bought a razor in Jurador from Toke Fearnim as a gift for Tuon.

Reader.name: Reader
Reader.overview: A Reader is a woman who heals the sick in Cairhien. They cure using herbs and are equivilent to Wisdoms and Wise Women. Whether or not it is common for Readers to be wilders is unknown.

Real-world references.name: Real-world references
Real-world references.overview:
Robert Jordan has explicitly said that our own world is both the past and the future of the Third Age and that it is possible to look forward and back along a wheel.

We draw the distinction between real-world references and real-world parallels by saying that the real-world references look back from the Third Age to a previous Age (which is our present), while the real-world parallels are elements that project forward from a previous Age (usually the Third) and are remembered in our present. Real-world references can be of people that are living or lived in our own world, objects from our time or various religious figures.

In contrast, an example of a parallel would be Perrin's parallels with the Slavic god Perun. Perrin isn't meant to be Perun in the series - as Brandon Sanderson says, "Perrin is not a god" - but the memory/myth/legend of Perrin led to the development of some aspects of Perun in that religion as it is known in our time. In fact, Perrin has many parallels, none of which are him as he was written by Jordan.

These references occur seldomly, and subject to interpretation. Where applicable, links to confirmation by Robert Jordan (or another of his team) are given. All other statements can be seen as speculative.

Reaping the Barley.name: Reaping the Barley
Reaping the Barley.overview: Reaping the Barley is a sword form. Galadedrid Damodred used this form against Eamon Valda during the Trial Beneath the Light. Galad sliced Valda just beneath his rib cage.

Reason and Unreason.name: Reason and Unreason
Reason and Unreason.overview: Reason and Unreason by Herid Fel is a book that Min Farshaw studied for clues as to how Rand al'Thor can defeat The Dark One.

Rebel Aes Sedai.name: Rebel Aes Sedai
Rebel Aes Sedai.overview: The Rebel Aes Sedai were a group of Aes Sedai from the White Tower who sided with Siuan Sanche rather than Elaida do Avriny a'Roihan during the White Tower Schism. Their primary purpose was to continue the traditions of Aes Sedai and to take the White Tower back from Elaida.

Red (horse).name: Red (horse)
Red (horse).overview: Red is the name of a horse given to Rand al'Thor by Basel Gill.

Red Ajah.name: Red Ajah
Red Ajah.overview:
The Red Ajah of the Aes Sedai was, for more than two thousand years, dedicated to prevent the wrong and dangerous use of the One Power. In particular the Red sisters dedicated themselves in locating men with the ability to channel saidin (the tainted and very dangerous half of the One Power ) and bringing them to the White Tower for gentling.

Red sisters generally do not have friends outside of their Ajah, and upon donning the shawl are often forced to end any friendship with women not also of the Red. Until recent times they bond no Warders, and have been at odds with the Blue Ajah for a millennium. The leader of the Red Ajah is known as the Highest.

For a detailed list of all known members, see List of Red Ajah sisters

Red cockleburr.name: Red cockleburr
Red cockleburr.overview:
The red cockleburr is a plant that cannot be found for one hundred miles south of the island of Tar Valon.

One red cockleburr was found on the saddlecloth of Zerah Dacan, leading her to confess to Seaine Herimon and Pevara Tazanovni that while she did ride down the bank of the Erinin to the village of Jualdhe, she did not actually begin her journey to Tar Valon from the north as she had implied.

Red daisy.name: Red daisy
Red daisy.overview: Red daisy is an herb. Almost nothing is known about it. It can, however, be combined in a tea with sheepstongue root. Both of those herbs taste horribly bitter. Nynaeve al'Meara once treatened Elayne Trakand with such a concoction.

Red Eagle Banner.name: Red Eagle Banner
Red Eagle Banner.overview: One of the two banners carried by Perrin 's men, the other being the Red Wolfhead Banner. It was the same as that of ancient Manetheren, consisting of a red eagle flying across a field of blue. It was used by Perrin in Altara to distract from his real intentions. Perrin put it aside when he reached an alliance with the Seanchan.

Red fennel.name: Red fennel
Red fennel.overview:
Red fennel is an herb that can be found in the Two Rivers region. Consuming red fennel can help settle an upset stomach. It is a good remedy for those who suffer from sea sickness.

Red fennel should not be confused with gray fennel, which is poisonous.

Red Hawk Takes a Dove.name: Red Hawk Takes a Dove
Red Hawk Takes a Dove.overview: Red Hawk Takes a Dove is a sword form. It was used by Eamon Valda during the Trial Beneath the Light against Galadedrid Damodred. Valda caused a shallow gash on Galad's left arm using this form.

Red Salt.name: Red Salt
Red Salt.overview: The Red Salt is a sept of the Goshien Aiel. The sept hold is unknown.

Red Springs Hold.name: Red Springs Hold
Red Springs Hold.overview: Red Springs Hold is the clan hold of the Codarra Aiel, located in the Aiel Waste. Sarinde is the hold's Wise One.

Red Water.name: Red Water
Red Water.overview: The Red Water is a sept of the Goshien Aiel. The sept hold is unknown.

Red Wolfhead Banner.name: Red Wolfhead Banner
Red Wolfhead Banner.overview:
The Red Wolfhead Banner is one of the two banners carried by Perrin 's men, the other being the Red Eagle Banner. It was used first time during the Battle of Emond's Field and it becomes the symbol of Perrin; now it is the insignia of the Wolf Guard.

The banner displays a red wolf's head on a field of white, with a red border.

Redarm.name: Redarm
Redarm.overview: Redarms are the policing force of the Band of the Red Hand.

Redwing.name: Redwing
Redwing.overview: Redwing is a horse owned by Medore Damara.

Reed in the Wind.name: Reed in the Wind
Reed in the Wind.overview: Reed in the WInd is a sword form. Other than the name, nothing is known about it.

Reisendrelle.name: Reisendrelle
Reisendrelle.overview: The Reisendrelle is a river that runs south through Murandy and Lugard. The rebel Aes Sedai under Egwene al'Vere briefly stopped on the Reisendrelle during their march to the Andoran border. It flows into the River Manetherendrelle. The Storn and Armahn both flow into it.

Religion.name: Religion
Religion.overview: Religion doesn't exist in Randland in well-defined terms or sects; instead, most people believe in a distant-but-all-powerful Creator, and the Dark One who opposes him. Individual cultures may create specific beliefs: for example, Children of the Light believe that all Aes Sedai are working for the Dark One, and the Seanchan believe that their Empress is infallible. Darkfriends, of course, are a special case of belief.

Remen.name: Remen
Remen.overview: Remen is a village in Altara, located in the northeast of the country on the Lugard Road where it crosses the River Manetherendrelle.

Rena Tower.name: Rena Tower
Rena Tower.overview: Rena Tower is a Kandori border tower situated to the northwest of Heeth Tower. Due to the advance of the Blight, it now lies within the Blight itself. Under the command of Lord Niach of House Okatomo, Rena Tower sent a flash to Heeth Tower before going completely silent. Shortly thereafter, Heeth Tower itself came under heavy attack by a massive Trolloc army, It can be assumed that Rena Tower has fallen to the Trolloc hordes.

Retash.name: Retash
Retash.overview:
Retash is place that lies in a cluster of islands leagues off the mainland. It is rarely visited by even the Sea Folk, but is known for the drink, Retashen Dazer.

Their infamous drink is mentioned in a conversation between Androl and Nalaam at the Black Tower. Androl claims that he has visited once and had the drink on a bet.

Retashen Dazer.name: Retashen Dazer
Retashen Dazer.overview:
A Retashen Dazer is an alcoholic beverage that is a mixture of mead and ewe's milk. It comes from Retash, a cluster of islands leagues offshore of the Mainland, although the exact location of these islands has not been ascertained. It is likely these islands are small with little produce for trade, for even the Atha'an Miere do not often visit them. Despite that, the drink became somewhat infamous.

When the Asha'man work in the Black Tower, Nalaam asks Androl to explain to them what is a Retashen Dazer. Androl tells them and says it is "Foul stuff.". Androl claims that he has visited once and drank it on a bet.

Reyn.name: Reyn
Reyn.overview: The Reyn are one of the twelve Aiel clans. Their clan hold is unknown. They were one of the four clans to cross the Dragonwall during the Aiel War. They were led by Janduin, father to Rand al'Thor, during the Aiel War.

Rhahime Naille.name: Rhahime Naille
Rhahime Naille.overview: Rhahime Naille was a city in the nation of Aramaelle, which was part of the Ten Nations. Aside from the name, nothing else is know about it. It has no discernible translation in the Old Tongue.

Rhamdashar.name: Rhamdashar
Rhamdashar.overview: Rhamdashar was one of the 29 nations of the Free Years. It was founded after the end of the Trolloc Wars, and was established on the former territory of Aramaelle. It was later absorbed by the growing might of Artur Hawkwing's Empire. Rhamdashar was one of the Borderlands in its day and also a militarily strong nation. The lands it once held later became the nations of Malkier and Shienar. The eastern half of Arafel also lay within Rhamdashar's area of control.

Rhannon Hills.name: Rhannon Hills
Rhannon Hills.overview: The Rhannon Hills are an extensive hill range located east of Ebou Dar. They run almost from the city for a hundred miles until they meet the Venir Mountains. The farm belonging to the Kin is located a few miles from the city to the northeast, close to the hills, and Rand al'Thor fought the Seanchan to a standstill north of the hills.

Rhuidean.name: Rhuidean
Rhuidean.overview: Rhuidean (RHUY-dee-ahn; /ˈɹʰuj.diˌɑn/) is a city in the Aiel Waste built by the Jenn Aiel, some time after the Breaking of the World, but before the Trolloc Wars. It was a large unpopulated city, but smaller than Tear and Caemlyn. The buildings are all majestic palaces, with many unfinished. There is a great plaza in the center of the city filled with hundreds of objects of the One Power. Avendesora grows at the very center.

Rhuidean Aes Sedai.name: Rhuidean Aes Sedai
Rhuidean Aes Sedai.overview: The Aes Sedai of Rhuidean are two Aes Sedai that accompany the Jenn Aiel when they build Rhuidean. They are the survivors of a group of Aes Sedai who join the Jenn when Rhodric is 17.

Rhyagelle.name: Rhyagelle
Rhyagelle.overview: Rhyagelle is a word in the Old Tongue meaning "Those Who Come Home" or "Homecomers." It was used by the Seanchan as the name of their main invasion force of the Westlands.

Ribbon in the Air.name: Ribbon in the Air
Ribbon in the Air.overview: Ribbon in the Air is a sword form. Nothing but the name is known about this form. It was used in the duel between Rand al'Thor and Turak Aladon. The opposing side countered with Stones Falling from the Cliff. Galadedrid Damodred once used this form against a Trolloc.

Ring of Tamyrlin.name: Ring of Tamyrlin
Ring of Tamyrlin.overview:
The Ring of Tamyrlin was a legendary ring, mythical even, from the Age of Legends worn by the leader of the Aes Sedai. Lews Therin Telamon wore the ring, however, no other wearers are known by name. Whether it was an angreal, sa'angreal, or ter'angreal of immense power is unknown, although stories often mention it was one of these. Stories tell that the ring might have been named after the first person who learned how to tap into the True Source and channel. Some other tales say it was made by that person. Contrary to popular Aes Sedai thinking, it cannot be said for certain whether it was a man or woman who first learned to channel. It is possible that the title Amyrlin is a corrupted version of the name Tamyrlin.

"Elan Morin grimaced. "Look at you," he said scornfully. "Once you stood first among the Servants. Once you wore the Ring of Tamyrlin, and sat in the High Seat. Once you summoned the Nine Rods of Dominion. Now look at you!"

Rising (horse).name: Rising (horse)
Rising (horse).overview: Rising is a horse from the Royal Palace of Andor.

Rissen.name: Rissen
Rissen.overview: Rissen is a Saldaean soldier under the command of Davram Bashere.

River Manetherendrelle.name: River Manetherendrelle
River Manetherendrelle.overview:
The River Manetherendrelle is one of the primary waterways of the Westlands. Together with its major tributary, the Arinelle, this river dominates much of the central-western region of the continent and keeps those lands fertile.

The Manetherendrelle itself rises in the Mountains of Mist at the extreme south-western tip of the Two Rivers district of Andor. Its initial course along the southern border of the Two Rivers is marked by rapids, which causes the water to foam and gives the river its local name of the White River. The White River is the southernmost of the waterflows that flanks the Two Rivers region. Although it has no crossing during modern times, the Forest of Shadows on the opposite far bank was also part of Manetheren must have been reachable by some means. In fact, a road extends south beyond Deven Ride that seems to end nowhere, but may have once led to a bridge.

The Tarendrelle joins the Manetherendrelle further east before it is also joined by the Arinelle some distance south of Whitebridge. The river then turns south and flows for several hundred miles through Altara, along the border of Murandy and through Illian before meeting the Sea of Storms at the City of Illian.

Between the Manetherendrelle and Arinelle, it is possible to sail from Maradon, the capital of Saldaea, all the way to Illian, a distance of approximately three thousand miles.

River of Light.name: River of Light
River of Light.overview: River of Light is a sword form. It is used as a draw-cut, usually ment to unsheath the sword and strike in the same motion. Eamon Valda used this form against Galadedrid Damodred during thier Trial Beneath the Light, albeit his sword was already out of its scabbard. Had Galad not quickly countered with Rain in High Wind, Valda would have sheared off one of Galad's arms.

River of Souls.name: River of Souls
River of Souls.overview: River of Souls is a short story published in an anthology entitled Unfettered.

River Queen.name: River Queen
River Queen.overview: The River Queen is a river ship. No mention is made of the names of the captain or any of the crew.

Riverserpent.name: Riverserpent
Riverserpent.overview: Riverserpent is a riverboat that travels the River Eldar, and Agni Neres is her captain. When he put in at Samara, both Galadedrid Damodred and Masema Dagar attempt to conscript the Riverserpent for Nynaeve al'Meara 's use. Galad, who succeeded, finds Nynaeve, his half-sister Elayne, and their group and escorts them to the docks. Before they leave, however, Nynaeve bullies Captain Neres into taking on several refugees at the docks, including Nicola Treehill, Areina Nermasiv, and " Marigan." After days on the river, the Riverserpent passes Boannda and the group disembarks near Salidar. ==Notes==

Robert Jordan's The Wheel of Time Calend.name: Robert Jordan's The Wheel of Time Calendar 2009
Robert Jordan's The Wheel of Time Calend.overview:
Robert Jordan's The Wheel of Time Calendar 2009 was a calendar published in July 2008.

As explained in a letter in the calendar, all of Robert Jordan 's royalties as well as a portion of Tor's proceeds from the sale of this calendar were donated to the Mayo Clinic for amyloidosis research.

Rodholder.name: Rodholder
Rodholder.overview: Rodholder is the title of the third in line commander of the armies of the Seanchan Empire.

Roemalle.name: Roemalle
Roemalle.overview: Roemalle was a kingdom of the Free Years. It was founded after the end of the Trolloc Wars, and was established on the former territory of Aramaelle. It was later absorbed by the growing might of Artur Hawkwing's Empire. The lands it once held are now desolate and mountainous wilderness.

Rolling hoops.name: Rolling hoops
Rolling hoops.overview: Rolling hoops is a child's game played in Emond's Field.

Roofmistress.name: Roofmistress
Roofmistress.overview:
A roofmistress is an Aiel woman who owns property.

There are at least two distinct kinds of roofmistress: any Aiel woman who owns a house, and the Hold 's representative roofmistress.

Rorn M'doi.name: Rorn M'doi
Rorn M'doi.overview: The Rorn M'doi was a place during the War of Power where Sammael carried the Shadow after betraying the Gates of Hevan. He escaped justice there. It was connected in some way to "the heart of Satelle."

Rose Crown of Andor.name: Rose Crown of Andor
Rose Crown of Andor.overview: The Rose Crown of Andor is the crown worn by the Queen of Andor. It is a wreath of highly-wrought golden roses. A simplified version is worn by the Daughter-Heir.

Rosebud.name: Rosebud
Rosebud.overview: Rosebud is the name of Selucia 's horse.

Royal Library of Cairhien.name: Royal Library of Cairhien
Royal Library of Cairhien.overview:
The Royal Library of Cairhien is one of the great wonders of the world, a vast treasure trove consisting of tens of thousands of books on every conceivable subject. It is located within the city of Cairhien, within an impressive and large stone structure. The Royal Library is one of the greatest treasures of the kingdom of Cairhien and as a depository of knowledge, it is second only to the Great Library of the White Tower in Tar Valon.

The Royal Library was one of the few buildings in the city not torched by the Aiel during the First Battle of Cairhien. The Aiel consider knowledge to be precious and will not destroy a book of knowledge.

Royal Palace of Andor.name: Royal Palace of Andor
Royal Palace of Andor.overview:
The Royal Palace of Andor is located in the very center of Caemlyn. Like most of the Inner City, it was originally built by Ogier stonemasons. It holds the Lion Throne within the Grand Hall, the Royal Apartments, and several courtyards and stables.

It also houses a number of reception rooms, including the Blue Reception Room.

The Palace was heavily damaged during the fight between Rand and Rahvin, with the use of balefire.

The Palace was occupied and probably destroyed or heavily damaged when the Shadowspawn conquered Caemlyn.

Ruby-hilted dagger.name: Ruby-hilted dagger
Ruby-hilted dagger.overview:
The ruby-hilted dagger is an artifact of Shadar Logoth; like all things from that city, it is contaminated with the evil that consumed the residents and will pass on the madness to whoever carries it.

Note that while The Eye of the World and The Great Hunt refer to the dagger as a "ruby-hilted dagger" eight times (and therefore this wiki adopts this terminology), it could be more accurately called a "ruby-pommeled dagger", since the hilt is not made of ruby, but rather is "capped" with one. Other names include "Shadar Logoth dagger" (4 times in The Eye of the World and The Dragon Reborn ) and "dagger from Shadar Logoth" (10 times in The Eye of the World, The Great Hunt, and The Dragon Reborn )

Runnien Crossing.name: Runnien Crossing
Runnien Crossing.overview: Runnien Crossing is a town in Altara

S'redit.name: S'redit
S'redit.overview:
S'redit are an animal from the Seanchan Empire, though Valan Luca made fanciful claims that they were from Shara.

S'redit are extremely large, with wrinkled gray skin, big ears, and long snouts that reach the ground. The adults also have huge curving tusks. In another age, they would be called elephants.

On the mainland, Valan Luca has named them "boar-horses," for interest and ease of pronunciation. He has three of them in his traveling show: Mer, a bull, Sanit, a cow or female, and Nerin a new-born calf. They are cared for by a Seanchan woman named Cerandin who had once served as a handler in the Court of the Nine Moons. She uses a heavy hooked goad in training.

S'redit are also used by the Seanchan as work animals and for war, such as the invasion in Falme.

In The Dragon Reborn, It is mentioned that inhabitants of the westlands do not know what animal ivory comes from, as it is traded for from the lands beyond the Aiel Waste. While the natural assumption would be a large, elephant-like creature such as the S'redit, the ivory trade in the westlands was present long before the Seanchan invasion. Unless there are wild S'redit in Shara as well as Seanchan (like the separate populations of African and Asian Elephants of our time), traded ivory must come from another animal, such as a walrus or narwhal.

Egwene encounters an ancient skeleton in Tel'aran'rhiod in the Panarch's Palace in Tanchico which may be from a s'redit.

Sa'las Plains.name: Sa'las Plains
Sa'las Plains.overview:
The Sa'las Plains is a region on the Seanchan continent. No more is known about it.

It is possible that the Sa'las Plains is a reference to "plains on which battles are fought" and not an actual place on the Seanchan continent. This is based on a thought from Kennar Miraj who observes that "Mud kept down the dust, yet word of an army on the move ran like wildfire on the Sa'las Plains, whatever the land." However, this sentence can also be read as a simple metaphor using the Sa'las Plains as the example.

Sa'sara.name: Sa'sara
Sa'sara.overview:
The sa'sara is an extremely sensual dance outlawed by several Saldaean queens for its indecency. While known by virtually every noblewoman in Saldaea, few would ever admit to the knowledge. The sa'sara, when done correctly, has the ability to drive men wild. The sa'sara is known to have started three wars and sparked two rebellions, forty-seven unions and feuds between houses, not to mention countless duels and smaller disturbances. Some tell the story of a Saldaean Queen who lost her throne to a rebellion and won it back by seducing the victorious general with the sa'sara. Any Saldaean queen will deny the tale.

Faile Bashere says she may dance it for Perrin one day and make his blood boil in his veins. She says that it makes the Tuatha'an dance, the tiganza, look very modest in comparison.

In the Old Tongue, sara is a kind of dance and sa' a prefix indicating superlative, as in sa'angreal. sa'sara is therefore a dance beyond all others!

Saban.name: Saban
Saban.overview: Saban is the third month in the Farede calendar. In most years, it is equivalent to the real world period from February 16 to March 15.

Sabinel.name: Sabinel
Sabinel.overview:
A town in an unknown nation. Mat tried to convince Talmanes to help him win a pair of barmaids there.

The town has a single reference during Tarmon Gai'don. A Seanchan messenger sent to Mat from Talmanes tells him that the Dragons are out of commission and that they had as much luck as the barmaids in Sabinel. When asked to explain, Mat tells the messenger that the maids there work for tips, but the people of the town never tip. In reality, Mat had a hard time flirting with the barmaids there and Talmanes suggested faking an old war wound for sympathy. The message is a code that the Dragons are not as damaged as the messenge would otherwise indicate.

Safer.name: Safer
Safer.overview: Safer was one of the Ten Nations that arose in the aftermath of the Breaking of the World. It fell in the aftermath of the Trolloc Wars.

Sailmistress.name: Sailmistress
Sailmistress.overview:
A Sailmistress is the captain of a Sea Folk ship and invariably a female. She is assisted by, and often married to her Cargomaster, who is always male.

The Sailmistress controls when and where the ship sails, her word unquestioned. As well as being the head of the ship, she is also regarded as the head of the crew's families, whether or not there is any actual kinship.

Salaking.name: Salaking
Salaking.overview:
Salaking is a place in Seanchan.

Semirhage told to Suroth that Seandar was in chaos and there was war from the Aldael Mountains to Salaking, so Salaking is probably in one of far ends of the Empire; no more is known about it.

Saldaea.name: Saldaea
Saldaea.overview: Saldaea is one of the four Borderland nations which lie on the threshold of the Great Blight. It is the westernmost of the Borderlands, lying between the Aryth Ocean and Kandor. The sign of Saldaea is three silver fish on a field of dark blue.

Salidar.name: Salidar
Salidar.overview:
Salidar is a small village in Altara. It is one or two miles inland from the River Eldar, on the border with Amadicia. It has been abandoned since the Whitecloak War some forty years before, along with other Altaran border villages, but was recently used as the headquarters of the Aes Sedai who rebelled against Elaida after Siuan Sanche was deposed as Amyrlin Seat.

It was once again abandoned (except for sisters occasionally going back to recover messenger pigeons) after the rebel Aes Sedai moved against the White Tower. Since it is abandoned, Egwene al'Vere frequently used it as a secret meeting location in Tel'aran'rhiod.

Salidar is of some note in the history of the Aes Sedai as it was the birthplace of Deane Aryman, acknowledged as one of the greatest Amyrlins since Rashima Kerenmosa. Aryman is credited with restoring the prestige of the Aes Sedai after her predecessor Bonwhin Meraighdin severely weakened them by provoking Artur Hawkwing into besieging Tar Valon for twenty years ( FY 975 - 994 ). It was Aryman who exposed Bonwhin and led her deposing and stilling in FY 992. At the time of Aryman's birth, Salidar was located in the kingdom of Shiota, and called Sallie Daera.

Salidar Embassy to the Dragon Reborn.name: Salidar Embassy to the Dragon Reborn
Salidar Embassy to the Dragon Reborn.overview: The deposition of the Amyrlin Seat Siuan Sanche followed by the division of the White Tower caused both factions of the Aes Sedai to try and ally themselves to Rand al'Thor.

Salidar Six.name: Salidar Six
Salidar Six.overview:
The Salidar Six is an informal name given by fans to the six Aes Sedai who orchestrated the core of the Rebel Aes Sedai in the abandoned village of Salidar. Sometimes, this group is referred to as "Sheriam and her circle" or "Sheriam's council," which predates Egwene's council of advisors. Each sister had significant influence in her Ajah in her own right, and together were extremely effective in the shaping of events during the White Tower Schism. These women are:

- Sheriam Bayanar - ostensibly of the Blue Ajah and former Mistress of Novices under Siuan Sanche . Undoubtedly the leader of the group, she was even offered the Amyrlin Seat in exile, and the strongest in the One Power among them. Installed herself as Keeper under Egwene al'Vere , presumably with the intention of being able to steer Egwene according to the will of the Salidar Six, although her motives were later revealed to serve a darker purpose.
- Anaiya - also of the Blue Ajah. It has been speculated that she was First Selector of the Blue Ajah, and though there is no hard evidence for this, she is certainly someone to whom many Blues listen.
- Myrelle Berengari - of the Green Ajah . She is fairly young for an Aes Sedai - only raised to the shawl fifteen years ago - but has risen very far in influence. She is strong in the One Power and became Captain-General in the rebel camp.
- Beonin Marinye - of the Gray Ajah . Although one of the sisters that helped organize the rebels in the first place, she was an undercover agent for Elaida .
- Morvrin - of the Brown Ajah . Morvrin may be on the Brown Ajah Council or even First Chair , as suggested by her appearance before the Hall to put Egwene forward as Amyrlin.
- Carlinya - of the White Ajah . Held as much sway as most Sitters even before the Tower's division.

In true Aes Sedai custom, these women are all very strong in the One Power, at least before the discovery of the main characters. With a strength level of 14(2), Sheriam was one of the strongest sisters in the rebel faction with only Lelaine Akashi and Romanda Cassin being stronger. Anaiya, Carlinya, Morvrin and Myrelle are all at strength 15(3), whereas Beonin is at 16(4). It is likely that they assumed their superior strength would give them dominance over the rebellion. Although Lelaine could have presented a challenge to their authority, Romanda was not expected to have joined the cause. We also see that the only two sisters who can match Sheriam in the rebel faction, Bera Harkin and Kiruna Nachiman, were deftly maneuvered to search for the Dragon Reborn in the Aiel Waste. This does not seem accidental, but rather way to get rid of two potential rivals known to work together. Only a single known rebel sister, Maigan, is as strong as the Anaiya et al.

Salmarna.name: Salmarna
Salmarna.overview: Salmarna was a historical location probably in the former Kingdom of Malkier. Bukama Marenellin is remembered as the hero of Salmarna in the Borderlands.

Salt Flat.name: Salt Flat
Salt Flat.overview: The Salt Flat is a sept of the Nakai Aiel. The sept hold is unknown.

Samaha.name: Samaha
Samaha.overview: Samaha is a village in Ghealdan.

Samara.name: Samara
Samara.overview:
Samara is a town in Ghealdan. It is situated on the River Eldar.

It was here that Nynaeve al'Meara was brought to meet Masema Dagar, the Prophet of the Dragon.

Shortly after this meeting, she met Galad Damodred and other Children of the Light. A conflict between the two forces of the Dragonsworn and Children of the Light takes place in Samara, and after it, only ruins are left.

Samma N'Sei.name: Samma N'Sei
Samma N'Sei.overview:
Samma N'Sei, meaning "Eye Blinders" in the Old Tongue, are male Aiel channelers and their descendants who serve the Dark One. They dwell in a town constructed by prison labor in the Great Blight, near Shayol Ghul.

The Samma N'Sei are a corrupted and subverted group of Aiel warriors. Aiel men who discover they can channel tainted saidin will go north into the Blight to fight the Shadow in hopes of dying in battle. It appears that since the Breaking, many have been captured over time and turned to the Shadow. Afterwards, these Aiel men have been able to channel saidin with the Dark One's protection from the taint.

In TWoTC, it is stated that not all of them are able to channel, probably the descendants of turned Aiel channelers, but nevertheless they are trained to become powerful warriors in the Aiel way.

There are inverse differences among the Samma N'Sei to Aiel culture. Their veils are red rather than black. Proper Aiel veil themselves before killing, while the Samma N'Sei unveil before making a kill. Those that are forcibly turned to the Shadow file their teeth to points.

Sand Hills.name: Sand Hills
Sand Hills.overview: The Sand Hills are an abnormal geographic feature that extend along the eastern foothills of the Mountains of Mist

Sanit.name: Sanit
Sanit.overview: Sanit is a s'redit cow tended by Cerandin in Valan Luca's Traveling Show.

Santhra's book on the Forsaken.name: Santhra's book on the Forsaken
Santhra's book on the Forsaken.overview: Santhra 's book on the Forsaken was among the books studied by Moiraine at Adeleas and Vandene 's house.

Santhra.name: Santhra
Santhra.overview: Santhra was a historical author who a book on the Forsaken. Adeleas and Vandene Namelle possessed a copy of the book.

Satare.name: Satare
Satare.overview: Satare is a "delicate" wine from the Age of Legends.

Satelle.name: Satelle
Satelle.overview: Satelle was a place during the Age of Legends. Tel Janin Aellinsar 's first betrayal led the Shadow there to victory, though nothing else is known about it.

Saven.name: Saven
Saven.overview: Saven is the sixth month in the Farede calendar. In most years, it is equivalent to the real world period from May 11 to June 7. Feast of Fools occurs during Saven (everywhere but Arad Doman and the Borderlands ) and Dahan on the 9th.

Scales of Office.name: Scales of Office
Scales of Office.overview: The Scales of Office is a silver medallion in the form of a set of balance scales. These, along with a set of real scales, represent the office of Mayor in Emond's Field.

School of Cairhien.name: School of Cairhien
School of Cairhien.overview: The School of Cairhien is an academy set up by Rand al'Thor after he took the city from the Shaido Aiel. It's located in Lord Barthanes 's former manor house in Cairhien. Rand offered funding and rewards to inventors in the city who would contribute to the school, in an effort to recover some of the lost knowledge from the Age of Legends.

Scouter.name: Scouter
Scouter.overview: Scouter is an old pack horse.

Scratch.name: Scratch
Scratch.overview: Scratch is a yellow cat owned by Brandelwyn al'Vere that lives in the Winespring Inn in Emond's Field.

Sea of L'Heye.name: Sea of L'Heye
Sea of L'Heye.overview: The Sea of L'Heye is a body of water in the Seanchan continent. The town of Abunai lies on the Sea of L'Heye.

Sea of Storms.name: Sea of Storms
Sea of Storms.overview:
The Sea of Storms is the large ocean that lies to the south of the Westlands, Termool and Shara, and to the north of the Mad Lands. The Atha'an Miere are the only people known to sail this sea. It is named because of its constant storming, and in the winter, tempests called "cemaros" roll across the Sea of Storms.

Mayene, Tear, Illian and Ebou Dar are the largest ports on the Sea of Storms.

The Sea Folk islands of Tremalking, Qaim and Cindaking lie in the Sea of Storms. There are also larger Sea Folk island groupings known to exist much further to the south, where mainlanders do not travel.

The Sea of Storms washes against the northern shores of the island continent known as the Land of the Madmen, the existence of which is virtually unknown to people other than the Sea Folk. The Sea Folk have declared this landmass off-limits, due to dangerous volcanic activity and also the instability and violence of the inhabitants, who fell into savagery during the Breaking of the World and have never recovered.

Seahawk.name: Seahawk
Seahawk.overview: The Seahawk is a ship, captained by Bayle Domon.

Sealbreaker.name: Sealbreaker
Sealbreaker.overview:
Sealbreaker is the title given to Logain Ablar by his bonded Aes Sedai, Gabrelle Brawley, as she urges him to destroy the seals in preparation for the resealing of the Bore by Rand al'Thor during the Last Battle.

The gaining of this title is almost certainly a partial fulfillment of various viewings by Min Farshaw concerning Logain.

Sean's Tale.name: Sean's Tale
Sean's Tale.overview: Sean's Tale is the local inn in Ostin Falls.

Seanchan.name: Seanchan
Seanchan.overview: Seanchan (pronounced SHAWN-chan) is an empire located on the continent of the same name. It was founded after the Trolloc Wars, and began an invasion of the Westlands in 998 NE to reclaim the continent in what the Seanchan call the Corenne ("the Return" in the Old Tongue ). This invasion was stopped when Empress Fortuona signs a treaty with the Dragon Reborn and agrees to fight alongside the forces of Light in The Last Battle.

Seanchan (continent).name: Seanchan (continent)
Seanchan (continent).overview:
The Seanchan home continent almost girdles the world from pole to pole and is considerably larger than the continent consisting of the Westlands, Aiel Waste, Great Blight, and Shara. The nearest parts of Seanchan to the Westlands are located more than 12,000 miles across the Aryth Ocean, a journey of some months even by the fastest ships and contributing to the lack of communication between the two continents for most of recorded history.

Seanchan is split into two landmasses, divided by a long dividing channel. There are four large islands located off the coast of the continent, and three small ones within the dividing channel.

Seandar.name: Seandar
Seandar.overview:
Seandar is the Seanchan Imperial Capital and is the largest city in the Empire of Seanchan, most likely the largest city in the world.

Seandar is located inland at the confluence of three great river networks, roughly halfway between the dividing channel and the Aryth Ocean. The city is located on an immense peninsular that extends for several thousand miles north and east out of the southern landmass of the continent, which mostly lies south of the equator. As such, it is somewhat remote from the other major cities of the continent, which may explain why it was able to grow to a large size and gave its name to the rest of the continent during the centuries following the Breaking of the World. Seandar is located at approximately the same latitude as Tremalking, but more than 5,000 miles to the west.

Seandar was an obvious target for the forces commanded by Luthair Paendrag Mondwin after his initial invasion had secured parts of the northern landmass, including the city of Imfaral. Once the renegade Aes Sedai known as Deain gave him the secrets of a'dam manufacture, Luthair was able to prosecute the conquest of Seanchan much more successfully, and eventually Seandar fell to his advance. It was designated as the Imperial Capital shortly thereafter.

Seandar is the location of the Court of the Nine Moons and the Crystal Throne, from where the Empress rules over her vast empire. It is also the location of the Tower of Ravens, the imperial prison and headquarters for the Seekers for Truth, the imperial police force.

In 1000 NE, whilst large numbers of Seanchan troops were engaged in the Corenne, the reconquest of the Westlands in the name of Artur Hawkwing, the city of Seandar was rocked by the slaughter of most of the imperial family, including the Empress Radhanan and all of her heirs west of the Aryth Ocean, by the Forsaken Semirhage. In the aftermath of the massacre, more than fifty nobles claimed the Crystal Throne and a civil war erupted, with Seandar and a dozen other major cities seeing both fighting and substantial looting. The outcome of this situation remains to be seen.

Second Battle of Cairhien.name: Second Battle of Cairhien
Second Battle of Cairhien.overview: The Second Battle of Cairhien was fought during the Shaido War of 999 NE. The 160,000 Shaido Aiel under Couladin, marching at a furious pace, had surrounded the city of Cairhien and besieged it, but the presence of not only native Cairhienin forces but also Tairen reinforcements sent into the kingdom at the order of Rand al'Thor prevented them from breaching the walls or capturing the city.

Sedar Cut.name: Sedar Cut
Sedar Cut.overview: Sedar Cut is a location in the Aiel Waste.

Seeing Through the Breaking.name: Seeing Through the Breaking
Seeing Through the Breaking.overview: Seeing Through the Breaking, by Elandria Borndat, is a history of the War of Power. Saerin studied it to learn about Mesaana.

Seeker.name: Seeker
Seeker.overview:
For the Seanchan position by the similar short name, see Seekers for Truth .

A Mahdi or Seeker is the leader of a Tuatha'an.

The Mahdi is responsible for various Tuatha'an ceremony, including the greeting of visitors.

The formal greeting and response would follow the pattern below:

Mahdi: <presses both hands to chest and bows> You are welcome to our fires. Do you know the song?

Visitor: <same bow> Your welcome warms my spirit, Mahdi, as your fires warm the flesh, but I do not know the song.

Mahdi: Then we seek still. As it was, so shall it be, if we but remember, seek, and find.

Seekers for Truth.name: Seekers for Truth
Seekers for Truth.overview:
The Seekers for Truth are Seanchan who investigate treason and other wrong-doing. They act as spies among the Seanchan and their enemies, and are akin to a secret police force. They are so'jhin and the personal property of the Empress. Seekers wear a tattoo of the Imperial Raven and Tower on the back of each shoulder, though they are less willing to show them off than the Deathwatch Guards with their own tattoos. Seekers also carry identification plaques for when the need arises.

Anyone must obey the Seekers of Truth, even one of the Blood.

Segade plant.name: Segade plant
Segade plant.overview: The segade plant is a type of flora from the Aiel Waste.

Sehar.name: Sehar
Sehar.overview:
Sehar is a village in Altara, located a few miles from the River Eldar and Amadicia.

When Morgase Trakand, Lini Eltring, Martyn Tallanvor, Basel Gill, Breane Taborwin and Lamgwin Dorn are traveling through Altara, they pass through Sehar on their way to Cormaed.

Sei'cair.name: Sei'cair
Sei'cair.overview: Sei'cair is a word from the Old Tongue meaning "the eyes of gold" or "golden eyes."

Sei'mosiev.name: Sei'mosiev
Sei'mosiev.overview:
Sei'mosiev is a term used among the Seanchan.

Literally, it means "downcast eyes," and it is used to indicate a loss of face, as "becoming sei'mosiev." Sei'mosiev is part of the Old Tongue. Sei means "eye" in the Old Tongue.

Sei'taer.name: Sei'taer
Sei'taer.overview: Sei'taer is an Old Tongue word meaning "straight eyes" or "level eyes."

Seia Doon.name: Seia Doon
Seia Doon.overview: The Seia Doon is an Aiel warrior society. The name means "Black Eyes" in the Old Tongue.

Seiera (horse).name: Seiera (horse)
Seiera (horse).overview:
For the flower by the same name, see Seiera .

Seiera is the name of a horse owned by Min Farshaw.

Seiera (plant).name: Seiera (plant)
Seiera (plant).overview:
For the horse by the same name, see Seiera .

Seiera is a flower. It is also called a blue-eye, both in reference to the Old Tongue meaning and its appearance.

Selean.name: Selean
Selean.overview: Selean was a town in Cairhien. It was located at the western end of the Jangai Pass, in the Spine of the World.

Seleisin.name: Seleisin
Seleisin.overview: Seleisin is a place that is thought to be extremely isolated. Elayne thinks that perhaps there might be a crofter in Seleisin that does not know of the Tower split, but that would be all. Moiraine knows no more about how soon Tarmon Gai'don will happen than does a redbird in Seleisin does.

Selfar.name: Selfar
Selfar.overview: Selfar is a horse owned by Talmanes Delovinde.

Semalaren.name: Semalaren
Semalaren.overview: Semalaren is a place in Seanchan where a battle was fought. Bakayar Mishima read that there were four hundred damane on either side and it was a slaughterhouse with half the Imperial army dead plus three out of four among the rebels.

Sen T'jore.name: Sen T'jore
Sen T'jore.overview:
Sen T'jore is a region on the Seanchan continent. From the references, it seems to be just an area of land and not a town or village.

Suroth Sabelle Meldarath owned a decorative panel with an image of a great spotted cat that originated from Sen T'jore. Kennar Miraj once mused that his enemies seemed to spring out of the ground like trap-worms from Sen T'jore.

Sept.name: Sept
Sept.overview:
A sept is a subdivision of the Aiel clans. Aiel can be of the same clan, but different septs. Each clan has different septs. For example, Jindo is a sept of the Taardad and no other clan would have a Jindo sept. While these are the known septs, it is possible that there are many that are known only within each clan.

While it is not known how many septs a clan normally has, the Shaido has had as many as eighty-three septs WH 4.

September.name: September
September.overview: September is the ninth month in the Gregorian calendar. It occurs in Wheel of Time world during Choren 1 to Shaldine 2.

Serai.name: Serai
Serai.overview: The Serai is a sept of the Tomanelle Aiel. The sept hold is unknown.

Serana.name: Serana
Serana.overview:
Serana is a village in Tarabon that lies halfway between Elmora and the border of Amadicia. It is a halfway point for merchant trains traveling between Tanchico and Amador, and has many inns. It is located about 400 miles south of Tarabon's border with Almoth Plain.

In the spring of 1000 NE, a mixed group of Dragonsworn, Taraboner rebels, and troops from Arad Doman under General Rodel Ituralde launched a suprise attack on a Seanchan encampment next to the village. They destroyed it as part of Ituralde's plan to provoke the Seanchan into assaulting Arad Doman and falling into a trap.

Serenda Palace.name: Serenda Palace
Serenda Palace.overview:
The Serenda Palace is the royal residence and seat of government for the ruler of the kingdom of Amadicia. It is noted for its opulence, where even the servants were red and gold livery.

The Palace was originally built some time after the War of the Hundred Years in the city of Amador. However, in the 930s NE the then-ruler of Amadicia granted permission for the Children of the Light to establish a permanant headquarters in the city, the Fortress of the Light. In less than a single generation the Children became the true power within Amadicia and as a reflection of this, the Serenda Palace was dismantled brick-by-brick and rebuilt two miles outside Amador's city walls.

The most recent resident of the Serenda Palace was King Ailron. After being killed at the Battle of Jeramel, the Seanchan appointed a new king to rule in their name from the Serenda Palace.

Serengada Dai.name: Serengada Dai
Serengada Dai.overview: Serengada Dai is a city in Seanchan. No more is known about it.

Seven Seals.name: Seven Seals
Seven Seals.overview:
The Great Seals are seven cuendillar discs, each bearing the ancient symbol of the Aes Sedai (a white teardrop and a black teardrop conjoined). They are the size of a man's hand and serve as a focus point for the actual seals which hold the Dark One in his prison.

When the forces of the Shadow were about to overrun the forces of Light and defeat seemed only months away, Lews Therin Telamon and the Hundred Companions decided to execute their dangerous plan to reseal the Bore that allowed the Dark One to touch the earth. They, together with a bodyguard of ten thousand warmen, Traveled to Shayol Ghul to execute their plan, sealing away the Dark One and the thirteen Forsaken. Strictly speaking, the discs themselves are not seals, but are as focus points, or anchors, for the seals. However, in common usage they are referred to as Seals.

Currently, even though the seals are made of cuendillar, the entropic influence of the Dark One has caused them to weaken to such an extent that they could shatter from a fall to the ground or being struck by a man with a hammer.

Seven Towers.name: Seven Towers
Seven Towers.overview: The Seven Towers refers to the seven towers on the walls of the capital of Malkier, a Borderland nation lost to The Blight. The Seven Towers were located alongside some lakes near the Mountains of Dhoom. Today it's only a broken ruin. According to The Wheel of Time Companion the Seven Towers were defining landmarks of Malkier and were broken by the Shadowspawn armies.

Seventh Age.name: Seventh Age
Seventh Age.overview:
The last Age of the Wheel of Time, and the age before the First Age comes again.

Nothing is known about what happens in this Age or what the basic shape of its Age Lace is, unlike the Third Age (the battle to re-seal the Dark One ), or the Second Age (the Age of Legends ). It has been speculated that the First Age is some subset of the real world's history. If this is the case, then the end of the Seventh Age ushers in our reality. Given the history of our world, the Seventh Age may end in a cataclysm so great that man is reduced to hunting and gathering. This reduction to a " Stone Age ↗ " would allow some subset of the history of our world to take place, starting with hunter-gatherers and progressing to agriculture and early major civilizations such as Sumeria, Egypt, Greece, and Rome.

Figures of past ages and the One Power itself would be relegated to myth or forgotten entirely. This is seen in the main narrative. For example, Perrin Aybara and Mat Cauthon exhibit many aspects of the Norse gods Thor/Perun and Odin, respectively, particularly in the later books. Perrin mirrors Thor when he forges his Power-wrought hammer which glows and flashes with lighting when he strikes Shadowspawn. Mat mirrors Odin with his one eye, wide-brimmed hat, spear with ravens on it, his title of Raven Prince, and his skill in battle.

The One Power needs to be completely or nearly completely forgotten by the time of the First Age so that it can be rediscovered, possibly as a way to save humanity from the cataclysm that ends the First Age and ushers in the Age of Legends.

Sha'je.name: Sha'je
Sha'je.overview: Sha'je was a type of duel using two daggers called aran'gar and osan'gar (right-hand side dagger and left-hand side dagger) at the end of the Age of Legends. The tips of the daggers were poisoned, so often none of the participants survived.

Sha'mad Conde.name: Sha'mad Conde
Sha'mad Conde.overview: The Sha'mad Conde is an Aiel warrior society. The name means "Thunder Walkers" in the Old Tongue.

Sha'rah.name: Sha'rah
Sha'rah.overview: Sha'rah is a complex boardgame that dates back to an age before the Age of Legends.

Shaarad.name: Shaarad
Shaarad.overview: The Shaarad are one of the twelve Aiel clans. Their clan hold is unknown. They were one of the four clans to cross the Dragonwall during the Aiel War.
