The Dragon Reborn.overview: The Dragon Reborn (abbreviated tDR ) is the third book in The Wheel of Time series. It was published by Tor Books and released on September 15, 1991. It is 699 pages long.

The Dusty Wheel.name: The Dusty Wheel
The Dusty Wheel.overview: The Dusty Wheel is an inn in Caemlyn. Though, its patrons, Nobles, commoners and everything in between know it as The Rumor Wheel. It is owned by Innkeeper Hatch.

The Essays of Willim of Maneches.name: The Essays of Willim of Maneches
The Essays of Willim of Maneches.overview:
The Essays of Willim of Maneches is a popular book of philosophy written in ancient times before the New Era. Rand saw a copy of the book located in the library of the Queen's Blessing inn in Caemlyn. Egwene and Elayne located a second copy within the home of Mother Guenna, a Wise Woman living in Tear. Elayne spent some time reading it while staying in her home. Loial also owns a copy of the book in his collection.

Willim's works influenced a number of later writers, including the Saldaean philosopher Shivena Kayenzi who claimed that all reality was an illusion. Lectures on his essays are taught to Novices and Accepted while they matriculate in the White Tower. When Moiraine Damodred was an Accepted, she was once questioned by Meilyn Arganya regarding Willim's influence over Shivena.

The Evening Star.name: The Evening Star
The Evening Star.overview:
For the chapter in New Spring called "The Evening Star", see New Spring/Chapter 23 .

The Evening Star is an inn located in the Kandori capital of Chachin. It is a respectable establishment made of stone and consisting of three stories. It caters mostly to merchants of middling success and rank and is popular with women, particularly of the Kandori Merchants' Guild who find more male-oriented inns noisy and tiresome. Because of its popularity with merchants, the inn employs guards and has a strong-room for the storage of high-value items and funds.

Moiraine Damodred and Siuan Sanche stayed at the inn briefly in 979 NE during their hunt for the Dragon Reborn. The innkeeper, Ailene Tolvina, proved helpful in their attempts to infiltrate Kandori society.

The Eye of the World.name: The Eye of the World
The Eye of the World.overview: The Eye of the World (abbreviated tEotW ) is the first book in The Wheel of Time series. It was published by Tor Books and released on January 15, 1990. It is 814 pages long.

The Eye of the World comic.name: The Eye of the World comic
The Eye of the World comic.overview: The Eye of the World comic is based of the book with the same name. The first issue, called Dragonmount ( The Wheel of Time: Eye of the World #0), was released on April 29, 2009. New issues came out monthly through Dabel Brothers Publishing. It was written and drawn by Chuck Dixon and Chase Conley. As of 2013, Dynamite Entertainment produced it on a monthly basis.
aliases: The Eye of the World comic cover

The Falcon Stoops.name: The Falcon Stoops
The Falcon Stoops.overview: The Falcon Stoops is a sword form. Other than the name, nothing is known about it. Gawyn Trakand used this form, as well as The Creeper Embraces the Oak and The Moon Rises Over the Lakes, when he fought Aiel after the Battle of Dumai's Wells.

The Fall of Aleth-Loriel.name: The Fall of Aleth-Loriel
The Fall of Aleth-Loriel.overview:
“The Bargain of Rogosh Eagle-eye” wound its way to an end, but Thom paused only to wet his throat from a mug of ale before launching into “Lian’s Stand.” In turn that was followed by “The Fall of Aleth-Loriel."

-The Eye of the World, Chapter 17

The Falling Leaf.name: The Falling Leaf
The Falling Leaf.overview: The Falling Leaf is a sword form. Other than the name, nothing is known about it. Rand al'Thor used this form against Ishamael during thier battle in the sky over Falme.

The Farrier's Green.name: The Farrier's Green
The Farrier's Green.overview: The Farrier's Green is a tavern in Caemlyn. It was the location where Jowdry was murdered by the gholam. Matrim Cauthon heard of this when he was dicing in the city.

The Fires of Heaven.name: The Fires of Heaven
The Fires of Heaven.overview: The Fires of Heaven (abbreviated tFoH ) is the fifth book in The Wheel of Time series. It was published by Tor Books ↗ and released on October 15, 1993. It is 992 pages long.

The Flame, the Blade and the Heart.name: The Flame, the Blade and the Heart
The Flame, the Blade and the Heart.overview:
The Flame, the Blade and the Heart is a book of romantic adventure stories. It tells the tales of Birgitte and Gaidal Cain, Anselan and Barashelle, and Rogosh and Dunsinin among others.

It seems to be a favorite among both young ladies and grown women who like the idea of romance and adventure. Aviendha lends a copy to Egwene and Romanda Cassin considers that her love of such novels would ruin her reputation as an Aes Sedai and a woman born in Far Madding.

The Gates of Heaven.name: The Gates of Heaven
The Gates of Heaven.overview:
The Gates of Heaven is an inn located in the Kandori city of Canluum. It is generally considered the best inn in the city and consists of four stories. It is located at the foot of Stag's Stand, the tallest hill in the city, in an upmarket area with many shops and eateries catering to the nobility and rich merchant classes. In 979 NE, it's proprietor was Master Helvin and among the staff was a stableman named Kazin.

Moiraine Damodred was one of six Aes Sedai staying at the inn in early 979 NE. She met Cadsuane Melaidhrin here and narrowly evaded being detained and questioned by her.

The Gathering Storm.name: The Gathering Storm
The Gathering Storm.overview:
The Gathering Storm (abbreviated tGS ) is the twelfth book in The Wheel of Time series. It was originally thought that it would be under the supertitle A Memory of Light, but is now being marketed as 'Book Twelve'. The Gathering Storm is the first of three novels that make up what was planned as A Memory of Light.

While the final novel, A Memory of Light, according to author Robert Jordan, was originally to have been released in one large volume "whether it is 1500 pages long, Tor has to invent a new binding system, or it comes with its own library cart", it was announced on March 25, 2009 that a decision has been reached by Tor Books ↗, Harriet Rigney, and Brandon Sanderson to release it in three parts, starting on 27 October 2009. It is 1120 pages long.

The Golden Barge.name: The Golden Barge
The Golden Barge.overview: The Golden Barge is an inn in So Habor, a city in Altara.

The Golden Crown of Heaven.name: The Golden Crown of Heaven
The Golden Crown of Heaven.overview: The Golden Crown of Heaven is a poor inn located in the Rahad district of the city of Ebou Dar. The grandiose name seems out of keeping with its dilapidated appearance and dubious clientele.

The Golden Cup.name: The Golden Cup
The Golden Cup.overview:
For the inn in Tanchico, see Inn of the Golden Cup .

The Golden Cup is an inn in the city of Tear. Mat and Thom find Comar there when they are looking for Elayne, Nynaeve and Egwene. Comar is gambling using two sets of dice to win from the locals. Mat gambles with him and wins even though they used the same loaded dice. He then confronts Comar, and after a brief scuffle Mat manages to toss him on to a table which unintentionally breaks his back. The innkeeper promises to give the Defenders a different description for the killer, a man he dreamed of the previous night which matches the description of Rand.

The Golden Ducks.name: The Golden Ducks
The Golden Ducks.overview:
The Golden Ducks is an inn in Ebou Dar. Nothings is known about the appearance of The Golden Ducks, as it has only been mentioned.

Noal Charin was staying in The Golden Ducks until he was kicked out by Seanchan immigrants.

The Golden Head.name: The Golden Head
The Golden Head.overview:
The Golden Head is an inn in Amador. As it is only referenced in passing, nothing is known about the location or appearance of the building.

The Golden Head is where Morgase Trakand instructs Lamgwin Dorn to wait while she tries to flee the Children of the Light.

The Golden Stag.name: The Golden Stag
The Golden Stag.overview:
The Golden Stag is a inn in Maerone, Cairhien.

It is the second best inn in town, located close to the centre. Inside, it has polished tables and benches with rose-carved legs throughout the high beamed ceiling common room. The plaster walls have blue-and gold scrollwork and the fireplaces were well-dressed stone, their hearths decorated with a few evergreen branches, a stag chiseled above each lintel. There is one clock

Mistress Daelvin is the innkeeper and Betse Silvin is a serving maid there.

Mat and the officers and lords in the Band stayed there for a time.

The Golden Swans of Heaven.name: The Golden Swans of Heaven
The Golden Swans of Heaven.overview: The Golden Swans of Heaven is an inn located in Ebou Dar, capital of Altara. Despite the grandiose name, the inn is very small and is squashed between a stable and a shop. The innkeeper's name is Darnella Shoran.

The Golden Wheel.name: The Golden Wheel
The Golden Wheel.overview:
The Golden Wheel is an inn in Far Madding. It is situated just off the Avharin Market. It has a long, beam-ceilinged common room bigger than the common room in The Counsel's Head with small square tables with a yellow painted arch into the separate Women's Room which is forbidden to men. The innkeeper is Mistress Gallger. The staff wear aprons with a yellow wagon wheel embroidered on them.

Rand enters the inn with drawings, looking for Torval, Kisman and the other renegade Asha'man. A serving man thinks the drawing of Torval looks like one of the patrons and Rand waits, listening to the talk of the common room. The man is from Illian however, not Tarabon, and has more weight and more years than Torval.

The Good Night's Ride.name: The Good Night's Ride
The Good Night's Ride.overview:
The Good Night's Ride is an inn in Lugard run by Duranda Tharne.

Duranda is an eyes-and-ears for the Blue Ajah. Siuan Sanche goes to see her to get information on where the Blue Ajah went when the White Tower broke.

The Good Queen.name: The Good Queen
The Good Queen.overview:
The Good Queen is an inn located in the city of Aringill, in Andor.

In 999 NE the innkeeper was Jeral Florry.

The Goose and Crown.name: The Goose and Crown
The Goose and Crown.overview: The Goose and Crown is an inn located in a village east of Carysford and about a day's ride from Caemlyn. Rand al'Thor and Mat Cauthon approached the inn, but then hid when they saw the innkeeper talking to a Myrddraal. They were then offered a lift into Caemlyn by cart-driver Almen Bunt.

The Grapevine Twines.name: The Grapevine Twines
The Grapevine Twines.overview: The Grapevine Twines is a sword form. Aside from the name, nothing is known about it. Rand al'Thor used this form during his practice duel with five other men in Caemlyn.

The Great Gathering.name: The Great Gathering
The Great Gathering.overview:
The Great Gathering is an inn in the Black Tower run by Lind Taglien and her husband Frask.

It has been transformed from a warehouse, though the process is still in progress and not all the tables and chairs match. It has an extensive library and an upper floor with guest rooms and dining chambers. Lind keeps a tight reign on it, and there is rarely any real trouble.

The Great Hunt.name: The Great Hunt
The Great Hunt.overview: The Great Hunt (abbreviated tGH ) is the second book in The Wheel of Time series. It was published by Tor Books and released on November 15, 1990. It is 705 pages long.

The Great Hunt of the Horn.name: The Great Hunt of the Horn
The Great Hunt of the Horn.overview: The Great Hunt of the Horn is an epic told by gleemen of the heroes of the third age that have traveled the length and breadth of the world searching for the Horn of Valere, usually after an official hunt has been called by Illian. The Horn is a sacred relic from the age before the age of legends, said to call heroes back from the grave.

The Great Tree.name: The Great Tree
The Great Tree.overview: The Great Tree is a inn in the capital city of Cairhien. It is located in the older parts of the city and is frequented by wealthier peoples of higher class than that of the Foregate. It is run by Mistress Tiedra. Verin Sedai frequents the inn when she is in Cairhien and brings Rand, Mat, Perrin, Loial, Hurin and Lord Ingtar to the inn after the Horn of Valere is stolen.

The Happy Throng.name: The Happy Throng
The Happy Throng.overview: The Happy Throng is an inn in Caemlyn. It is owned by Master Denezel.

The Harilin's Leap.name: The Harilin's Leap
The Harilin's Leap.overview: Harilin's Leap is an inn in Jarra, Ghealdan.

The Heron Spreads Its Wings.name: The Heron Spreads Its Wings
The Heron Spreads Its Wings.overview:
The Heron Spreads Its Wings is a sword form. Other than the name, nothing is known about it. Rand al'Thor flowed through this form to cut down a group of Trollocs after stealing back the Horn of Valere from Padan Fain.

The name of the form is probably an allusion to a common Tai Chi form called White Crane Spreads Its Wings

The History of the Stone of Tear.name: The History of the Stone of Tear
The History of the Stone of Tear.overview: The History of the Stone of Tear is a book that Rand had in his room two weeks after taking Callandor

The Hoop and Arrow.name: The Hoop and Arrow
The Hoop and Arrow.overview:
The Hoop and Arrow is an inn in Caemlyn, in the New City.

Master Harnder visits Millis Fendry, the innkeeper, every three to four days.

The Ionin Spring Inn.name: The Ionin Spring Inn
The Ionin Spring Inn.overview:
The Ionin Spring Inn is an establishment in Ionin Spring, a village in Altara.

When Egwene al'Vere enters Tel'aran'rhiod physically to travel to Salidar, she identifies the name of the village she is in by the name of the inn.

The Killers of the Black Veil.name: The Killers of the Black Veil
The Killers of the Black Veil.overview: The Killers of the Black Veil, by Soran Milo is a book about the Aiel. Rand al'Thor read the book in Tear to find that there was a Portal Stone near Rhuidean.

The King's Lancer (inn).name: The King's Lancer (inn)
The King's Lancer (inn).overview: King's Lancer is an inn in Sienda in Amadicia. One of the boar horses with Valan Luca 's menagerie took offense at the inn sign and tore down the sign and damaged the inn. Some of the guests had to leave after the damage.

The Kingfisher Takes a Silverback.name: The Kingfisher Takes a Silverback
The Kingfisher Takes a Silverback.overview: The Kingfisher Takes a Silverback is a sword form. Other than the name, nothing is known about it. Rand al'Thor used this form against Ishamael during their battle in the sky over Falme.

The last embrace of the mother.name: The last embrace of the mother
The last embrace of the mother.overview: It is a Shienaran tradition to bury their dead naked, without a burial shroud or coffin. This burial is called the last embrace of the mother.

The Last Ride of Buad of Albhain.name: The Last Ride of Buad of Albhain
The Last Ride of Buad of Albhain.overview: Buad of Albhain is a historical character bound to the Wheel of Time as a Hero of the Horn, who is part of the legendary saga of The Great Hunt of the Horn - specifically a tale called The Last Ride of Buad of Albhain.

The Light of Truth.name: The Light of Truth
The Light of Truth.overview:
The Light of Truth is an inn in Sienda run by Mistress Jharen.

It is, as the name might suggest, frequented by Children of the Light.

The Lion Springs.name: The Lion Springs
The Lion Springs.overview: The Lion Springs is a sword form. The movement of the form is unknown. Eamon Valda flowed from The Swallow Takes Flight into this form after Galadedrid Damodred tried to use Threading the Needle.

The Long Man.name: The Long Man
The Long Man.overview: The Long Man is an inn in Cairhien.

The Marella Inn.name: The Marella Inn
The Marella Inn.overview:
The Marella Inn is an establishment in Marella, a village in Altara.

When Egwene al'Vere enters Tel'aran'rhiod physically to travel to Salidar, she identifies the village she is in by the name of the inn.

The Marriage Knife.name: The Marriage Knife
The Marriage Knife.overview: The Marriage Knife is an small inn which Elayne Trakand 's party stayed in during their journey from Salidar to Ebou Dar to search for the Bowl of the Winds.

The Mire.name: The Mire
The Mire.overview: The Mire is the name given to the lowland swamp located east of the Waterwood. It lies adjacent to the junction of the Tarendrelle and Manetherendrelle rivers.

The Moon Rises Over the Lakes.name: The Moon Rises Over the Lakes
The Moon Rises Over the Lakes.overview: The Moon Rises Over the Lakes is a sword form. It is a way to unsheath the sword, but can also be used once the sword is out of its scabbard. When ambushed by Trollocs in Cairhien, Rand al'Thor killed one of them with this form. Gawyn Trakand also used this form, as well as The Falcon Stoops and The Creeper Embraces the Oak, when he fought Aiel after the Battle of Dumai's Wells.

The Moon Rises Over Water.name: The Moon Rises Over Water
The Moon Rises Over Water.overview: The Moon Rises Over Water is a sword form. The movement of the sword form is a slashing movement. Rand al'Thor used this form when battling his reflections from a bubble of evil in the Stone of Tear. Rand later used the form with a sword wrought from saidin in Rhuidean while escaping another bubble of evil with Matrim Cauthon.

The Nine Horse Hitch (inn).name: The Nine Horse Hitch (inn)
The Nine Horse Hitch (inn).overview:
The Nine Horse Hitch is an inn in Lugard.

Siuan Sanche, Leane Sharif, Min Farshaw and Logain Ablar stop there briefly while Siuan tries to find out where the Blue Ajah is located.

The Nine Rings (inn).name: The Nine Rings (inn)
The Nine Rings (inn).overview:
For other uses of the term, see The Nine Rings .

The Nine Rings is an inn in Cairhien where Rand al'Thor stays with Selene, Hurin and Loial.

The Nine Rings (story).name: The Nine Rings (story)
The Nine Rings (story).overview:
For other uses of the term, see The Nine Rings .

The Nine Rings is one of Rand al'Thor 's favorite adventure stories.

The Oak and Thorn.name: The Oak and Thorn
The Oak and Thorn.overview:
The Oak and Thorn is an inn in Amador. As it is only referenced in passing, nothing is known about the location or appearance of the building.

The Oak and Thorn is where Morgase Trakand instructs Martyn Tallanvor to wait while she tries to flee the Children of the Light.

The Oarsman's Pride.name: The Oarsman's Pride
The Oarsman's Pride.overview:
The Oarsman's Pride is an inn in Ebou Dar. It is near the River Eldar. Nothing is known about the appearance of the inn.

When Nynaeve al'Meara is crossing the river, Moghedien uses balefire on her boat from the top of The Oarsman's Pride.

The Old Sheep.name: The Old Sheep
The Old Sheep.overview:
The Old Sheep is an inn in Ebou Dar. Its location in the city and the appearance of the building is not known.

A serving maid, Maylin, is talking about rumors of riots when Mat Cauthon went looking for Olver.

The Path of Daggers.name: The Path of Daggers
The Path of Daggers.overview:
The Path of Daggers (abbreviated as tPoD ) is the eighth book in The Wheel of Time series. It was published by Tor Books and released on October 20, 1998. Upon its release, it immediately rose to the #1 position on the New York Times hardcover fiction bestseller list, making it the first Wheel of Time book to reach the #1 position on that list. It remained on the list for the next two months. It is 685 pages long, making it the shortest book in the main series.

The title of the book is a reference to a Seanchan saying: "On the heights, the paths are paved with daggers."

The Plowman's Blade.name: The Plowman's Blade
The Plowman's Blade.overview:
The Plowman's Blade is an inn located in the Kandori village of Manala, on the road from Canluum to Chachin. It has two stories and a red roof. Like many inns in the Borderlands it does not have windows on the ground floor, only arrow-slits to aid in defense against Shadowspawn attacks. The inn is named for the local agricultural trade, which helps feed the larger nearby settlements of Canluum and Chachin. In 979 NE the innkeeper was one Mistress Tomichi.

Moiraine Damodred, al'Lan Mandragoran, Ryne Venamar, and Bukama Marenellin stopped at the inn for breakfast on their way to Chachin in 979.

The Prince of the Ravens.name: The Prince of the Ravens
The Prince of the Ravens.overview:
The Prince of the Ravens is a Seanchan title given to the husband of the Daughter of the Nine Moons. The title derives from the ravens' use as an emblem of the Seanchan Imperial family. It can be speculated that this title is also granted to any male member of the Seanchan Imperial family who stands in line to ascend the Crystal Throne. Alternatively, if a female were to be heir, the title might be changed to "Princess of the Ravens."

When Tuon Athaem Kore Paendrag completed the Seanchan marriage ceremony, Matrim Cauthon became the Prince of the Ravens. After Tuon was raised to become the new Empress of the Seanchan Empire, she continued to refer to Mat by that title, suggesting that this elite status will remain unchanged throughout his lifetime.

The Proper Taming of Power.name: The Proper Taming of Power
The Proper Taming of Power.overview: The Proper Taming of Power is a book read by Cadsuane.

The Queen's Blessing.name: The Queen's Blessing
The Queen's Blessing.overview:
The Queen's Blessing is an inn located in the city of Caemlyn, capital of Andor. It is a fairly broad stone building with a large common room, a decent kitchen, several private rooms, an attached stable and even a small library.

In 998 NE the innkeeper was Basel Gill. Other staff included the cook, several maids and a strongarm to guard the door, named Lamgwin Dorn. Rand al'Thor and Mat Cauthon were directed to the Queen's Blessing by Thom Merrilin, a friend of Gill's, and there were reunited with Perrin, Egwene, Moiraine and Lan here. It was also here where Rand al'Thor first met Loial. The Queen's Blessing was a meeting point for those who supported Queen Morgase during the tensions that plagued the city over the parading of Logain through the city.

After Rand's visit, the inn enjoyed peace for a time, until Morgase had to flee the city and Martyn Tallanvor enlisted Basel Gill and Lamgwin's aid in helping them escape.

The Queen's Glory in Radiance.name: The Queen's Glory in Radiance
The Queen's Glory in Radiance.overview: The Queen's Glory in Radiance is a tavern in Ebou Dar. It is one of the grimiest tavern in the city, keeping with Ebou Dari tradition that grandiose names are used for the lowest of places.

The Queen's Lance.name: The Queen's Lance
The Queen's Lance.overview: The Queen's Lance is an inn in the town of Kayacun in Saldaea.

The Queen's Man.name: The Queen's Man
The Queen's Man.overview:
The Queen's Man is an inn located in a small village on the Caemlyn Road, east of Market Sheran. Rand al'Thor and Matrim Cauthon are here briefly. The name refers to the Queens of Andor.

Rand thinks of it as being "no bigger than the Winespring Inn " and then reflects that it seemed strange to think of it as being small, since he once imagined anything bigger as being a palace. Prices here are not as high as Market Sheran, but they still could not afford a room or even a meal.

Subsequently, they spent the night in the inn's stable, where they were attacked by the Darkfriend Mili Skane. They evaded her attack, Mat threatening her with the cursed dagger from Shadar Logoth, allowing their escape.

The River Queen.name: The River Queen
The River Queen.overview:
The River Queen is a riverboat that travels the River Mora and the River Erinin.

The River Serpent is one of the ships that brings the Amyrlin and party to Shienar and then returns them to Tar Valon. The ships are docked at Medo where Nynaeve and Egwene board.. Egwene and Nynaeve receive lessons on the way.

The River Undercuts the Bank.name: The River Undercuts the Bank
The River Undercuts the Bank.overview: The River Undercuts the Bank is a sword form.

The Rose of Eldar.name: The Rose of Eldar
The Rose of Eldar.overview:
The Rose of Eldar is a tavern in Ebou Dar, located near the River Eldar. It is a cheap tavern where they keep the dented tin cups chained to benches outside.

Mat Cauthon uses The Rose of Eldar as a place to sit and watch a house owned by the Kin. He sits at the tavern with Nalesean Aldiaya, Juilin Sandar, and Thomdril Merrilin.

The Rose Unfolds.name: The Rose Unfolds
The Rose Unfolds.overview: The Rose Unfolds is a sword form. Other than the name, nothing is known about it. Lan Mandragoran once used this form to slice down an assassin's arm.

The Royal Inn.name: The Royal Inn
The Royal Inn.overview:
The Royal Inn is an inn in Four Kings and is one of the better-appointed inns in the town.

Howal Gode visited the Royal Inn whilst searching for Rand al'Thor and Mat Cauthon. News of his odd behavior there later reached the staff of the Dancing Cartman, alerting Rand and Mat to his status as a Darkfriend.

The Ruffled Goose.name: The Ruffled Goose
The Ruffled Goose.overview:
The Ruffled Goose is an inn located in the Kandori capital of Chachin. It is located within the first ringwall of the city in a disreputable, run-down district.

Moiraine Damodred visited the inn in 979 NE, whilst trying to find Siuan Sanche for an arranged rendezvous. Her horse, Arrow, was almost stolen whilst she was inside.

The Serpents Tongue Dances.name: The Serpents Tongue Dances
The Serpents Tongue Dances.overview: The Serpents Tongue Dances is a sword form. Other than the name, nothing is known about it.

The Seven-Striped Lass.name: The Seven-Striped Lass
The Seven-Striped Lass.overview:
The Seven-Striped Lass is one of the finest taverns and kept clean. Located in western Caemlyn, it busily caters to farmers and nobles.

Melli Craeb is the tavernkeeper and Berg is the tough doorman.

The Shadow Rising.name: The Shadow Rising
The Shadow Rising.overview: The Shadow Rising (abbreviated tSR ) is the fourth book in The Wheel of Time series. It was published by Tor Books and released on September 15, 1992. It is 1004 pages long.

The Shaken Fist.name: The Shaken Fist
The Shaken Fist.overview: The Shaken Fist is an inn located in the village of Trustair in Murandy. Verin Mathwin is staying at the inn while trying to reach Mat Cauthon.

The Siege of the Pillars of the Sky.name: The Siege of the Pillars of the Sky
The Siege of the Pillars of the Sky.overview: A story known and performed by Thom, and one of many tales he knew. It is mentioned on the steps of the Winespring Inn in Emond's Field just before the winternight battle.

The Silver Dolphin.name: The Silver Dolphin
The Silver Dolphin.overview: The Silver Dolphin is an inn in the City of Illian.

The Silver Penny.name: The Silver Penny
The Silver Penny.overview:
The Silver Penny is an inn located in the Kandori capital of Chachin. It is located within the first ringwall of the city in a disreputable, run-down district. Despite its unsavory surroundings, the inn itself was mostly clean and relatively hospitable compared to its neighbors.

Moiraine Damodred visited the inn in 979 NE, whilst trying to find Siuan Sanche for an arranged rendezvous. The innkeeper, Nedare Satarov, attempted to drug Moiraine for unknown but presumably unsavory purposes, until Moiraine made her drink the drug instead.

The Silver Swan.name: The Silver Swan
The Silver Swan.overview: The Silver Swan is an inn in Caemlyn which seems to be one of the best in the city and one of the Aes Sedai preferred places in the capital.

The Southern Hoop.name: The Southern Hoop
The Southern Hoop.overview: The Southern Hoop is an inn in So Tehar, Altara.

The Stag and Lion.name: The Stag and Lion
The Stag and Lion.overview: The Stag and Lion is a prominent inn in Baerlon. It is four stories tall, and run by Master Fitch. It is notable for being the first inn in which the Emond's Fielders stayed after they left the Two Rivers following the Winternight attack. Min Farshaw worked there until the inn burned down following an infiltration by a Fade; she then went to Tar Valon while the inn was being rebuilt by Master Fitch with Tar Valon gold. The Two Rivers folk were reunited with Nynaeve at the inn and set out from there on the fateful path that took them to Shadar Logoth.

The Star.name: The Star
The Star.overview:
The Star is an inn in the city of Tear run by Jurah Haret.

Perrin, Loial, Moiraine, Lan and Faile stay there when they arrive in Tear, chasing after Rand. There is a weaver's shop on one side and a smithy on the other which combined make the inn quite noisy. It stands four stories tall and has small windows in its roof as well. Perrin worked in the smithy run by Dermid Ajala while Moiraine was looking for Rand.

The Stranded Goose.name: The Stranded Goose
The Stranded Goose.overview:
The Stranded Goose is an inn in the east side of Ebou Dar. It is a large, three story building.

When Setalle Anan is taking Elayne Trakand and Nynaeve al'Meara to the Kin, she stops at The Stranded Goose.

The Strike at Shayol Ghul.name: The Strike at Shayol Ghul
The Strike at Shayol Ghul.overview: The Strike at Shayol Ghul was a short piece written by Robert Jordan in 1996 to explain the events surrounding the imprisonment of the Dark One and the circumstances surrounding it.

The Swallow Rides the Air.name: The Swallow Rides the Air
The Swallow Rides the Air.overview: The Swallow Rides the Air is a sword form. Aside from the name, nothing is known about it. Rand al'Thor used this form against Ishamael during thier battle in the sky over Falme.

The Swallow Takes Flight.name: The Swallow Takes Flight
The Swallow Takes Flight.overview:
For the similarly named sword form, see The Swallow Rides the Air .

The Swallow Takes Flight is a sword form. Other than the name, nothing is known about it.

The Thousand Tales of Anla.name: The Thousand Tales of Anla
The Thousand Tales of Anla.overview: The Thousand Tales of Anla the Wise Counselor is one of the fables that Thom hints at performing as he is waiting for a larger crowd outside of The Winespring Inn.

The Three Moons.name: The Three Moons
The Three Moons.overview: The Three Moons is an inn in the City of Tear, not far from The Dragon.

The Three Plum Court.name: The Three Plum Court
The Three Plum Court.overview: The Three Plum Court is an inn in Tanchico. The innkeeper's name is Rendra. Special dining rooms at Three Plum Court include the Chamber of Falling Blossoms.

The Three Stars.name: The Three Stars
The Three Stars.overview:
The Three Stars is an inn in Ebou Dar. Nothing is known about the location or appearance of the building.

In 1000 NE, Tuon Athaem Kore Paendrag tell Beslan Mitsobar that she is aware of the treasonous meetings he had with General Habiger and Lord Malalin at The Three Stars.

The Tipsy Gelding (inn).name: The Tipsy Gelding (inn)
The Tipsy Gelding (inn).overview:
The Tipsy Gelding is an inn located in the village of Hinderstap Murandy. The inn is three streets out from the center of town in the back west corner of the village. In the opinion of Mat Cauthon, the establishment is more of a tavern than an inn.

The night when Mat, Thom, Joline, Teslyn and Edesina are sleeping in Hinderstap, they are attacked inside this inn by the crazy people of the village.

The Towers of Midnight.name: The Towers of Midnight
The Towers of Midnight.overview:
The Towers of Midnight are a complex of thirteen fortresses built from unpolished black marble located within the city of Imfaral on the Seanchan continent. The Towers of Midnight are first noted in history as the place where Deain, the creator of the a'dam, was imprisoned after being betrayed by Luthair Paendrag Mondwin during The Conquest.

The Towers of Midnight and the city of Imfaral were captured early during Luthair's invasion, and were the primary base of operations for the invaders before they took Seandar later in the war.

Since the Consolidation, the Towers have remained unoccupied. Legend has it that when a time of dire need comes, the Imperial family will return to the Towers and "right that which is wrong".

The Travels of Jain Farstrider.name: The Travels of Jain Farstrider
The Travels of Jain Farstrider.overview: The Travels of Jain Farstrider is a famous book written by Jain Farstrider. Published in the year 968 NE, it consists largely of his travels across the world, including stories of the highly mysterious land of Shara beyond the Aiel Waste, encounters with the Sea Folk, and numerous fantastic adventures. The popular book appears in libraries across the Westlands, from an inn in Caemlyn to small personal libraries on remote farms.

The Treasures of the Stone of Tear.name: The Treasures of the Stone of Tear
The Treasures of the Stone of Tear.overview: The Treasures of the Stone of Tear is a book that Rand studied in the Stone of Tear.

The Tremalking Splice.name: The Tremalking Splice
The Tremalking Splice.overview: The Tremalking Splice is a tavern in Tar Valon where Mat Cauthon finds himself at the end of a night of gambling.

The Twelve Salt Wells.name: The Twelve Salt Wells
The Twelve Salt Wells.overview:
The Twelve Salt Wells in an inn in Jurador. It is a large building made of stone.

Mat Cauthon buys a razor for Tuon at a stable next to The Twelve Salt Wells.

The Two Apples.name: The Two Apples
The Two Apples.overview: The Two Apples is an inn in Caemlyn, one of the better quality inns in that particular district. Thom Merrillin plays there while waiting to go to the Tower of Ghenjei.

The Viper Flicks Its Tongue.name: The Viper Flicks Its Tongue
The Viper Flicks Its Tongue.overview: The Viper Flicks Its Tongue is a sword form. It can be used when a swordsman fights alone, but it is more effective when used with an ally. Sleete used this form when he and Marlesh practiced against Gawyn Trakand in the village of Dorian. Gawyn countered with Cat Dances on the Wall.

The Wagon Seat.name: The Wagon Seat
The Wagon Seat.overview:
The Wagon Seat is a red-roofed inn in Lugard, Murandy. It bears a sign with an explicit interpretation of the name.

Gareth Bryne meets Joni and Barim in the inn. They were asking questions in the town about Siuan and the other girls. He thinks the singer, in her revealing blouse, would have found a husband in short order in any soldiers' camp.

The Wake of the Breaking.name: The Wake of the Breaking
The Wake of the Breaking.overview: The Wake of the Breaking is a history book that Min was reading in Arad Doman.

The Wandering Woman.name: The Wandering Woman
The Wandering Woman.overview:
For the chapter in Lord of Chaos called "The Wandering Woman", see Lord of Chaos/Chapter 47 .

The Wandering Woman is an inn in Ebou Dar situated near the Tarasin Palace.. It is currently owned by Lydel Elonid and previously owned by Setalle Anan. For a time, Matrim Cauthon and the members of the Band of the Red Hand who accompanied him to the city stayed there. After the Seanchan invaded, Setalle hid Joline Maza and her Warders in the cellar.

The Watchers Over the Waves.name: The Watchers Over the Waves
The Watchers Over the Waves.overview:
The Watchers Over the Waves or Do Miere A'vron were a group of people who believed that the armies Artur Hawkwing sent across the Aryth Ocean would someday return. They were located in the Almoth Plain, along the coast of Toman Head, primarily in the town of Falme.

The Watchers built watchtowers along the coast. Their leader was called the First Watcher. The Do Meire A'vron were mentioned in the Karaethon Cycle. It was said that "above the Watchers shall he proclaim himself." Rand al'Thor first accepted the mantle of the Dragon Reborn above Falme when the Horn of Valere was sounded.

When the Seanchan appeared in Falme the Do Meire A'vron were punished. The First Watcher was placed in a cage, hung from one of their towers overlooking the harbor in Falme, and left to die. When the First Watcher died another was named and placed in the cage. The Seanchan claimed the Watchers over the Waves had "watched for the wrong thing, and forgot what they should have been remembering."

The Way of the Light.name: The Way of the Light
The Way of the Light.overview: The Way of the Light is a philosophical treatise written by Lothair Mantelar, the founder of the Children of the Light during the War of the Hundred Years. In it, he outlined a humble, simple life dedicated to serving the Light that he believed all should follow. He also asserted that touching the True Source was for the Creator alone, and that those humans who wielded it (namely Aes Sedai ) were Darkfriends. The book became the basis for the ideology of the Children of the Light.

The Wayfarers' Rest.name: The Wayfarers' Rest
The Wayfarers' Rest.overview:
The Wayfarers' Rest is an inn located in the town of Whitebridge in Andor. It is on the main square where the White Bridge meets the east bank of the Arinelle. It is a reasonably large establishment with the common room divided in half by a low wall, designed so that feuding ship crews can be separated into areas where they are unlikely to run into one another. The inn is owned and run by Master Bartim.

Rand al'Thor, Mat Cauthon and Thom Merrilin visited the Wayfarers' Rest on their way to Caemlyn, and learned from Bartim about the defeat of the false Dragon Logain Ablar. Bartim also told them that a crazed man had passed through the town searching for them a week earlier. Rand and his cohorts had an altercation with Floran Gelb whilst leaving the inn and were attacked by a Myrddraal in the square outside, resulting in a battle that saw several buildings damaged by fire. Moiraine Damodred, Lan Mandragoran, and Nynaeve al'Meara later passed through the town and had a meal at the Wayfarers' Rest before continuing their pursuit of Rand and Mat.

The Wayland's Forge.name: The Wayland's Forge
The Wayland's Forge.overview: Wayland's Forge is an inn in Remen on the Ghealdan / Murandy border.

The Wheel of Time.name: The Wheel of Time
The Wheel of Time.overview:
The Wheel of Time (abbreviated as WoT by fans) is a bestselling series of epic fantasy novels written by the American author James Oliver Rigney, Jr. under the pen name Robert Jordan. Originally planned as a six-book series, it now consists of fourteen published novels. The series also includes a stand-alone prequel novel and a companion book. The author began writing the first volume, The Eye of the World, in 1984 and it was published in 1990. The eleventh volume was published in 2005. The author passed away in September 2007 while working on the final volume, A Memory of Light. Fellow fantasy writer Brandon Sanderson was to complete the final volume for publication in late 2009, however due to the size it was decided that Jordan's A Memory of Light would be divided into three separate novels. The first of the three, The Gathering Storm was released October 27th, 2009, with the others to follow at one-year intervals. The second of the three, Towers of Midnight, was released November 2nd, 2010. The fourteenth and ultimate volume in the series, A Memory of Light, was released January 8th, 2013.

The series is noted for its length, its well-developed magic system, the extremely large numbers of subplots, the intricate detail of its imaginary world, and the extremely large number of characters (there are more than 1,800 named characters in the series). The series proved a success from the start, selling out of its original American print run in just a few months. The eighth through eleventh volumes each debuted at #1 on the New York Times bestseller list. As of August 2019, the series had sold 90 million copies worldwide. The series has spawned several games, and even a soundtrack. In April 2016, it was confirmed that the books were being adapted as a TV series.

The Wheel of Time (book).name: The Wheel of Time (book)
The Wheel of Time (book).overview: The Wheel of Time is a historical work produced by Sulamein so Bhagad, the Chief Historian at the Court of the Sun in the Fourth Age.

The Wheel of Time Companion.name: The Wheel of Time Companion
The Wheel of Time Companion.overview:
The Wheel of Time Companion is an encyclopedia and guidebook to the world of The Wheel of Time. It was published in November 2015. It was written by Harriet McDougal, Robert Jordan 's widow and editor, with the assistance of Maria Simons and Alan Romanczuk. Maria and Alan were Robert Jordan's writing assistants and fact-checkers during the writing of most of the novels of the main series. The book draws heavily upon Robert Jordan's unpublished notes and outlines for the series.

The companion is the second guide to the series to be published, following The World of Robert Jordan's The Wheel of Time, published in 1997. The companion is a new work, not merely an updated version of the older book.

The book features a comprehensive guide to many of the characters in the series, along with a 1,000-word vocabulary of the Old Tongue, new maps depicting the Last Battle (including one of Thakan'dar ), new portraits of many of the characters, detailed information on the nations of the world, descriptions of flora and fauna, and information on the relative strengths of different channelers.

The book features new artwork commissioned by Irene Gallo at Tor Books.

The White Boar.name: The White Boar
The White Boar.overview:
The White Boar is an inn located in Watch Hill in the Two Rivers. It sits at the crest of the hill and is visible for some distance around the village. It has a distinctive tile roof, the only inn in Watch Hill to do so.

During their original flight from the Two Rivers, Rand al'Thor and Mat Cauthon heard the sounds of merry-making from the tavern and wished they could stop for a meal at the White Boar, but the appearance of a Draghkar changed their minds.

Later, during the Whitecloak occupation of the Two Rivers, Dain Bornhald sometimes drunk in the inn, hoping the locals would relax and feed him information. After the Whitecloaks were ejected from the district, the banner of Manetheren was raised above the inn, as foreseen by Perrin Aybara in a wolf dream.

The White Crescent.name: The White Crescent
The White Crescent.overview: The White Crescent is an inn in the city of Tear run by Cavan Lopar. Mat and Thom stayed there whilst searching for Elayne, Nynaeve, Egwene, and their pursuer, the Darkfriend Comar.

The White Ring.name: The White Ring
The White Ring.overview: The White Ring is an inn in the town of Maderin Altara. It is the locale to which Thom Merrilin and Matrim Cauthon escort Tuon and Selucia so that Tuon may observe a hell. The two women are unaware that the inn in question is not a hell.

The White Tower.name: The White Tower
The White Tower.overview: The White Tower is both the central structure that houses Aes Sedai in Tar Valon as well as a term that describes the organization of Aes Sedai itself. The tower structure is the tallest building in Tar Valon and resides within a campus complex refered to as the "tower grounds". The compound is both home and a training facility for Aes Sedai, those seeking to become Aes Sedai, and warders who serve and protect Aes Sedai sisters. The tower structure is a bone-white spire nearly 100 spans (around 600 feet or 183 meters) in height. Its roof is flat-topped with a waist-high railing.

The White Tower (inn).name: The White Tower (inn)
The White Tower (inn).overview: The White Tower is an inn located in the Kandori village of Ravinda, on the main road from Canluum to Chachin. It was constructed in 979 NE by Avene Sahera, a recipient of the bounty awarded by the Amyrlin Seat Tamra Ospenya to all women who gave birth during the Battle of the Shining Walls. Sahera named it in honor of the Aes Sedai and thanks for the bounty. Moiraine Damodred visited the inn while it was under construction and believed that it was unlikely the Aes Sedai would approve of the name, but she did not suggest that the innkeeper change the name as she was traveling in disguise.

The Wind's Favor.name: The Wind's Favor
The Wind's Favor.overview: The Wind's Favor is an inn located in Bandar Eban. The owner is Quillin Tasil, an Andoran. Quillin is an agent for Cadsuane Melaidhrin and his daughter is Namine Tasil, an Aes Sedai of the Brown Ajah.

The wind.name: The wind
The wind.overview: The wind is a framing device used in the novels of the Wheel of Time. Each book's first chapter starts with a similarly structured paragraph:

The Wind Blows Over the Wall.name: The Wind Blows Over the Wall
The Wind Blows Over the Wall.overview: The Wind Blows Over the Wall is a sword form. Other than the name, nothing is known about it. Rand al'Thor used this form to cut off a Gray Man 's hand before driving a saidin -wrought sword through his opponent's heart.

The Wind Song Inn.name: The Wind Song Inn
The Wind Song Inn.overview: The Wind Song Inn is an inn in Falme.

The Winespring Inn.name: The Winespring Inn
The Winespring Inn.overview:
The Winespring Inn is an inn in Emond's Field owned by Brandelwyn al'Vere. It stands on the east end of the Green beside the Wagon Bridge and adjacent to the Winespring Water. Bran's wife Marin is the inn's cook.

The first floor of the inn is constructed of river rock, though built upon a foundation of much older stone quarried from the Mountains of Mist. The foundation continues south of the inn proper and represents the remnants of an older, larger structure built when Manetheren ruled the region. A large oak now grows amidst these ruins and shades an area where, in the summertime, Bran a'Vere sets tables so villagers can drink, talk, and play Stones.

The second floor is whitewashed and extends out over the lower floor for the entire perimeter. The structure has a dozen chimneys and a red tiled roof that was the first non-thatched covering in Emond's Field. Bran al'Vere lives with his family at the back of the second floor (although in TDR 49, Mat remembers them as living "at the front of the second floor.")

The Winespring Inn serves as the meeting place for the Village Council and, as one of the largest and most stout buildings in the community, exists as an excellent defensive position. Along with the village green, it is a primary focal point during annual Bel Tine festivals.

For a long time the only inn in the village, recent mass immigrations to Emond's Field have led to increased economic demands, and thus the construction of a second inn named The Archers. Recent population changes are due to an influx of refugees from Almoth Plain, Tarabon, Arad Doman and Ghealdan.

The Winter Blossom.name: The Winter Blossom
The Winter Blossom.overview:
The Winter Blossom is a respectable inn in Ebou Dar.

When Mat Cauthon returned to Ebou Dar, he stopped at The Winter Blossom. He didn't stay at the inn due to the large number of Deathwatch Guards staying there, the presence of which caused him to worry that he might encounter Furyk Karede.

The Wood Grouse Dances.name: The Wood Grouse Dances
The Wood Grouse Dances.overview: The Wood Grouse Dances is a sword form. Aside from the name, nothing is know about it.

The World of Robert Jordan's The Wheel o.name: The World of Robert Jordan's The Wheel of Time
The World of Robert Jordan's The Wheel o.overview:
The World of Robert Jordan's The Wheel of Time is a reference book for the bestselling Wheel of Time series of fantasy novels by Robert Jordan. It is published in the United States by Tor Books and in the UK by Orbit. The book was written primarily by Teresa Patterson based on detailed notes and maps provided by Robert Jordan, who also served as editor on the project. Jordan also contributed the full text of the entry The Strike at Shayol Ghul, which had previously appeared online a year or so earlier.

The book takes an in-universe tone, describing events for the reader as if they were real, rather than being a reference work that analyzes the series. It was published after the seventh book in the series, A Crown of Swords, and features a great deal of artwork, including reproductions of the first seven novel covers.
aliases: The World of Robert Jordan's Wheel of Time

The Yearly Brawl.name: The Yearly Brawl
The Yearly Brawl.overview:
The Yearly Brawl is an inn in Ebou Dar, owned and operated by the innkeeper Kathana. Kathana is married to a Seanchan immigrant named Jame who serves as the establishment's primary bouncer. The inn's sign features an image of people clapping.

Mat Cauthon stops at The Yearly Brawl, thinking it is his type of inn. He learns from Jame, the bouncer and husband of the innkeeper Kathana, that Tuon is under threat of assassins.

Thief-taker.name: Thief-taker
Thief-taker.overview: Thief-takers, called thief-catchers in Tear, are those who specialize in tracking down thieves and bandits in cities.

Third Age.name: Third Age
Third Age.overview:
The Third Age of the Wheel of Time began with the chaos and destruction of the Breaking of the World that ended the Age of Legends (the Second Age) and ended with the Last Battle, the conclusion of which marked the beginning of the Fourth Age. The Third Age is the Age in which the Wheel of Time novels take place.

The Third Age is sometimes called the Age of Prophecy, as for the entire length of its duration it has been prophesied that the Dragon will be reborn to fight and defeat the Dark One, and the Aes Sedai of the Third Age have attempted to prepare mankind for this prophesied battle.

The Third Age has lasted for almost 3,500 years and has been divided into three lesser eras: After the Breaking (1,350 years), the Free Years (1,135 years) and the New Era (1,000 years). The main sequence novels begin in the year 998 NE.

Third Rise.name: Third Rise
Third Rise.overview: The Third Rise is the name of an hour in the morning, used in Tar Valon.

Third War of Garen's Wall.name: Third War of Garen's Wall
Third War of Garen's Wall.overview:
The Third War of Garen's Wall was a military conflict fought some time around 600 NE. Historical records of this war are patchy at best, possibly due to Aes Sedai machinations. It is not even known who fought the war, although Ghealdan, which controls the ridgeline of Garen's Wall, was almost certainly involved. Altara, which lay to the east, may have also been involved, but it is also possible it was a civil war within Ghealdan itself.

Aes Sedai meddling in the records is possible due to the fact the sisters themselves teach in history classes within the White Tower that the then- Amyrlin Seat, Shein Chunla, caused the war due to bungled mishandling of the situation. However, what is not taught is that some ascribe the mistakes of this period to the Hall of the Tower of the time, which was effectively ruling by decree and overruling Chunla's authority. The situation grew so bad that Chunla and the Sitters were all deposed in a mutiny launched by the other sisters.

Records of this mutiny and Chunla's fate (smothered to death by sisters fifty years later to prevent her being reinstalled on the Amyrlin Seat) are sealed in the Thirteenth Depository of the White Tower library.

Thirteenth Depository.name: Thirteenth Depository
Thirteenth Depository.overview: The Thirteenth Depository is a set of hidden records in the Great Library of Tar Valon. These contain hidden histories open only to the Amyrlin Seat, the Keeper of the Chronicles, and the Sitters of the Hall. These histories describe events that Aes Sedai have worked hard to hide from all but the top of their own membership.

Thistledown Floats on the Whirlwind.name: Thistledown Floats on the Whirlwind
Thistledown Floats on the Whirlwind.overview: Thistledown Floats on the Whirlwind is a sword form.

Thom Grinwell.name: Thom Grinwell
Thom Grinwell.overview: Thom Grinwell is the alias Mat used when delivering Elayne's letter to Queen Morgase.

Thoughts Among the Ruins.name: Thoughts Among the Ruins
Thoughts Among the Ruins.overview: Thoughts Among the Ruins is one of Min Farshaw 's books.

Threading the Needle.name: Threading the Needle
Threading the Needle.overview: Threading the Needle is a sword form. Other than the name, nothing is known about it. Galadedrid Damodred used this form a number of times against Eamon Valda during thier Trial Beneath the Light, aiming for Valda's left shoulder. Each time, Valda used The Swallow Takes Flight to counter, until the last time, when Galad altered the stroke into Reaping the Barley, scoring a hit beneath Valda's rib cage.

Three Crowns Inn.name: Three Crowns Inn
Three Crowns Inn.overview: The Three Crowns Inn is the local inn in Aturo's Orchard. It is run by Hobbs DaVoren.

Three Geese (Constellation).name: Three Geese (Constellation)
Three Geese (Constellation).overview: One of the constellations seen over the night skies of the Westlands.

Three Oaths.name: Three Oaths
Three Oaths.overview:
Before an Accepted is raised to be Aes Sedai she must swear three oaths on a ter'angreal called an Oath Rod that completely binds her to keep those oaths. The Three Oaths are as follows:

- To speak no word that is not true.
- To make no weapon with which one man may kill another.
- Never to use the One Power as a weapon except against Darkfriends [ 1 ] or Shadowspawn , or in the last extreme defense of her life, the life of her Warder , or another Aes Sedai.

Three Plum Blossoms.name: Three Plum Blossoms
Three Plum Blossoms.overview:
Three Plum Blossoms Inn is an inn in Falme. Before the Seanchan arrived, the word "Watcher" appeared in the name but this was hastily painted out.

Nynaeve, Elayne and Min meet Bayle Domon there to discuss sailing away from Falme when they rescue Egwene from the damane quarters.

Three Toes.name: Three Toes
Three Toes.overview: Three Toes is a pack-leader of wolves.

Throne of the Clouds.name: Throne of the Clouds
Throne of the Clouds.overview:
The Throne of the Clouds is the seat of power in Kandor, located in Chachin 's Aesdaishar Palace.

It can be that the Throne is only a symbolic and simple seat or truly a ter'angreal that can somehow influence the weather, because some old legendary rulers of Kandor claimed to be able to do so (or maybe they were assisted by some Aes Sedai able in Cloud Dancing ).

Throne of the Winds.name: Throne of the Winds
Throne of the Winds.overview: The Throne of the Winds is the seat of power in Altara, located in Ebou Dar 's Tarasin Palace.

Thunder Mist.name: Thunder Mist
Thunder Mist.overview: Thunder Mist is part of Leafhunter 's pack of wolves.

Tifan's Well.name: Tifan's Well
Tifan's Well.overview: Tifan's Well is a small village and farming community in Arafel.

Tiganza.name: Tiganza
Tiganza.overview:
The tiganza is a sensual dance performed by Tuatha'an women. The dance involves shuffling steps to the slow beat of drums, small circular turns, and a slow rotation of the hips that is emphasized by the sway of a fringed shawl. It is usually done barefoot to the light of the campfire.

Perrin describes the tiganza as the Tinker women's swaying, hip-rolling dance that sets the heart pounding.

Timeline.name: Timeline
Timeline.overview:
This timeline attempts to lay out the history of the Westlands and the world based on dates and information given in the novels and supporting material.

Dates are given in the three calendar systems given in the books, namely the Toman, Gazaran and Farede calendars. For events in the Age of Legends, dates are given prior to the Breaking, since no information has been retained about dating systems used at that time.

Timsin root.name: Timsin root
Timsin root.overview: Timsin root is a root used in tea to alleviate a headache. It was once mixed with silverleaf in a tea for Mat Cauthon.

Tirish Adar.name: Tirish Adar
Tirish Adar.overview: Tirish Adar starts from the rise of the first full moon in Adar, and ends at the rise of the next moon. In most northern countries, no one sleeps more than an hour or two a night during this period.

To'raken.name: To'raken
To'raken.overview:
To'raken are animals used by the Seanchan.

Like the raken, it is roughly equal to a horse in intelligence. To'raken are larger than raken, and are unable to simply throw themselves into flight, instead requiring a running start. The to'raken are also not particularly agile fliers. Their value instead comes from their strength and endurance. They have been known to fly up to a thousand miles with only a single morat'to'raken in the saddle.

To'raken are typically used to carry valuable cargo or people who need to be transported quickly. With only a single morat aboard, a to'raken is able to carry an additional thousand pounds up to two hundred miles.

When injured, to'raken frequently refuse to fly farther than the safest landing area; however there is often a difference in opinion between the to'raken and the morat as to what constitutes a "safe landing area."

To Sail Beyond the Sunset.name: To Sail Beyond the Sunset
To Sail Beyond the Sunset.overview: To Sail Beyond the Sunset is a book that Loial was reading when Rand woke up after Falme.

Tobin's Hollow.name: Tobin's Hollow
Tobin's Hollow.overview: Tobin's Hollow is a village in Toman Head, close to the border of Almoth Plain and the village of Aturo's Orchard.

Toman Head.name: Toman Head
Toman Head.overview:
Toman Head is a peninsula that extends of the west coast of Westlands. It lies in between Arad Doman and Tarabon, claimed by neither and both, depending on the state of relations between the two nations. The only notable city on the peninsula is Falme, at the very tip.

Toman Head became famous across the Westlands when the Seanchan armies met their first defeat, at the hands of the Heroes of the Horn.

Tomanelle.name: Tomanelle
Tomanelle.overview: The Tomanelle are one of the twelve Aiel clans. Their clan hold is unknown. The Jenda sept's hold is Mainde Cut Hold.

Topless Towers.name: Topless Towers
Topless Towers.overview: The famous Topless Towers of Cairhien are among the most famous landmarks of that city.

Tora Harad.name: Tora Harad
Tora Harad.overview:
The Tora Harad was an exceptionally strong fortress known for its ability of withstand a siege. Its strength rivalled the Stone of Tear in its formidability.

Little is known of this fortress other than from Mat's memories of ancient times. It existed and presumably no longer exists today. Mat Cauthon recalled the Tora Harad whilst comparing its strength to that of Cold Rocks Hold in the Aiel Waste. It is not known if there is a link between the Tora Harad and Harad Dakar, the long-fallen capital of Hardan.

Torm.name: Torm
Torm.overview:
Torm are an exotic species from Seanchan. They resemble great cats with copper scales instead of fur and six-clawed feet that can grip the stones of the road. They also have three eyes. A torm is approximately the size of a horse. They are not widely available, and are hard to replace. The Seanchan consider it the most intelligent of their creatures, being well above that of a very bright dog, and can come close to human levels in certain areas of problem solving, such as maze tests.

Torm bear live young, and nurse them. Most torm do not reach adulthood, however, as fights for dominance between torm typically result in the death of one of the animals. Training by animal handlers prevents these fights for dominance.

Early morat'torm sought to use these intelligent animals as trackers. But each torm quickly made it clear that it hunted only what it wanted to, and nothing else. A torm is primarily carnivorous; it can survive on only plants for several days, but if deprived of meat for long, it becomes increasingly difficult to control as it attempts to hunt for food. They are the most intelligent of the Seanchan exotics, after damane, of course. They have an intelligence quotient above that of a very bright dog. In some cases, they can come close to our level in certain areas of problem solving, such as maze tests.

Any torm can outrun even the fastest horse, but riding a torm is apparently very difficult. Torm will turn and attack rider after rider, until it accepts one for no apparent reason. When a torm finally chooses its one rider, it will not allow another to ride. If a rider dies, the torm can take an extremely long time to accept another.

A torm's primary function is that of conveyance for scouting, rather than in protracted combat. It is faster than a horse, with better endurance as well. However, if in battle for too long, a torm will suffer from fighting frenzy. It rarely will turn on its rider during one of these frenzies, but will strike at anyone else within reach. Regardless of the length of combat, a torm will immediately attack any corlm within reach. Because of these factors, the risk of losing a torm in combat is too high considering their rarity and value.

- http://www.redbrick.dcu.ie/~melmoth/gc18.html

Tova.name: Tova
Tova.overview: Tova was a kingdom of the Free Years. It was founded after the end of the Trolloc Wars, and was established on the former territory of Almoren. It was later absorbed by the growing might of Artur Hawkwing's Empire. The lands it once held are now controlled by Cairhien.

Tower Guard.name: Tower Guard
Tower Guard.overview:
Tower Guards are soldiers that defend the Aes Sedai and the White Tower in the city of Tar Valon. They are led by the High Captain, who answers to the Amyrlin Seat.

12,000 Tower Guards were used in the Aiel War and were part of the Great Coalition.

Elaida, under the influence of Alviarin, decreed that the Tower Guard be increased to 50,000 men. However, how large it managed to grow before Egwene took the city is unknown.

The Tower Guard may have been part of the White Tower army during Tarmon Gai'don. It remained a separate force from the army raised by Gareth Bryne.

Tower law.name: Tower law
Tower law.overview:
Tower law is a set of decrees, laws, and statutes for governing the White Tower. As the Tower Guard is the military force of Tar Valon, they may be applied to the entire city-island.

Known laws of the White Tower at the current time:

Tower of Ghenjei.name: Tower of Ghenjei
Tower of Ghenjei.overview:
The Tower of Ghenjei is a gateway into the world of the Eelfinn and the Aelfinn.

It lies near the River Arinelle ten days north of Whitebridge, and it is a solid and spotless metal tower, two hundred feet high without any doors or windows. There is no opening on it; if one draws the symbol for the game of Snakes and Foxes on the tower's surface with a bronze knife, then a doorway will appear.

The Tower of Ghenjei is accessible through both the waking world and Tel'aran'rhiod. Once someone enters the Tower Of Ghenjei and moves away from the doorway, the doorway (probably) cannot be found again (maybe it disappears, maybe it is just a matter of orientating), and it is extremely hard to leave the Tower. Before moving away from the doorway, it is possible to leave and the doorway disappear afterwards. In Tel'aran'rhiod, the leaving is all but impossible.

Bayle Domon points out the tower to Rand al'Thor and Matrim Cauthon after Rand spots something glinting in the distance while traveling on the Spray down the Arinelle. Captain Domon says that the tower is a marker for river traders.

Tower of Morning.name: Tower of Morning
Tower of Morning.overview: Tower of Morning is a sword form. Aside from the name, nothing is known about it. Rand al'Thor flowed from Lion on the Hill to Arc of the Moon to this form when he was practicing against five other men in Caemlyn.

Tower of Ravens.name: Tower of Ravens
Tower of Ravens.overview:
The Tower of Ravens is the central imperial prison of Seanchan.

It is located in the Seanchan capital city of Seandar. It serves as the primary headquarters of the Seekers for Truth and is used to incarcerate notable criminals, especially members of The Blood. For centuries Members of the Blood have been questioned and executed within the tower, though such executions must be done without spilling a single drop of their blood.

Tower of the Full Moon.name: Tower of the Full Moon
Tower of the Full Moon.overview: A structure at the Sun Palace in Cairhien; Dobraine had rooms there where he was attacked by robbers. Usually the Tower was set aside for visiting nobility of high rank.

Towers of Midnight.name: Towers of Midnight
Towers of Midnight.overview:
Towers of Midnight (abbreviated ToM ) is the thirteenth and penultimate book in The Wheel of Time series. The working title Shifting Winds was adopted for a time, but the name was replaced at Brandon Sanderson 's urging in September 2009.

It was reportedly due for release on October 26, 2010, but it was also rumored for release in the UK on November 5, 2010. The US release date has been pushed back to November 2, 2010.

Chapter Eight "The Seven-Striped Lass" has been made available on Brandon Sanderson's blog following the "Great Hunt" puzzle event. The prologue " Distinctions " was sold on September 21, 2010 as an e-book for $2.99 on Amazon.com et al. to US/Canada residents. Chapter One "Apples First" is available to read on Tor website, while Chapter Two "Questions of Leadership" is available as an audiobook via Tor website. It is 1264 pages long.

Town.name: Town
Town.overview:
The Town is an urban centre in the Great Blight, located not far from the valley of Thakan'dar at the foot of Shayol Ghul. It is a sprawling, ramshackle settlement that has existed for over two thousand years and was constructed by forced labor.

The Town is inhabited mainly by Darkfriends and the numerous people enslaved by them. From the description it seems a very dangerous place where the laws of force, fear, and crime are rule. At the top of the hierarchy, it seems that there are the people able to impose their will through force and intrigue.

Nevertheless the hierarchy and the rules of the Darkfriends are applied and it appears also to follow some of the same rules as Shayol Ghul itself; for example, channeling can be restricted to those with the Great Lord 's favor.

Isam was raised in the Town from a very young age, and still uses it as a "base camp" when he is in the waking world. The Town also contains a great percentage of Samma N'Sei and their relatives.

The Forsaken are known to visit the Town from time to time as needed.

Town Watch.name: Town Watch
Town Watch.overview: The Town Watch is Baerlon 's guard. They patrol the streets to prevent problems, especially if the Children of the Light are around. They are armed with quarterstaffs.

Traitors' Court.name: Traitors' Court
Traitors' Court.overview:
Traitor's Court is an area in the White Tower in Tar Valon where executions, stillings and gentlings take place.

During Egwene 's test for accepted after she has gone through the third arch she is informed that Rand is being taken here to be gentled.

After being captured in the Stone of Tear, Amico Nagoyin and Joiya Byir are scheduled to be shipped to Tar Valon for stilling and execution..

Traveler.name: Traveler
Traveler.overview:
For the process to travel with the One Power , see Traveling .

For the Traveling People, see Tuatha'an .

Traveler is the horse owned by Gareth Bryne.

Traveler (Constellation).name: Traveler (Constellation)
Traveler (Constellation).overview: One of the constellations seen over the night skies of the Westlands, “with her staff standing out sharp.”

Traveling box.name: Traveling box
Traveling box.overview: A Traveling box, or nar'baha ("fool box" in the Old Tongue ), is a small box that supposedly uses saidin to enable Traveling. In reality, the box has no purpose.

Travels in the Aiel Waste, with Various.name: Travels in the Aiel Waste, with Various Observations on the Savage Inhabitants
Travels in the Aiel Waste, with Various.overview: Travels in the Aiel Waste, with Various Observations on the Savage Inhabitants is a "dusty, wood-bound book" that Rand studied in the Stone of Tear.

Treebrother.name: Treebrother
Treebrother.overview: Treebrother is a honorific sometimes used when referring to Nym or Ogier. Both Nym and Ogier spend much of their time and energy tending to nature, most notably in tending trees. Nym are seemingly made from various forms of plant life and have the ability to stimulate plant growth. Some Ogier are able to use treesinging to stimulate tree growth. Both Nym and Ogier were involved in Seed Singing in some way.

Treesinging.name: Treesinging
Treesinging.overview:
Treesinging is a Talent unique to the Ogier Treesingers in the modern days. With the Songs of Growing they stimulate the growth of living things, mostly plants and trees. It also allows them to use different songs to control the growth and to communicate, in a fashion, with the plant; Treesingers are known to produce extremely distinctive, valuable wooden crafts. They are able to make these wooden crafts without in any way harming the tree, "pulling" the shaped wooden artifact out of the tree without hurting it. The ability seems to have dwindled in recent times; Loial is one of the most talented Treesingers in a very long time.

During the time of the Age of Legends these songs were sung by Aiel and other people during Seed Singing which with the use of Nyms, made their agriculture extremely effective.

Rand listened to Loial singing to trees two times. First time at the Eye of the World when the Ogier brought back a dying tree to life and Rand described the song as if " the earth itself sang". Second time Loial sings to a tree in an alternate reality of their world and that time it sounded as the Ogier murmured his song and " the land echoed it in a whisper". It seemed pure song, music without words, or if there were any Rand could not hear them. But the song caught him up hypnotically, filling his mind almost the way the void did. " It seemed so familiar as if he should know it."

Lews Therin most probably used to sing those songs and he had the Voice, so did Ilyena as it is indicated in the Prologue of he Eye of the World. After Rand and Lews Therin became one person Rand used that "trick" during his meeting with Matt and Tuon in Ebu Dar when he was shielded from the One Power, yet he made Tuon's garden green and flourishing.

There were other examples for " unexpected plant behaviour " around Rand.

Tremalking.name: Tremalking
Tremalking.overview: Tremalking is a large and highly mountainous island found southwest of the main landmass of the Westlands. It is the largest of the Sea Folk islands. The female statue of the Choedan Kal stands on the island. It is populated by the peaceful Amayar.

Tremonsien.name: Tremonsien
Tremonsien.overview: Tremonsien is a small town in the northern region of Cairhien.

Trial Beneath the Light.name: Trial Beneath the Light
Trial Beneath the Light.overview: The Trial Beneath the Light is a legal process used among the Children of the Light for charges laid against one Child by another. The trial takes the form of a one-on-one sword fight that ends upon the death of one party. According to the High Inquisitor Rhadam Asunawa the right to Trial Beneath the Light was often claimed by the accused, when he knew that actual evidence would convict him. The right had not been claimed among the Children for four hundred years, until Galad Damodred challenged Lord Captain Commander Eamon Valda.

Trolloc Wars.name: Trolloc Wars
Trolloc Wars.overview:
The Trolloc Wars were a series of sustained conflicts fought between humanity and Shadowspawn between 1000 AB and 1350 AB. The Shadow armies were comprised mostly of Trollocs, hence the name, although Myrddraal, Draghkar, and most other forms of Shadowspawn are believed to have played major roles as well. During the war human servants of the Shadow - Darkfriends and Dreadlords - also fought against the forces of the Light.

The Trolloc Wars mark the end of the period of history known as After the Breaking and the beginning of the Free Years. The wars also mark the end of a period of intense cooperation between the nations of humanity and the beginning of a somewhat more fractious period, with all of the Ten Nations either totally destroyed in the war or weakened so much they collapsed shortly after it concluded.

Troop.name: Troop
Troop.overview: A troop is a military unit led by a lieutenant consisting of fifty cavalry.

True Blade of Malkier.name: True Blade of Malkier
True Blade of Malkier.overview: True Blade of Malkier is a title of the Malkieri monarch. Nothing is known as to what the title alludes. Currently, al'Lan Mandragoran holds this title.

Trustair.name: Trustair
Trustair.overview: Trustair is a town Matrim Cauthon planned on raiding, involving extensive yarn-spinning and conning a Warder into lending his fancloth cloak but it was rendered unnecessary by Verin Mathwin.

Truthspeaker.name: Truthspeaker
Truthspeaker.overview: A Truthspeaker or Soe'feia is a so'jhin who serves Seanchan royalty by telling them the absolute truth of a situation as they see it, no matter how painful or humiliating it might be. While many of the Blood call their Voice "Truthspeaker," few understand how much power they truly hold. Since those owned by the Blood are so'jhin they can be punished, but a true Truthspeaker is required to tell the absolute truth and may not be punished for it. Many think that Algwyn, the last man to hold the Crystal Throne, was mad to allow his soe'feia to live after she slapped him in the face before the entire court.

Tsodrelle'Aman.name: Tsodrelle'Aman
Tsodrelle'Aman.overview: Tsodrelle'Aman is the name of the lake formed in the city of Rhuidean after Rand al'Thor brought water to the sacred Aiel city by splitting the Earth down to a vast underground aquifer, a side-effect of his struggle with Asmodean for the Access Key. Its name translates to "Tears of the Dragon," although Aviendha thinks it should be called "Tears of the Aiel."

Tsorovan'm'hael.name: Tsorovan'm'hael
Tsorovan'm'hael.overview: Tsorovan'm'hael is a word in the Old Tongue meaning "Storm Leader." It is a title in the Asha'man military rank that was held by Charl Gedwyn before his death and is considered to be below only the M'Hael.

Tuatha'an.name: Tuatha'an
Tuatha'an.overview:
For the chapter in The Eye of the World called "The Traveling People", see The Eye of the World/Chapter 25 .

The Tuatha'an, (pronounced: too-AH-thah-AHN), are a nomadic people who live in brightly painted wagons and live by a pacifist philosophy known as the Way of the Leaf. Outsiders sometimes call them " Tinkers " or refer to them as the " Traveling People ".

Tuel.name: Tuel
Tuel.overview: Tuel is a region of Seanchan. No more is known about it.

Tuli.name: Tuli
Tuli.overview: Tuli was the name of Renna Emain 's kitten when Renna was a child.

Tunaighan Hills.name: Tunaighan Hills
Tunaighan Hills.overview:
The Tunaighan Hills lie just south of Caemlyn in Andor. These rolling hills are home to farms and small villages. The Black Tower is located close to this region. During his occupation of Caemlyn, Rand al'Thor used the Tunaighan Hills as a training ground for some of his troops, and attended a display of military forces there organized by Davram Bashere. The Tunaighan Hills are also home to some of Andor's finer vineyards, including some whose wines are served in the Royal Palace itself.

The hills may be an offshoot of the more extensive Hills of Kintara or Chishen Mountains to the south.

Turn Bow.name: Turn Bow
Turn Bow.overview: Turn Bow is a female pack leader.

Twilight (wolf).name: Twilight (wolf)
Twilight (wolf).overview: Twilight is a pack leader of wolves.

Twisting the Wind.name: Twisting the Wind
Twisting the Wind.overview: Twisting the Wind is a sword form. Other than the name, nothing is known about it.

Two Hares Leaping.name: Two Hares Leaping
Two Hares Leaping.overview: Two Hares Leaping is a sword form. Other than the name, nothing is known about it. This form was used during the duel between Galadedrid Damodred and Eamon Valda. It was used to counter Hummingbird Kisses the Honeyrose.

Two Moons.name: Two Moons
Two Moons.overview: Two Moons is a pack leader of wolves.

Two Rivers.name: Two Rivers
Two Rivers.overview: The Two Rivers is a region centrally-located in the Westlands which derives its name from the two rivers that mark its boundaries: the Taren River to the north and the White River to the south. It contains the villages of Taren Ferry, Deven Ride, Emond's Field, and Watch Hill, along with many independent farms.

Two Rivers Longbow.name: Two Rivers Longbow
Two Rivers Longbow.overview:
The Two Rivers Longbow is the weapon of choice among Two Rivers folk. Typical unstrung bows are a hand or two taller than the person drawing them. Black yew is considered the best wood for constructing a Two Rivers Longbow while the bowstring is constructed of tightly wrapped cords coated in a thin layer of beeswax to protect it from the elements.

Soldiers, notably the Shienarans, consider the weapon to be far too unwieldy since it is nearly impossible to fire from horseback. However, the weapon is put to great use defending against the Trolloc attacks during the Battle of Emond's Field. It has a range upwards of 500 paces and is so powerful that it can puncture clear through mail and oftentimes out the back end as well.

Two Spires.name: Two Spires
Two Spires.overview: The Two Spires are a sept of the Reyn Aiel. The sept hold is unknown.

Two step.name: Two step
Two step.overview: The two step is a small brown snake of the Aiel Waste.

Tyr.name: Tyr
Tyr.overview: Tyr is a geographical region of the Borderland nation of Saldaea. Its lord is Davram Bashere.

Tzora.name: Tzora
Tzora.overview:
Tzora was the second greatest city in the world at the time of the Age of Legends. It was known for its huge, multicoloured glass towers, varying in shape and glittering in the sunlight.

The city was destroyed by the male Aes Sedai Jaric Mondoran when he went insane after the Dark One cursed saidin. Ten thousand Da'shain Aiel sacrificed themselves to buy an extra hour for the people of the city to flee. Mondoran then unleashed an immense wave of heat which fused the stone, metal and flesh of the city together, leaving behind only a sheet of glass.

Unaligned sisters.name: Unaligned sisters
Unaligned sisters.overview: Those Aes Sedai who did not choose a side during the White Tower Schism, the Unaligned sisters, stood apart from the loyalists and the rebels.

Unfolding the Fan.name: Unfolding the Fan
Unfolding the Fan.overview:
For the similarly named sword form, see Folding the Fan .

Unfolding the Fan is a sword form. Other than the name, nothing is known about it. Rand al'Thor used this form to counter Stones Falling Down the Mountain when he was being attacked by his reflections in the Stone of Tear.

V'saine.name: V'saine
V'saine.overview:
V'saine was a city that existed during the Age of Legends. It was best known as the home of Collam Daan, a great university of silver and blue domes whose architecture was overshadowed only by the Sharom that floated overhead. Like all other cities of the Age of Legends, it was utterly ruined and only legends of it have survived.

The only known descriptions of the city of V'saine are given by those who visit the Glass Columns of Rhuidean and the Visions shown within and of those, only Rand al'Thors vision have been spoken aloud.

Valan Luca's Traveling Show.name: Valan Luca's Traveling Show
Valan Luca's Traveling Show.overview:
