Valan Luca's Traveling Show, or Valan Luca's Grand Traveling Show and Magnificent Display of Marvelous Wonders, is a band of performers led by Valan Luca, showman extraordinaire. The show is sometimes referred to as a circus or menagerie.

Elayne Trakand 's first impression upon meeting the show is that of a traveling menagerie due to the obvious animals with the camped people. Unlike a menagerie, though, the show also features human performers.

Venir Mountains.name: Venir Mountains
Venir Mountains.overview:
The Venir Mountains are a range of peaks lying along the south coast of Altara, stretching from Arran Head almost to the city of Ebou Dar. The Rhannon Hills may be part of this range.

In the early part of 1000 NE, the Seanchan invasion force positioned troops in the mountains to secure their flanks after taking Ebou Dar and also to prepare for a possible march on Illian. In response, Rand al'Thor led a mixed force of 6,000 Cairhienin, Tairen and Illianer troops supported by Asha'man into the mountains and in a series of rapid engagements dislodged the Seanchan forces and sent them reeling back to Ebou Dar. Rand attempted to force a decisive engagement east of the city, but his control of the One Power using Callandor proved erratic and he inflicted substantial damages on his own forces as well as the Seanchan, forcing him to abandon the campaign.

Verin's letter to Mat.name: Verin's letter to Mat
Verin's letter to Mat.overview: Verin Mathwin gave a letter to Matrim Cauthon before she used Traveling to take the Band of the Red Hand to Caemlyn in Andor. He swore an oath that if he opened it he would carry out its message and would be allowed to leave Caemlyn in ten days. If he didn't he could leave in thirty days and be forced to burn it. He chose not to open it and it was opened by Olver while Mat was away with Thomdril Merrilin and Noal Charin in the Tower of Ghenjei.

Victory of Kidron.name: Victory of Kidron
Victory of Kidron.overview: The Victory of Kidron is a three-masted Seanchan greatship.

View-wall.name: View-wall
View-wall.overview: A device from the Age of Legends that allowed the user to create any illusion on the walls of a room such as a forest.

Village Council.name: Village Council
Village Council.overview:
In the Two Rivers district of western Andor the villages of Taren Ferry, Watch Hill, Emond's Field, and Deven Ride hold themselves politically independent and practice a form of gender-based bicameral government. The Village Council of each community is an all-male eight-member committee whose councilors are elected by the corresponding villagers and nearby farmers. Each council is headed by a Mayor who is elected in a similar fashion and serves as one of the eight members. Village councils are common in communities outside the Two Rivers as well. In most places these councils will make decisions affecting their areas as a whole and will negotiate with councils of other villages over matters jointly affecting the communities.

Village councilors establish economic policy with merchants, peddlers, and the councils of other communities. Twice each year these councils will assist their mayors in observing trade with visiting merchant caravans that travel to the Two Rivers to purchase Tabac and wool. The primary function of the Mayor in this regard is to ensure a fair marketplace for all participants transacting within a village's sphere of influence. Councilors will also engage in the resolution of disputes related to property ownership. In extremely rare cases, councils have sent out patrols if villages believe they are being victimized by outsiders seeking to steal property from locals. While the elections for mayors and councilors are usually peaceful in the three smaller villages, campaigns in Taren Ferry have been known to become quite contentious, sometimes leading to prolonged quarreling among townsfolk.

The power of the Village Council in each community is balanced by - and often at odds with -the equally important Women's Circle. Members of the Circle are elder females in each village that are chosen to join the Circle by existing members. Each Circle is headed by a Wisdom who serves for life. Though these two ruling bodies frequently bicker over small issues, it is generally understood and accepted that Councils regulate matters of economics and safety while Circles hold sway over social issues and serve as guardians of culture.

Beginning in the summer of 999 NE, the councils of each village began to defer to Perrin Aybara and Faile Aybara who have emerged as sovereign nobles ruling over the Two Rivers district. Under this new structure, councils have ceased to govern independently and now function as enforcers of Faile's economic policies. Faile has been very active in consolidating power with councils; first by exerting influence over Jerinvar Barstere and the councilors of Watch Hill prior to the Battle of Emond's Field. She next manipulated the council of Taren Ferry to maneuver men sympathetic to Perrin into power in order to consolidate her political control over the community, though she has been forbidden by her husband to repeat similar actions in the future.

Vine-carved staff.name: Vine-carved staff
Vine-carved staff.overview: The vine-carved staff is a staff that belonged to Moiraine Damodred. It is carved in vines and flowers. She uses it as a walking staff. She uses it multiple times when fighting or channeling. It was burned to a char when she cut a hole in a waygate near Fal Dara.

Visions of Rhuidean.name: Visions of Rhuidean
Visions of Rhuidean.overview: When Rand enters the glass forest ter'angreal of Rhuidean he learns the history of the Aiel through his own ancestors' eyes.

Void.name: Void
Void.overview:
The Void, aka The Flame and the Void, aka The Oneness, aka Ko'di are different terms for a state of nothingness, a concentration or meditation technique used in combat arts throughout the cultures and Ages of the Wheel of Time universe. The mind is completely cleared from fears and emotions leaving the individual in a hyperaware state of consciousness to be able to focus exclusively on their desired task.

Blademasters enter the Void in order to achieve perfection in performing sword forms. Archers use the Void to aim without distraction. Channellers use the Void as a preparation to seize saidin, or in case of females they "open themselves to embrace the source".

"The Flame and the Void" refers to the visualization of a single flame of a candle into which the person could throw all their emotions, fears and obstacles which block them from performing. All concerns, thoughts, even the concerns of life and death - can be learned to be fed into the flame. This allows the user to perceive reality cleared from everything distracting. Sometimes other external focusing device is used.

Another technique is to imagine to become one with their weapon and one with their target or opponent, removing obstacles of rational thoughts and emotions such as the opponent is stronger or more advanced in combat, and such.

Voyages Among the Sea Folk.name: Voyages Among the Sea Folk
Voyages Among the Sea Folk.overview: Voyages Among the Sea Folk is a book by Jain Charin. Rand al'Thor saw a copy in the library of the Queen's Blessing inn.

Wagon Bridge.name: Wagon Bridge
Wagon Bridge.overview:
The Wagon Bridge is one of three bridges that span the Winespring Water in Emond's Field. Its name derives from the fact that it is the only bridge wide and stout enough to bear wagons. It crosses the stream on the east side of the village Green next to the Winespring Inn.

The bridge marks the point where the North Road, coming down from Taren Ferry and Watch Hill, becomes the Old Road leading to Deven Ride. Although outsiders often find it odd that the continuous road through Emond's Field is named differently on either side of the Wagon Bridge, villagers accept the convention without question.

War of Power.name: War of Power
War of Power.overview:
The War of Power, also known as The War of the Shadow, was a devastating global conflict that marked the beginning of the end of the Age of Legends.

In the supposedly utopian society of the Age of Legends, Aes Sedai were frequently devoted to academic and scientific endeavors. However, the society of the time had advanced to the point that females and males each being able to draw strictly from a single half of the One Power had seemingly become an impediment to further progress. Then, a new source of energy that men and women could evidently both wield in equal measure was discovered outside of the Pattern. In order to gain access to this power, a team of Aes Sedai researchers led by the esteemed scientist Beidomon used the One Power to drill a hole through the Pattern and into the barrier that separated this energy source from the rest of reality. As it turned out, the source of the energy that the researchers had been attempting to access was the " True Power "; the essence of the Dark One. In creating the hole, they inadvertently breached the Dark One's prison and allowed his influence to begin spreading throughout the world.

War of the Hundred Years.name: War of the Hundred Years
War of the Hundred Years.overview: The War of the Hundred Years was a devastating series of overlapping wars among constantly shifting alliances, precipitated by the death of Artur Hawkwing and the resulting struggle for his empire. With the deaths of all of his surviving children in the Westlands (the fate of others in Seanchan and Shara were unknown at that time), there was no designated heir to inherit the mantle of High King. As a result, the Empire fragmented and collapsed. Over the course of 123 years of incessant fighting, the nations of the New Era were formed.

War of the Second Dragon.name: War of the Second Dragon
War of the Second Dragon.overview: The War of the Second Dragon is a major military conflict that took place between FY 939 and 943 and spanned most of the Westlands. It was in this conflict that Artur Paendrag Tanreall rose to prominence and gained the nickname "Hawkwing." The war was fought between a loose alliance of eastern kingdoms allied to Tar Valon against the false Dragon Guaire Amalasan and the kingdoms he had conquered.

Wars of Cairhienin Succession.name: Wars of Cairhienin Succession
Wars of Cairhienin Succession.overview: The Wars of Cairhienin Succession refer to the internal realignments of power within the kingdom of Cairhien. There have been five such wars since the War of the Hundred Years, although the Cairhienin prefer not to discuss them with outsiders. These conflicts should not be confused with the Succession Wars of neighboring Andor.

Wasp-jelly.name: Wasp-jelly
Wasp-jelly.overview:
Defined as "a small aquatic creature that appears to be made of jelly but stings severely when touched". In the real world, a jellyfish.

Siuan references them when mentioning the danger of stirring up the Asha'man:

Watch Hill.name: Watch Hill
Watch Hill.overview: Watch Hill is a village north-centrally located in the Two Rivers region, directly north of Emond's Field along the North Road.

Watcher of the Seals.name: Watcher of the Seals
Watcher of the Seals.overview:
Watcher of the Seals is one of the titles of the Amyrlin Seat, referring to the Seven Seals on the Dark One's prison.

The title descends from the Breaking of the World and the formation of the White Tower. At the time, the Seven Seals were dispersed to prevent male Aes Sedai or Shadowspawn from finding them. However, sometime during the Trolloc Wars, knowledge of these hiding places had been lost, and the White Tower apparently never actually possessed them. Since then, while no Amyrlin has known the location of the seals, they still claim the title.

As Rand al'Thor later pointed out, the title is essentially symbolic and was practically meaningless, as the White Tower neither possessed the seals nor had any Amyrlin Seat ever really watched over them.

Anyway just prior to the Last Battle finally the Amyrlin Egwene fulfilled somehow the role of Watcher of the Seals when Rand was convinced to give her the three remaining intact Seals (even if later it was revealed that they were not the real ones because of a manipulation by M'Hael). During the Last Battle Egwene also explains just a moment before to die when it is the right time to break the three real Seals, permitting the Dragon to accomplish his mission.

Water Flows Downhill.name: Water Flows Downhill
Water Flows Downhill.overview: Water Flows Downhill is a sword form. Other than the name, nothing is known about it. During thier duel over Callandor in the Stone of Tear, Rand al'Thor flowed through this form, as well as Parting the Silk and Wind and Rain, with a saidin -wrought sword in an effort to best Be'lal. Gawyn used this form agaisnt a Trolloc during the Last Battle

Water oath.name: Water oath
Water oath.overview: Water oaths are the most sacred and binding promises in Aiel culture.

Water Way.name: Water Way
Water Way.overview:
The Water Way is a philosophy followed by the Amayar, the fair-skinned natives of Tremalking. It is a very peaceful way of life similar to the Way of the Leaf, and its followers prize acceptance on what it is, rather than what might be wished for.

It is unknown whether the Water Way continued to live on anywhere in the world after the Amayar's mass suicide following the Cleansing of saidin.

Watered Silk.name: Watered Silk
Watered Silk.overview: Watered Silk is a sword form. Other than the name, nothing is known about it. During thier duel over Callandor in the Stone of Tear, either Rand al'Thor or Be'lal used this form to counter The Falling Leaf.

Waterwood.name: Waterwood
Waterwood.overview: The Waterwood is the name given to the wooded floodplain located in the eastern area of the Two Rivers region. It is a swampy area of streams, ponds, and forests located due east of Emond's Field.

Wavedancer.name: Wavedancer
Wavedancer.overview: Wavedancer is an Atha'an Miere raker.

Wavemistress.name: Wavemistress
Wavemistress.overview:
Wavemistress is the Atha'an Miere title for the leader of a Sea Folk Clan. The Wavemistress of a clan is also the Sailmistress of her own ship.

The Wavemistress usually appoints her Cargomaster to become Swordmaster for her, and one of her Windfinders as her personal advisor.

A Wavemistress can be recognized by the large number of medallions on her nose-ring. Often, they number so greatly that there is no space in between each one.

Way of the Leaf.name: Way of the Leaf
Way of the Leaf.overview:
The Way of the Leaf is a pacifistic code of honor practiced by the Da'shain Aiel. The Tuatha'an, who descended from the Da'shain Aiel, also follow it. The philosophy uses the leaf as a model for life; not using force or resisting its fall from the tree. It is similar to the Water Way. It is held in contempt by most of the people in the Aiel Waste and the Wetlands, probably due to the fact that the Tinkers follow it.

Under the Way of the Leaf, the Tuatha'an will not raise a hand even to defend themselves.

Ways.name: Ways
Ways.overview: The Ways are an area outside of reality crafted by male Aes Sedai to allow Ogier to travel safely between their stedding.

Weesin.name: Weesin
Weesin.overview:
Weesin is a small village in Altara. It is located north of Ebou Dar along the Great North Road.

Even though Valan Luca describes the village as "flyspeck," he still wants to stop his show to perform.

Weikin Rebellion.name: Weikin Rebellion
Weikin Rebellion.overview: The Weikin Rebellion is a historical conflict frequently studied by White Tower novices. After Egwene al'Vere was forcibly returned to novice status she was quizzed about the rebellion by Bennae Nalsad. At the time, Egwene knew nothing about it.

West Stable.name: West Stable
West Stable.overview:
The West Stable in the White Tower is a three story stone gray structure. In front of the the structure there is a paved stable yard. The path that leads to the West Stable is on the same side of the Tower as the Accepted's quarters.

In 978 NE, all of the Tower's Accepted rush to the stable when they are allowed to leave Tar Valon for the census just after the Aiel War. The census is a cover in order to find the identity of the Dragon Reborn.

Westlands.name: Westlands
Westlands.overview: The Westlands is one of several names given to the continent or subcontinent that stretches from the Aiel Waste to the Aryth Ocean, and from the Great Blight to the Sea of Storms. It forms the westernmost part of one large landmass that also incorporates the Aiel Waste and the land of Shara, as well as a number of offshore islands belonging to the Sea Folk.

Westwood.name: Westwood
Westwood.overview: The Westwood is a dense tangled forest that extends along the eastern foothills of the Mountains of Mist in the region known as the Two Rivers.

Wetlander.name: Wetlander
Wetlander.overview: Wetlander is an Aiel term used to refer to those who live west of the Spine of the World. Its origin derives from the fact that the Westlands are a much "wetter" place than the Three-fold Land. The term is often used as a pejorative by the Aiel who view those not hailing from the Aiel Waste as being weak and soft.

What is yet to happen.name: What is yet to happen
What is yet to happen.overview: This is a theory page, listing what is yet to happen or happened off screen by the conclusion of A Memory of Light. Feel free to add what is missing or re-organize it if the classification, by person and what comes from them, is messy.

Wheel of Time audiobooks.name: Wheel of Time audiobooks
Wheel of Time audiobooks.overview:
The audio versions of the main series books and prequel first came out in the form of cassette tapes, then later CD and digital download. Both abridged and unabridged versions have been published, although the abridged versions are no longer available to purchase. The unabridged versions were originally not available for the commercial market, but solely for the rental and library markets.

Robert Jordan did listen to the audio versions of his own books, finding it useful to gain a different perspective:

An audio version of The World of Robert Jordan's Wheel of Time was recorded by Paul Woodson and published by Bill Fawcett and Associates in 1997.

Unabridged audiobooks in languages other than English do exist. See Wheel of Time translations for a summary.

The Eye of the World and The Wheel of Time Companion have also been published in braille.

Whirlwind on the Mountain.name: Whirlwind on the Mountain
Whirlwind on the Mountain.overview: Whirlwind on the Mountain is a sword form. Other than the name, nothing is known about it. Rand al'Thor used this form with a saidin -wrought blade to defend against spears thrown by Couladin and two other Aiel after returning from Rhuidean with Matrim Cauthon.

White Ajah.name: White Ajah
White Ajah.overview:
The White Ajah is one of the seven legitimate Aes Sedai Ajahs. Sisters of this Ajah abstain from matters of the world and worldly knowledge, and instead devote themselves to questions of philosophy and truth. The head of the White Ajah is called the First Reasoner.

Also see List of White Ajah sisters.

White Cliff.name: White Cliff
White Cliff.overview: The White Cliff is a sept of the Shaido Aiel.

White henpepper.name: White henpepper
White henpepper.overview:
White henpepper is an herb that can be found in the area of Two Rivers and Amadicia. It is a soothing remedy for a toothache.

Another application for white henpepper is as a hair dye; a wash of the herb will turn hair black as night. Pokeleaf makes an effective wash for removing the color from white henpepper.

White Lions.name: White Lions
White Lions.overview:
The White Lions are Andoran soldiers who have sworn fealty to the Lion Throne of Andor, as opposed to the Queen of Andor.

The White Lions were recruited by Rahvin, posing as a western Andoran lord named Gaebril to replace the Queen's Guards. Rahvin had designs to claim the Lion Throne for himself, and needed the swords to achieve his goals as the Queen's Guards would have fought him to the end.

After Rahvin was destroyed by balefire wielded by Rand, and Rand himself had taken control of the city, the majority of the White Lions fled Andor and ended up near the Spine of the World with Cairhienin rebels.

White Mountain.name: White Mountain
White Mountain.overview:
The White Mountain is a sept of the Chareen Aiel.

When Rand al'Thor asks Aviendha what type of trouble could occur at Imre Stand, she suggests it could be a raid for sheep or goats by the White Mountain or Jarra septs of the Chareen clan. They are the two septs closest to Imre.

White Ribbon.name: White Ribbon
White Ribbon.overview:
The White Ribbon is a traditional symbol of truce in Arad Doman whereupon warring parties will set aside violence to enable a conference. If one person offers the White Ribbon and his opponents accept it, they will be bound by oaths on their souls and hopes of salvation not to draw a weapon against each other or shed blood for three days.

The White Ribbon was most recently offered by Rodel Ituralde to the various Dragonsworn lords and Taraboner soldiers on Almoth Plain and in Arad Doman. Ituralde believed his order to do so came from King Alsalam, but it was actually sent by Graendal. The Dragonsworn and Taraboners accepted the White Ribbon and Ituralde convinced them to make a truce to battle the Seanchan.

White Spray.name: White Spray
White Spray.overview: The White Spray is an Atha'an Miere soarer with two raked masts. The ship belongs to Clan Shodein.

White Tail.name: White Tail
White Tail.overview: White Tail is a wolf belonging to Leafhunter's pack.

White Tower Library.name: White Tower Library
White Tower Library.overview: The White Tower Library, sometimes called the Great Library, is generally considered the largest and most complete library in the world. It is only partially open to outsiders.

Whitebridge.name: Whitebridge
Whitebridge.overview:
Whitebridge is a town in central-western Andor, named for the huge milk-white bridge that spans the River Arinelle.

Most buildings in Whitebridge are made of stone or brick, and the docks are made of wood. All social classes are represented in Whitebridge, from merchants in their shiny lacquered carriages and velvet coats to farmers and peasants in rough wool.

Whitebridge Gate.name: Whitebridge Gate
Whitebridge Gate.overview: The Whitebridge Gate is one of Baerlon 's gates. It is assumed that this gate leads to the road to Whitebridge.

Whitecap.name: Whitecap
Whitecap.overview: The Whitecap is a ship of the Atha'an Miere.

Whitecloak War.name: Whitecloak War
Whitecloak War.overview:
The Whitecloak War was a conflict from summer 957 NE to autumn 959 NE in which the Lord Captain Commander of the Children of the Light, Pedron Niall, attempted to expand the borders of Amadicia into northern Altara. The Children of the Light call it The Troubles as "Whitecloak" is a pejorative to their organisation.

Altara, as a weak and decentralised nation, could not withstand the invaders alone, gaining assistance from Murandy and the much stronger Illian. Those nations feared that the Whitecloaks would not stop with Altara and continue into their own territories. Whether true or not, they believed it. The strategy of the side of the Altarans was referred to as The Altaran Noon, an attempt to make the Altaran territory "too hot to handle" for occupying forces.

Asides from the heads of the national forces, known veterans of the conflict include current High Captain of the Tower Guard Jimar Chubain, who fought as a mercenary for Illian, and Tam al'Thor, who distinguished himself enough to become appointed to the elite Illianer Companions.

Andor may have also sent troops to reinforce. According to Talmanes, Andor had not sent troops south into Murandy in large numbers since the Aiel and Whitecloak Wars and those troops were merely "passing though". Andor's involvement is not mentioned in either The World of Robert Jordan's The Wheel of Time or The Wheel of Time Companion, however.

Whitefennel.name: Whitefennel
Whitefennel.overview:
Whitefennel is an herb that can be found in the Two Rivers region and in Tear. A little whitefennel can be given to a birthing mother to aid her during a particularly difficult labor.

Whitefennel should not be confused with gray fennel, which is poisonous.

Wildfire.name: Wildfire
Wildfire.overview: Wildfire is a female wolf and the leader of a wolfpack.

Wildrose.name: Wildrose
Wildrose.overview: Wildrose is the name of a horse once ridden by Min Farshaw.

Willar.name: Willar
Willar.overview: Willar is a small village in Ghealdan, east of the River Boern.

Willowbark.name: Willowbark
Willowbark.overview:
Willowbark is a fairly common herbal medicine. It is used to treat pain, particularly headaches.

Tam and Rand keep some willowbark among their bags of medicines. Mat, who keeps willowbark in his saddlebags, offers willowbark tea to Perrin after he speaks to the wolves. Nynaeve tells Thom to ask Rendra for willowbark or acem to relieve his bruised head. Nynaeve used willowbark after channeling too much at Algarin Pendaloan 's manor.

Wind (horse).name: Wind (horse)
Wind (horse).overview: Wind is the name of a horse ridden by Olver cross-country as well as successfully on the racetrack in Ebou Dar.

Wind (wolf).name: Wind (wolf)
Wind (wolf).overview: Wind is the name of a wolf in Dapple 's pack.

Wind and Rain.name: Wind and Rain
Wind and Rain.overview: Wind and Rain is a sword form. Other than the name, nothing is known about it. During thier duel over Callandor in the Stone of Tear, Rand al'Thor flowed through this form, as well as Parting the Silk and Water Flows Downhill, with a saidin -wrought sword in an effort to best Be'lal.

Wind Racer.name: Wind Racer
Wind Racer.overview:
Wind Racer is an Atha'an Miere darter.

Cemeille din Selaan Long Eyes, Sailmistress of Wind Racer, learns of the suicide of the Amayar and sails as fast as she can to Illian to tell the Mistress of the Ships the news.

Windbiter's Finger.name: Windbiter's Finger
Windbiter's Finger.overview: Windbiter's Finger is a substantial peninsula extending several hundred miles into the sea from the Shadow Coast. It marks the point where the Aryth Ocean meets the Sea of Storms. The peninsula is ragged and semi-submerged in places, and is dangerous to shipping. The Sea Folk and other traders use it as a navigational marker, but do not travel too close to it.

Windfinder.name: Windfinder
Windfinder.overview: Windfinders are Sea Folk women who advise Sailmistresses, Wavemistresses, and the Mistress of the Ships in plotting a course based on the wind and currents.

Windrunner.name: Windrunner
Windrunner.overview: Windrunner is an Atha'an Miere ship.

Winespring.name: Winespring
Winespring.overview: The Winespring is a natural aquifer located on the west side of the Green in Emond's Field and is the headwater of the Winespring Water.

Winespring Water.name: Winespring Water
Winespring Water.overview: The Winespring Water is a large stream that originates in the village of Emond's Field.

Wing (horse).name: Wing (horse)
Wing (horse).overview: Wing is a horse owned by Sheriam Bayanar.

Winged Guards.name: Winged Guards
Winged Guards.overview: The Winged Guards are the military force of Mayene.

Winter's Heart.name: Winter's Heart
Winter's Heart.overview:
Winter's Heart (abbreviated WH ) is the ninth book in The Wheel of Time series. It was published by Tor Books ↗ and released on November 7, 2000. Upon its release, it immediately rose to the #1 position on the New York Times ↗ hardcover fiction bestseller list ↗, making it the second Wheel of Time book to reach the #1 position on that list. It remained on the list for the next two months. It is 780 pages long.

As is the usual style, the title of the book is incorporated into the verse quoted from the Prophecies of the Dragon at the beginning, and also refers to the winter that was created by the use of the Bowl of the Winds in the prior book.

It is also a reference to the ever deepening cold in Rand's heart.

Winterfinch.name: Winterfinch
Winterfinch.overview: Winterfinch is a horse owned by Beonin Marinye.

Winternight.name: Winternight
Winternight.overview: Winternight is a holiday marking the end of winter. It is celebrated the night before Bel Tine and participants typically spend the night visiting one another, exchanging gifts, and eating and drinking together.

Wisdom.name: Wisdom
Wisdom.overview:
For the chapter in The Eye of the World called "The Wisdom", see The Eye of the World/Chapter 16 .

Wisdom is a term used in the Two Rivers region of Andor to describe a village healer and leader of the local Women's Circle. Outside the Two Rivers and depending on the region, such a woman might instead have another title, such as Guide, Healer, Wise Woman, Reader, Advisor, Seeker, or Wise One, although Wisdom is also used in some other regions. Regardless of title, such women possess similar skills in the application of herbal remedies and are adept at treating illnesses and injuries. Many, though not all, are saidar -sensitive, but they are almost without variation Wilders with no complete knowledge of their true power potential.

The position of Wisdom is one of great responsibility and authority, both actual and implied. Wisdoms are generally considered the equal to a village Mayor, and in some places his superior. Unlike mayors, Wisdoms are generally chosen for life and it is exceptionally rare for a Wisdom to be removed from her office before her death. All Wisdoms claim that they can " Listen to the Wind " but only those who are also wilders actually have the ability.

Wise One.name: Wise One
Wise One.overview: Wise Ones are matriarchal leaders among the Aiel. Every Hold has at least one Wise One and they socially rank as peers alongside a Roofmistress or the chief of a Hold.

Wolf-Head Banner.name: Wolf-Head Banner
Wolf-Head Banner.overview: The Wolf-Head Banner is the banner given to Perrin Aybara after he saves the Two Rivers from an onslaught of Trollocks. Following the battles many call Perrin Aybara the Lord of the Two Rivers and erect the Wolf-Head Banner for him. Perrin many times protests the banner and orders it taken down but in the end he accepts the Banner.

Wolf.name: Wolf
Wolf.overview:
While it is not widely known, wolves are sentient creatures who can communicate through telepathy and form close social bonds with their pack, and occasionally with wolfbrothers, humans who share the gift for communicating with them. When wolves and wolfbrothers communicate they don't talk so much as send sensations and images. Wolfbrothers can use the wolves to track over long distances.

Wolves remember every life they have lived. When a wolf dies, the soul of the wolf enters the "wolf dream," which is actually Tel'aran'rhiod. Each wolf is born again into the world in a cycle. If a wolf is killed by a Darkhound, or in the wolf dream, the cycle is broken. They call Darkhounds "Shadowbrothers," creatures made from wolf stock by twisting the soul of a wolf.

The wolves are aware of Rand al'Thor. They call him "Shadowkiller" and are in awe of him. Wolves also know of Tarmon Gai'don and refer to it as the "last hunt." It is widely believed that Perrin Aybara will call the wolves to Tarmon Gai'don.

Wolf names are not simple. For example, the name Two Moons is actually described as "a night shrouded pool, smooth as ice in the instant before a breeze stirred, with a tang of autumn in the air, and one moon hanging full in the sky and another reflected perfectly on the water so that it was difficult to tell which was real. And that is cutting it to the bone."

Wolves are generally feared, used often in Two Rivers phrases such as "whether the wolf beats the bear or the bear beats the wolf, the rabbit always loses" although this isn't a reference to wolves. People often suspect a link between the Shadow and wolves, unaware that in actuality wolves harbor deep hatred for the Shadow. Whitecloaks frequently hunt wolves, claiming that Trollocs use wolf skin, muzzle, teeth, and claws to be created. Wolves hate Trollocs and Myrddraal; packs of wolves can overpower Trollocs in small numbers quite easily and will hunt them if possible, but their hatred for Myrddraal goes so deep that entire packs will sacrifice themselves to pull a single Fade down.

Wolf Guard.name: Wolf Guard
Wolf Guard.overview:
The Wolf Guard is a military force comprised of former mercenaries and refugees turned soldiers sworn to Perrin Aybara. A select few serve Perrin's personal guard.

They were trained by Tam al'Thor and Dannil Lewin following the Battle of Malden. The Wolf Guard utilize the Red Wolfhead Banner as their rallying insignia. They have been specially trained in the use of the Two Rivers Longbow.

They fought honorably in the Last Battle under Tam's command.

Wolfspeak.name: Wolfspeak
Wolfspeak.overview: Wolfspeak is the terms that wolves use during telepathic communication with Wolfkin that uses imagery to describe matters that have specific terminology in the Old Tongue or New Tongue, but is too complex for wolves to understand. They therefore use somewhat unusual language to describe certain things and beings in the world.

Women's Circle.name: Women's Circle
Women's Circle.overview:
In the Two Rivers district of western Andor the villages of Taren Ferry, Watch Hill, Emond's Field, and Deven Ride hold themselves politically independent and practice a form of gender-based bicameral government. The Women's Circle of each community is an all-female committee whose members are selected by consensus of woman in each village. Each Circle is guided by a Wisdom who is chosen by the Circle and serves for life. The number of members in a Circle is not set at a certain amount, though they do tend to be proportional in size to the population of the differing communities; with Taren Ferry's Circle being the largest and Deven Ride's having the fewest members. In lands outside the Two Rivers, Circles exist but are often known by other names such as The Ring or The Gathering.

The primary function of Circles is to establish and maintain social protocols within Two Rivers culture. A young woman in the Two Rivers is not allowed to Braid her hair until members of the local Women's Circle have decided that she is of marriageable age. When weddings do occur, members of the Circle stand as witnesses while the local Wisdom performs the ceremony. Members of the Circle convene when villagers break with social norms; such as when a youth is caught misbehaving or if two young women are fighting over a local boy. They will also gather to settle non-property related disputes among folk. Members are generally versed in a Wisdom's skills and might assist her in the arts of healing, weather prediction, and herblore.

The power of the Women's Circle in each community is balanced by - and often at odds with -the equally important Village Council. Councils are eight-member committees of men in each village who have been elected to office by townsfolk. They are headed by a Mayor who is also elected into office and serves as one of the eight members. Though these two ruling bodies frequently bicker over small issues, it is generally understood and accepted that Councils regulate economic matters and Circles hold sway over social issues.

Beginning in the summer of 999 NE the Circles of each village began to defer to Perrin Aybara and Faile Aybara who have emerged as sovereign nobles ruling over the Two Rivers district. Under this new structure, Circles dispatch their Wisdoms to Emond's Field to engage in dispute resolution while in audience with either Perrin or Faile. Faile has also worked in secret to manipulate Circle memberships in order to consolidate her political control over the four communities in the Two Rivers.

Woodsman Strips the Branch.name: Woodsman Strips the Branch
Woodsman Strips the Branch.overview: Woodsman Strips the Branch is a sword form. Other than the name, nothing is known about it.

World's End.name: World's End
World's End.overview:
World's End is the name given to the extremely remote, far northwestern coast of the Westlands. Comprising the western coastline of Saldaea, this area to the south of the Great Blight consists of rocky, sheer cliffs that plunge into the Aryth Ocean. The Banikhan Mountains lie just inland, and prevent easy access to the coast.

When Lan Mandragoran asks his wife Nynaeve to help him with his personal war against the Shadow, she drops him off at World's End and then quietly goes to rally Borderlanders to his banner, starting in the nearby town of Kayacun.

World Sea.name: World Sea
World Sea.overview:
The World Sea is a geographical area of the Age of Legends. It is described by Ishamael as being analogous to the Aryth Ocean of the Third Age, suggesting that the World Sea was the largest and most extensive ocean of the Age of Legends. Interestingly, at one point an inhabitant of Seanchan also refers to the Aryth Ocean as the World Sea (instead of the traditional Seanchan name, the Eastern Sea), indicating that Seanchan culture at some point adopted the alternate term.

It is possible that it was a large ocean surrounding the continent(s) that the people lived on, like that surrounding Pangaea ↗.

Worrynot root.name: Worrynot root
Worrynot root.overview: Worrynot root is an herb that can be found in the Two Rivers region. It is a common remedy for fever.

WoTCon.name: WoTCon
WoTCon.overview: WoTCon is a Wheel of Time Convention that takes place annually in Columbus, Ohio. It was founded in 2022.

Yellow Ajah.name: Yellow Ajah
Yellow Ajah.overview:
The Yellow Ajah is a sisterhood of Aes Sedai devoted to the studies of Healing. The leader of the Yellow Ajah is called the First Weaver.

Also see List of Yellow Ajah sisters.

Younglings.name: Younglings
Younglings.overview: The Younglings are a military force born of the White Tower Schism ]]. They were loyal to Elaida's White Tower and viewed Elaida as the rightful Amyrlin Seat.

Zara.name: Zara
Zara.overview: Zara was a violent game from the Age of Legends.

Zemai.name: Zemai
Zemai.overview: Zemai is a staple grain of the Aiel Waste, and is used in the production of oosquai.

Zomara.name: Zomara
Zomara.overview: A zomara (plural zomaran ) is a type of Shadowspawn created by Aginor during the Age of Legends for the sole purpose of serving.

Zushi.name: Zushi
Zushi.overview: Zushi is a former Atha'an Miere Windfinder who was captured by the Seanchan and collared as a Damane.
